(May technically contain spoilers) I should preface this review with saying I had a really bad feeling that this film was really going to suck. I had hoped it would live up to the hype, but as so often happens with Hollywood hype, films fall flat on their own false reputation.  Baz Luhrmann's film "Moulin Rouge" far exceeded any expectations I had, negative or positive, and was a truly magical and beautiful cinematic experience. While most filmmakers agree that at a fundamental level, films should be in some way about the human condition, there is always a drive to create, innovate and impress.  All too often films try too hard to do one or the other to extremes, but once in a while a film comes along and does them both, splendidly. "Moulin Rouge" is one such film. The story in "Moulin Rouge" takes the tried and true narrative path of the innocent love story, between the coveted and gorgeous courtesan, 'Satine' (Nicole Kidman) and young naive writer 'Christian' (Ewan Macgregor). The plot centers on these two characters' struggle to practice their love, which is forbidden for a variety of reasons.  The most pressing obstacle to their love is the 'evil' (read: classic slimey Hollywood bad guy character) Duke of Monroth, played hilariously by the talented Richard Roxburgh.  Without giving too much of the story away, the Duke's character puts the young lovers in a decidedly tough position and ultimately puts their love to the test. Cinematically, "Moulin Rouge" is a feast for the eyes, as well as the ears.  Yes it can be campy. Yes it can be over the top. Is that a problem? If you are a cynic who can't handle too much colour (and I have to tell you I thought I was) or honestly believe in nothing but stark realism in cinema, then this film is probably not for you. To those of you with an open mind, this film is a gorgeous rainbow for the eyes and ears.The soundtrack. Where to begin?  A postmodern extravaganza of lovesong lyrics well weaved into traditional orchestral songs, as well as ultra modern thumping electronica... Luhrman (who was the album producer) has done to the musical what hiphop did to the humble sampler. (Who said you can only sample recorded audio? Why not lyrics and score as well?)..  Again I don't want to give anything away, but think of all the many cheesy love songs of the last twenty years compressed into a couple of all-encompassing big band musical scores in the most tastefully kitsch and gorgeously wonderful way. This film oozes post modern cred. :) As for the performances themselves - it was great to see that non-musicians were chosen to lead, as well as sing. They (Kidman, Macgregor) have good voices, but they don't have the heavily over-trained voices of a singer. In my humble opinion this makes the soundtrack so much more honest, which is so important for a love story like this.  They don't sound like pop stars, they sound like your friend or neighbour who has a nice voice (maybe they even sound like you)... Technically. Well all I can say is as an Australian in the film industry I often wondered why it took Hollywood so long to work out we always had the skills (I guess now we have the currency that will soon come in bundles ;P ), but anyway the special effects and studio wizardry in this film is what the world has come to expect from films out of Fox in Sydney, so no surprises there. And the only minor quibble I had?  The music was wonderful. BUT (and I strongly believe it was just the theater I was in - a preview screening with most patrons just thankful to be there), the mixes on the songs, while on the whole very good, at the worst of times did not really seem (technically, mixing) designed for a cinema space. For the most part they were rich and sonically dynamic, but on one or two tracks I felt the audience was a bit dissapointed at how the location audio was pushed right forward at the expense of bassy thumpin' tracks. Nonetheless, the quality was excellent, despite the concerned head scratching of one or two patrons in the theater I was in. Cinema audiences these days, I ask you. ;)  It's not enough that a film like "Moulin Rouge" blows their mind and their preconceptions, they need the bass cranked and for it to shake them out of their seats. The on screen love between Satine and Christian was enough for me.  Go watch this film, and please do as I did and keep an open mind and heart, you will not be dissapointed.

Review title: No Laws. No Limits. One Rule. See This Movie and You Will Fall In Love.
Review_body: The first time I saw the film, I wasn't quite sure what to make of it.  I came away not really sure what the colorful, unique, fast-paced piece of art was really all about.  I liked it, but I didn't know why.  But this is not a shortcoming of the film, but probably its greatest strength: it makes you watch it again.and again...and again until you cannot stop.Moulin Rouge creates its own genre: a mixture of a musical, a comedy, a romance, a drama, and a tragedy.  It is also a mixture of a film, a play, and a dance show.  It takes the best from each of these genres and each of these art mediums to create an unforgettable classic.  Baz Luhrmann has succeeded in creating a world that you can escape to, be entertained by, be moved by, and never want to leave.Although many of the songs in the film are not original, the film transforms popular songs into "Moulin Rouge" music.  The songs fit seamlessly into the story and are sung and danced to with such talent, that soon the film version of the song may become your favorite.  The music is simply exceptional.  The soundtrack, unfortunately, does not take many of the best songs from the film and, in fact, only one of the songs on the soundtrack is exactly how it appears in the film.Besides the music, the other strongest asset of the film is the acting. Each actor/actress creates such an indelible and developed character that it will be difficult to accept the actors/actresses playing roles in any other film.  For example, Ewan McGregor seemed totally out of place in Black Hawk Down, his next feature film, playing a soldier (with a virtually shaved head) in the U.S. Army.  Nicole Kidman, Ewan McGregor, John Leguizamo, Jim Broadbent, and Richard Roxburgh tie the choppy scenes of the film together and all deserve awards.  The surprisingly good singing by Kidman, McGregor, and Broadbent, who provide their own voices for their songs, define their characters.What truly makes the film a classic is that you can go to any scene in the film and be both entertained and moved.  Every scene is done with such style, such phenomenal acting, and often performed to stunning music and dance, that this film has a timeless quality.Besides being entertaining, what makes a film a truly great and unforgettable film is if it has meaning.  From beginning to end, Moulin Rouge is about "Truth, Beauty, Freedom, and above all Love."  Moulin Rouge is in fact a fairy tale, and like all classic fairy tales, its purpose is not only to transport you into another world, but also to leave you with a new meaning about your own world.  "The greatest thing you'll ever learn is just to love, and be loved in return."So, remember, watch Moulin Rouge open-minded, and then see it again and again and again...10/10 -- One of the best films, one of the best musicals, and one of the best love stories ever.

I like musicals but not this one. If it had been made a short music video, it would have been right up there as a good one. The story was weak, the acting not much better, only the choice of music saved it.Not good.

Review title: We'll quote this film in the future
Review_body: The film takes video clip language to its limits, producing a visual orgy. The story is simple and well known, but who cares? I even think that a weak plot is a great idea when form and aesthetics should prevail. I am sure this movie will establish a borderline, and we will talk about "before and after Moulin Rouge". The film is not a mere MTV long clip, it is much more than that. The music is quite nice, specially for those older than 30.

In the first 15 minutes, my senses were assaulted.  I was also taken aback by the use of popular song lyrics as dialogue.  Then I finally got the point of the movie. It's not even remotely grounded in reality.  It's "hyper-real" (Lurhman's own words).  It's allegorical. The characters are deliberately archetypal.Relax, and give in to this feast for the senses, and you won't be disappointed.McGregor's ability to sing surprised me more than Kidman's.  Personally, I think he did a better job singing, but both were quite good!Roxburgh's portrayal of the Duke is superbly comical.  When he recites a couple of lines from "Like a Virgin", I was rolling on the floor.  Compare this with his character in MI2.  They are a wonderful contrast.My favorite part is when the song, "Roxanne," is given an awesome interpretation in some passionate Argentine Tango.The key is that the songs and lyrics-as-dialogue are wonderfully integrated into the movie, unlike a standard musical that stops for a song.  This integration contributes to the film's good pacing.  It's so refreshing to see popular songs used in original ways.

Moulin Rouge tells the story of Christian (McGregor), an innocent young poet who defies his father and moves to late nineteenth century Paris to live a penniless bohemian life, and winds up falling in love with Satine (Kidman), the "Sparkling Diamond" of the Moulin Rouge, a nightclub. Satine, who is dying of tuberculosis but doesn't know it, dives into an ill-fated relationship with Christian, despite the only rule of the Moulin Rouge: never to fall in love. The storyline is cliche, but it is told in such a unique way that you feel as if you're being told a love story for the very first time.Everything about this film is beautiful. The visuals are even more outlandish and artistic than those of Baz Luhrmann's last film, William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet, but they seem to work even better for this film. The scenes cut so often and are so mixed up that the movie could have easily been a mess, but Luhrmann somehow managed to put them all together perfectly.The music is also wonderful. I have always had a soft spot for film musicals, and it's refreshing to know that they haven't gone completely extinct. The music is also fun because it's mostly made up of contemporary pop songs, featuring such artists as Sting and Elton John, as well as a few classics like "Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend" and "The Sound of Music." It's amazing how well the songs fit; it almost seems as if they were written for the movie.The acting is astounding. Nicole Kidman is wonderful, and has a surprisingly good voice (yes, it is her singing). And Ewan McGregor is indescribably amazing! He is immensely talented as an actor and has a beautiful voice. He really has a talent for making the audience feel the intense emotions that pour out of his character. Richard Roxburgh, Jim Broadbent and John Leguizamo, who play the Duke, Zidler, and Toulouse Lautrec respectively are all very entertaining, providing the comic relief. All of the actors portray their characters in a very exaggerated, melodramatic and operatic way, which confirms the fact that this film is a modern opera.This movie swept me off my feet. Everything about it is perfect; I wouldn't change a thing. When it came to the end of the movie, it felt to me like waking up from a wonderful dream, wishing it could have lasted forever. But it is obviously the type of movie where you either love it or you hate it, because it's so unique. If you tend to go for simple movies, or movies with a diverse, constantly twisting plot (not that I don't love that genre), you probably won't see much in this movie. But if you like original, artistic, intensely dramatic films, this is one you don't want to miss.

Review title: like a kid fuelled by red cordial...
Review_body: The first half of this film is a fun, frenetic romp full of hilarious dialogue and cheekiness. This shall be known as 'the good bit'. Then comes the second half. And just like a kid fuelled on red cordial, the buzz ends sooner than you want to, and with Moulin Rouge, crikey did it end. Unfortunately, the buzz ended exactly at the halfway mark. This shall be known as 'the bad bit.' From that moment on, this is some of the most boring film-making in the history of the world. The good bit -- with Ewan in fine form, Nicole doing a lovely job pretending to sing and the cast so brim full of energy you could power a small town on their vibrations -- neatly glosses over the absolute lack of story. Well, the thinnest story imaginable. But as a chorus of suited blokes would sing, "it's not about the story, it's about love and clever use of modern songs in a turn-of-the-century setting". How much that matters is up to you. The comes the bad bit. When the film comes to a grinding halt in the middle, the bit when it decides to try and be a real movie and less of an experience, this is when you should stick knitting needles in your eyes. The life, soul and spirit is sucked out of proceedings harder than something I can't write here but involves one of the many prostitutes in the film. A shame. Moulin Rouge is a red-hot go at a musical, but realises midway through proceedings that it just can't go on, when in fact it should have.

Having seen this film last night, I still cant get over how good this was.It quite clearly owes more to stage Opera than stage musical, and that is possibly why people feel that it is a disorganised mess with limited plot.Opera plots are very similar to this, with twists and turns complicating simple love stories.The handling of the songs is also much more Operatic, with two people singing different songs at each other, musical refrains occurring and re-occurring throughout.The Roxanne song and dance number was awesome, Ewan McGregor and Jacek Koman singing the same song in very differing styles, whilst Nicole Kidman sings the recurring love theme song.A great film, the style of which will be lost on those who are expecting a musical, when what they get is closer to Opera.  A style in which this day and age is ignored by the average movie-goer.Baz Luhrmann has truly opened up a new genre in film with this excellent masterpiece, you would be a fool to miss it, whether you feel it will be your cup of tea or not.

In the past few years it had started to seem that Hollywood was never going to do anything different or special.  For years it was the trend movies (ie-the disaster movies, WW2 movies, destroying earth movies).  Now we have this glimmering light from the depths of Hollywood shining through all the proverbial muck.  I can't say much more about this movie without talking about the story and plot.  But I can say that I was making plans to see it again less than half way through the movie.  And it doesn't hurt that the music is wonderful.  McGregor and Kidman are incredible together, and they have the most wonderful voices.  I recommend this movie to any person of any age, and especially to those of a theatre background.

Review title: Memo to those that think it's great: Have you ever seen other movies?
Review_body: Unless I'm missing something, it's about a SINGING WHORE.Answers the question: what would it look like if a music video director devoid of soul or life experience was given a huge amount of money?The romantic story makes the relationship in Titanic look realistic.  It gets to all the points that a real story would make but it earns none of them.Are we really supposed to find the lyrics to "The Sound of Music," "Smels Like Teen Spirit" and/or Elton John's "Your Song" compelling and/or meaningful?  Or is this some really subtle joke that went over my head?  It would be more forgiveable if we found out that the filmmakers were stoned the whole time.Until my fading memory returns, I'd have to say this is the worst movie I've ever seen.

Shockingly good to the point of amazing. I have to admit I almost missed this movie. I prejudged it by its horrible marketing and some poorly formed prejudices about its cast. Great music and a great story. Surperb acting! Kudos to all involved (except those how pitched it to the public).

Review title: Best since American Beauty and in some ways better
Review_body: All good films have to be good on at least one level.Gladiator was an epic, American Beauty ironic, Priscilla Queen of the Desert kooky, Delicatessan original, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon beautiful, Kes sad, Chocolat romantic and Shrek plain funny.Moulin Rouge manages to be all of these at the same time(maybe not an epic!). The scenery and characterisations are enchanting, the notion of displacing music could have been disasterous, but worked out just fine. In fact, it was what Topsy Turvy should have been (Jim Broadbent please note).It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but after the nightmare of New York this week, Moulin Rouge was a terrific piece of escapism in the grand manner. 10 out of 10 without hesitation. Baz Luhrmann goes into my book with Sam Mendez and Stephen Poliakoff.

Didn't anyone notice that the camera was sooooooo close to the cast that you could almost smell them.  What was the lighting trying to say? Don't get me wrong....I LOVE musicals. I guess I was expecting original music, great lighting and a camera person who knew what they were doing. Don't waste your time.

This is a movie you won't soon forget -- not only for the performances, which are all Oscar worthy -- but the music and sets and originality of the script.  If you've ever been in love ........... you'll cry.

What a wonderful movie!  I know this is one of those movies that people say it is not for everyone, but how could you not like this movie?  I suppose if you don't like remarkable visual imagery, beautiful people, wonderful music, choreography and a love story you wouldn't like this, but is there really someone out there like that?  I'm going to go watch it again.

Review title: One of the few films I walked out on...
Review_body: Having viewed the first then minutes with the possibility of them being the prelude to an entertaining film, I was negatively surprised to learn that this was the actual style of this film. I can see that this style might be attractive to some viewers, but I'd say that after talking to some of my movie-going colleagues, this will most probably to be a minority...Let's hope Nicole will return to some real moviemaking after this performance cinema experiment.

I'm truly disappointed.  I had been looking forward to seeing this movie for quite awhile.Moulin Rouge! could have been a truly great movie if someone would have held Baz Luhrmann's hand and restrained him a bit.  Unfortunately, the film suffered from many of the shortcomings of Romeo and Juliet, but this time they were amplified beyond all reason.  Baz Luhrmann's editing, while innovative, is nothing short of self-indulgent.  It takes over the film, interrupts the story, and turns the film into a mediocre overly-long music video.I don't fault any of the performances...not even the singing.  The story was actually pretty good...when it was allowed to unfold.  Had the film-makers exercised some self-control in the editing room, this movie could have easily taken place inside of one hour.  It also could have been a very good movie.  Luhrmann is a visual genius, but he needs to be reined in a bit.

I'll just list the problems with the film:I doubt a woman in the advanced stages of tuberculosis could have been singing like Satine was.  It's like asking me to believe that a paraplegic could perform Riverdance.The editing was arbitrary and distracting.There was absolutely NO chemistry between Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman. It felt like I was watching a brother and sister kiss.The film could have been improved immensely had they used original music. What a horrible idea.Now what was good:I did enjoy the costumes and the beautiful sets.

First of all this is an obvious Nicole Kidman vehicle. Nothing wrong with that however to cast around her average singing talent with  Ewan McGregor,a fine actor but a terrible singer makes this film;and only then sightly, easier to watch sans sound. Second,I love a roller coaster ride however lets don't change the mood of a scene even before the song has ended. It loses alot in the emotion of the film when you aren't able to properly feel the mood before it changes again. The entire movie did have a very rushed feeling to it. I did, however find John Leguizamo portrayal of Toulouse Lautrec very enjoyable. Just my opinion.

Moulin Rouge is probably the worst film I've seen this year and That really is something when you know this year I have watched things like Drop Dead Gorgeous and Hour of the pig! The beginning was completely crap and I was sooo bored by the end! Ewan Mcgregor cannot act or sing or smile! the plot was not good and I dont really think any of them could act. Definitely one of the "Must-miss" films this year!

This is a tremendous film.  It elicits so many different emotions.The use of modern day pop songs laced throughout added greatly to the entertainment and thats what is was- great entertainment. The special effects and the larger than life characters wove a fascinating web that engulfed you and before I knew it, it was over.That is the mark of a good film when it only seems like it started and its finished.I, along with the whole of the male population must have fallen in love with Nicole, Tom's loss is our gain.  The chemistry between her and Ewen was so hot it burnt an acid stain in my brain. I watched it pay for view and at this rate I could be bankrupt by Christmas.Enjoy !

Calling a film "the best film I have ever seen" is not a compliment that comes easily. But for Moulin Rouge, I can personally make an exception. I can understand why some may not like this film, but for anyone who is well educated in the art of filmmaking, surely Moulin Rouge rates highly in terms of ingenuity.Every scene knocked me off my feet. I saw this film with a group of fellow film students, and every single one of us thought it was fantastic, astounding, hilarious, moving. The "El Tango De Roxanne" sequence was simply amazing, really powerful stuff! And who knew of the enchanting vocal talents McGregor and Kidman possess?10 out of 10. I cannot believe it didn't get a look in at Cannes. Just shows how stuffy and conservative the industry is getting. Hurrah for this wonderful work of art; I can't wait to see it again... at least twice more!

Review title: prepare to go back to the turn of the century
Review_body:
***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** This has been the first movie to impress me on all accounts since I first saw "Breakfast At Tiffanys". Basicaly, it starts out with a young writer, Christian (played to perfection by the addorable Ewan McGregor), moves to Paris in 1899. He quickly gets invovled in a group of actors, with the lovable John Leguizamo playing Toulouse Lautrec. He then quickly finds himself quickly into the Moulin Rogue and meets Satine, played by Nicole Kidman. Which results in a hilarous first meeting, she finds that he is not the Duke that she is suppose to be "impressing". This quickly leaves to a passionate secret love affair between Christian and Satine, behind the Duke's, who is also taken by Satine and wants her to himself, back. But little to any of them know, is that Satine is slowly dieing.
I've been waiting for years for a good musical to come along, and it looks as if i finally got my wish. A GREAT soundtrack, tho i have one complaint, where's the version of Madonna's "Like A Virgin" on the soundtrack?  10 out of 10 stars easily. I'm going to be completly disappointed if it doesn't get alteast 4 oscars nods. This is a must see hit movie of the summer.

An awe-striking arrangement of both musical and acting talents.  The much anticipated release of the controversial duo Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGreger surpasses all expectations.  When a young courtesan, Satine, and a "pennyless writer", Christan, fall into an unlikely triangle with a conniving Duke, the plot twists into a hysterical comedy and tear jerking tragedy all rolled into two hours.  With a killer soundtrack including, Beck, Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGreger, and the infamous "Lady Marmalade", it's not just about the scenes but also about the back ground and foreground tracks.  Still if you are expecting to get every tune in the film on CD, you had better buy the DVD because the fourteen song album only holds a fraction of the actual music in the film. Still with all the sounds and wonderful performances, this is probably the best film of the year because of the well developed plot and outright crazy sequences.  I give it ten stars not just five.

Review title: Worst movie I've ever seen (so far) :(
Review_body: Don't waste your money.Would have been better if they wrote their own music instead of the cheezy use of pop songs.What a dreadful low the film industry has hit.  Doesn't anyone appreciate originality and creativity anymore?  Recycling music is not being creative and I feel the film was highly overrated.On the plus side, I liked the costumes and the cinematography, but hated the music, the plot and the acting so much that I could not appreciate the good stuff.

After reading the many comments already posted, I'm not sure what I can add, except I Love This Movie!!  Not since "Titanic" has a movie gotten me this excited!!  Even though they are very different movies, they have the same "feel" to them, i.e the long lines of people waiting to get in; the heart-wrenching love story; audiences clapping throughout and at the end; at least half the theater sitting through all the credits.  I've seen it twice and will definitely see it at least a few more times.There is so much visually to take in that it is impossible to catch everything in one showing.  Baz Luhrman did a remarkable job.  I really enjoyed his version of Romeo & Juliet, but this even surpasses that!Nicole Kidman & Ewan McGregor were amazing and so good together.  And who knew they could sing so well!  I agree this movie is probably not for everyone, but even if you are not a "fan" of musicals this will "knock your socks off!"  It is a roller coaster ride of emotions & visual & musical stimuli that will leave you breathless - and running back for more!I really hope the "critics" are not too hard on this wonderful movie. Sometimes it seems like they feel it it their job to find fault with movies rather than "experience" them.  This is one movie that is definitely an Experience!!Please, go see it and you will not be disappointed.  It is definitely a 10/10!!

Having just returned from the cinema, I'm simply too overwhelmed to write anything exhaustive. I'll put it bluntly and just say that it was an extraordinary film in every aspect, both technically and artistically.
It was stunning, inspiring and breathtaking.Loved it and seing it again tomorrow.

Review title: My favorite movie of 2001 So Far!
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is not just a romantic musical, it is a theatrical experience of the heart, eyes, mind and soul. This film delivers a moving passionate love story amidst cutting edge electric direction and music deliveries that dazzle the senses.Set at the turn of the century in France's bohemian subculture, this film tells the tale of a man, Christian (Ewan McGregor) who goes there from England to write about the movement. Instead, by a strange twist of fate he is talked into writing for a play at the famed Moulin Rouge. He ends up becoming enchanted by Satine (Nicole Kidman), the main star of the Moulin Rouge who is also a courtesan. Christian falls uncontrollably in love with her.The movie is cute and charming, very, very romantic. For those who scoff at the high concepts of love, this is movie is definitely not for you. This film also contains singing and dancing in a theatrical manner. But the funny thing is the songs are not all Julie Andrews type songs, most of them are modern hits of the last decade or so, like Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" or Madonna's "Like A Virgin" (which gets a truly hillarious delivery). Notice how I didn't say it was a musical? To call this film a musical is like calling Mt. Everest a tall mountain. It underscores the greatness. All of the actors in this film do their own singing, even Nicole Kidman, and shock! She sounds good. Both Nicole and Ewan underwent weeks of singing lessons for this movie. Ewan has an incredible voice and is a powerful actor.The entire production, the costumes, the characters, the musical numbers, it is all very visually captivating. Baz Luhrman's (Romeo & Juliet) production is cutting edge, bringing an animated feel to the movie, and adding much life to it. If you are open to new deliveries of old ideas, and enjoy romantic love stories set amidst pending doom, this will be a movie you should not miss. This film will not be for everyone, but for me it was a pleasant surprise. It will be a shock if it does not pick up an Oscar nod for music and costumes, if not a nomination for Best Film of the Year, which as December 6th, it is for me!

Review title: This one is not for everyone, just those who love music and movies.
Review_body: A dazzling and dizzying delight to the senses. Moulin Rouge is an unexpected homage to the 20th century songbook that's fantastic as a fairy tale and familiar as a cherished LP. Don't be surprised if you find yourself breathless at one moment and weeping the next. This movie is a thrilling carnival ride and classic musical tragedy rolled up into one. The fusion of soundtrack, visuals and plot is nothing short of deft craftsmanship. I don't mean to be vague but to give specific details would be to take away from the surprising pleasures that await. I can say that this ride left me completely satisfied.

The pace at the beginning is frantic - but it's a wild, magical and fascinating ride. There has never been a movie like this folks. The production quality, visuals, special effects, settings, and more are all truly spectacular. Of special note is the "Tango de Roxanne" which will leave you believing that "Roxanne" had to be written in 1900. The brilliant arrangement of the song and the vision of 30 couples simultaneously dancing a dirty, almost violent tango is absolutely captivating. Other numbers of note are the hilarious send up of "Like a Virgin" and the "Lovers Medley". See it. This isn't just a movie - it's a life experience.

Review title: These are perfect performances by Kidman and McGregor -- both emotionally and the way they look..
Review_body: This is a fresh, exciting movie that has to be seen, and seen on the wide screen. It is brilliant in many aspects, with few valleys. I would have enjoyed more coverage of the dancing and a few less camera swipes, fly-arounds, and quick cuts, though. Some of the art direction is breathtaking. Nicole Kidman is absolute filmic beauty.Most incredible is the way Kidman and McGregor stay within their characters and make their romance real and totally believable -- not so much as a story but as a magical connection that burns between them. Both have a screen presence in this film that is magnetic and captivating, and when they are together their combined energy makes looking away from them impossible. They are brilliant, and since many of their scenes with sustained emotion and emotional development are cut together from footage in totally different make-up, costumes, settings, and lighting, the work of both the director and editors must be considered brilliant, as well.

Review title: You really can fall in love with a movie
Review_body: Yes. I, too, really fell in love with this movie. It's propably the most beautiful movie I have ever seen, audiovisually and by the cliché storyline. Everything is beautiful and melancholy. The music ain't very good in itself, but the main actors make it sound beautiful. You have to dig your fingernails into your palms to stop yourself from sobbing, when Christian sings "why does my heart cry"...*sigh*... Moulin Rouge! is a beautiful faerytale, which makes you feel unreal. I'd hope it'd stay in the movie theatres for ever and ever, and see it again and again.

Review title: sorry, but this movie was awful
Review_body: If I want to see overdone sets, awful acting, and unbelievably cheesy cover tunes woven into an overdone musical, I'll go see this movie. It's completely pretentious and without any sort of merit from an artistic standpoint. Nicole Kidman is a square peg in a round hole in a musical, period. She's mediocre to begin with, overvalued as an actor in general, and horribly miscast in this movie. I couldn't even watch the movie. If I hadn't fallen asleep 3 times while trying to get through this horrible film, I'd want to throttle most of the actors for over acting. I realize I'm in the minority here, but anyone who thinks this movie is unique has never seen a decent Broadway musical.This movie is Velveeta on Wonder Bread. I guess that's what the masses eat for lunch, so it figures that most people would like this. To me it it's a waste of good celluloid.

ok, so i have now seen this movie 4 times.  i have made others see it with me.  i have the soundtrack.  but there is not a single song in that movie (of the covers, that is) that i liked, or even tolerated, before i saw the movie.  but now,  when i listen to the soundtrack, i feel the way i usually feel when i listen to the smiths.  but enough about the music...i am not quite sure what has drawn me to this movie.  the first time i saw it, about 2 weeks after it opened, the theater was packed for the matinee. the audience was 'into' this movie, which perhaps enhanced my view of it. people laughed, people cried, everyone stayed till the end of the credits (!).  the males in the audience were crying!  i was crying!  it was an audience love-in.  the second time i saw it a few days later, it was again packed.  people walking in were singing 'because we can can can'.  there was a grandmother with her grandson.  they both left crying.  as did i.  by the third and fourth times i saw it, i was bawling openly for the last 20 minutes.  i can imagine that those who are not used to the lightning-fast style of mtv would get a little disturbed by the editing style, but i found that it really enhanced the whirlwind feeling of suddenly being dropped into the moulin rouge.  people who know me cannot believe that i would be so attracted to a movie about a love story.  the last movie i saw this many times was fight club. i think this movie appeals to a very broad audience: those who appreciate the absurd, those who watch mtv, those who like musicals, those who like tragic love stories, those who have always wanted to see ewan mcgregor not looking emaciated...to all filmmakers:   more musicals please!!!

Suffice to say, if you are a fan of Baz Luhrmann (as I am) you will love this film.  I don't think the anachronistic use of modern-day songs could have been more expertly woven into a story, to give it a depth and emotional credibility that just would not have been possible if it were being told "straight".This is not a history lesson, and there are no morals or hidden meanings. It is simply a fantasy that takes your eyes, ears, and emotions on a holiday that you wish you didn't have to come back from.An enormous amount of love, passion, and meticulous attention to detail went into the making of this film and every member of the cast and crew deserves a standing ovation for their efforts.An inspiring effort: 10/10

Review title: Moulin Rouge! has the stature, not the insight of Talouse Lautrec, unfortunately
Review_body: Moulin Rouge was a disappointment.A musical needs its own music. Not only did Moulin Rouge! fail in that, but the music it had was well-known prior to the movie and identified with a modern era.Indeed, each time the characters broke into song it yanked the viewer out of the 1899 setting of the movie. So well-known is the music that it seemed like even the most serious scenes were comedic, with the joke being the character partaking in anachronism.The costumes, however, were wonderful. They suck the viewer into the period and feel of the movie.Too bad the music causes the viewer "toulouse lautrec'' of time.

This film is not only visually stunning, it has an amazingly, beautiful and touching story. It tells the story of a young, naive writer named Christian (McGregor) who comes to Paris to try and start his career. After making friends with some rather scrupulous characters, including famed absinthe soaked artist Toulouse-Lautrec(Leguizamo), he gets into a fiasco involving a bordello, its owner(Broadbent), its star performer(Kidman), and a Duke(Roxburgh) who is to invest in an upcoming show. The film then takes the viewer on a whirlwind journey through romance, comedy and tragedy. This is a truly breathtaking film full of exciting musical numbers and superb acting from the whole cast. An easy 10/10.

People I've watched the film with have said that it rips off some great songs, but as far as I am concerned the songs are used well, especially Roxanne, which no offence to the 'Police' was a better version in Moulin Rouge. Its the cinematography but not only that the acting, ecstatic. I feel sorry for Baz that he wasn't nominated in the directing category for the oscars. However, I do wish Nicole Kidman the best of luck considering she totally deserves best actress with an absolutely stunning performance in Moulin Rouge, even better than The Others, she has really sprung into action in the last year and deserves one hell of a congratulations for it, what better with an oscar. This film makes love out to be fantastic and Hollywood and the audiences have been waiting for a romantic tragedy (Romeo and Juliet not quite right) for years and finally is delivered, screw Lord of the Rings, I may be British but Moulin Rouge has got more of a watchable storyline, shame that it is up against Lord of the Rings, which will probably run away with it this year at the oscars, any other year Moulin Rouge would be the best. Good Luck Moulin Rouge and Nicole Kidman, I'll be watching.

Review title: Cabaret Meets Fantasia, Collides with Inane Humor
Review_body: This was the worst movie I've seen in years. I liked Cabaret, and I expected a Titanic-like plot. This was so over-the-top stupid ... without the sexual content, I could have taken a nine-year-old to see it and he or she would have enjoyed it. Nicole Kidman is gorgeous, so why make her do such ridiculous scenes in the first half, like in her chambers when she's dancing with the others in that improvised skit? The supporting cast, especially Zidler, made me feel like I was being held hostage in a carnival gone bad. The beautiful costumes and equally beautiful Ewan McGregor made me stay for the full two hours to see if Moulin Rouge got better, but sadly, it couldn't get much worse.

Review title: Best film I've seen in a long time!!
Review_body: "Moulin Rouge" is a classic story of love overcoming social and political obstacles, but is told with a very different twist. A period setting with modern music hightening every scene. The funny thing about it is....it works! Whoever arranged all the music deserves an Oscar, and even though we're only halfway through the year, expect "Moulin Rouge" to get a few Oscar nods in Costume Design and make up. The cinematography is like a theme park ride taking you through the streets of Paris and into the characters windows, and with more close ups the actors to really make you feel like your sitting right next to them. If you haven't seen this film yet, what are you waiting for? I've seen it three times and each time the audience applauds, which is something I haven't seen in a long time! So go, and don't take it too seriously. The film is a very entertaining ride through the wild nightlife of 20th century Paris.

This magical musical about forbidden love between a penniless writer and glamorous courtesan is absolutely magnificent. Over the top, yes, loud and in your face, yes, but romantic and beautiful and sad? yes, yes and yes.The acting is solid, Nicole Kidman's voice will impress you and the clever use of pop music is laudable.Its stylish and daring, original and predictable, funny, tragic and a little mad. I'm often surprised that people either hate it or love it. I say sit through the first 20 minutes and you will find it really hard to not enjoy Lurhmanns genius, Nicole's elegance or the story's beauty.

"come what may" this movie is one of the best musical ever. Very realistic costumes that puts you exactly in the place and time where the movie takes place. When???? At the very end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 2nd millennium. Where???? In Paris "City Of Lights" the place where the Bohimian revolution has just started.to be specific it takes place in the infamous nightclub "The moulin rouge". Great performances by Nicole Kidman and Ewan Mcgregor,fantastic music that will live forever.The classic battle between Good and evil side.Jon steward "host of the 78th academy awards" said in the 44th Grammy's awards " Our next song ' referring to lady marmalade ' is from the movie Moulin Rouge the film that took us back to the days where the w***e houses were about the music" If u believe in Freedom,Beauty,Truth and above all things Love then you are a true bohemian.

Review title: Best Musical for a long time!
Review_body: By far one of the greatest movies of 2001. Nicole Kidman gives a "Spectacular Spectacular" preformance. Ewan McGregor used his charm and acting ability to make you love him and his character! Great cast and great acting make this movie a must see. The fact that they can blend songs from 1930ish to 2000 is amazing! The lead characters will attract you to the movie, and the music will keep you yelling for more! Truly a great film that involves drama, comedy, music, and dancing while not falling to the chick flick genre. One of the greatest parts of the movie however is only on the video as the extented dance scene. This scene truly shows that it will be a cult movie and a Broadway hopeful! DO NOT let the fact that Lil Kim, Maya, Christina Augurliara, and Pink do a song for the soundtrack! THe music in the movie is far better including songs from Elton John, Madonna, Beck, Nirvana, Pattie LaBell, Bono, Sting (the Police), and sooooo many more! Fall into love with this movie!

This movie has probably been one of the best movies I have seen in awhile... It's a nice break from all the teen bimbo films coming out these days. If you like any of the following then you'll love this movie: Comedy, Romance, Musicals, Ewan McGregor, or Nicole Kidman. After all this is "A story about love" The thing about this movie is that it's not just weak romance... it's REAL PASSION... And you can feel that when you watch this movie. There is this force between Ewan and Nicole in this movie and the love in the script actually comes onto the screen and you can actually FEEL the passion they're feeling when you watch it. It's amazing! It's not some sappy romantic movie- it's a story of true love.. A love that will last forever... 10/10...

Moulin Rouge is VERY obviously a Baz Luhrmann film.  With all the trademarks of his previous ventures it begins with the promise of greatness. Unfortunately there is something lacking and I can only surmise that it is heart. There are some fantastic moments in this film and the actors are all perfectly cast and beautifully portrayed, however, in hind-sight there is nothing new in the movie which would warrant a return viewing. I also thought there were a few opportunities missed, which may have made the film more enjoyable, albeit more predictable. Moulin Rouge was an interesting attempt from a director who has so much more to offer.  Maybe a smaller budget and less hype will allow him to experiment once again and hopefully next time hit the mark. See it once, but I doubt you will see it again.

In a way, Moulin Rouge typifies everything that's wrong with American cinema by bastardizing everything that's right with its European counterpart. Visually, the movie is a great reference for any commercial or video director. But unlike a music video that lasts only three minutes, Moulin Rouge begins with a visual volume worthy of Spinal Tap and tries to sustain it for 120 minutes. It doesn't work. The rule of dynamics applies as much to a pretentious musical as it does to an ambitious action film. If the volume is too loud, you simply can't hear anything. Everything gets lost in Moulin Rouge's hurricane of desperate art direction and production design. The film's leads, talented actors though they may be, simply aren't charismatic enough to compete. The movie requires posturing, not acting. And, frankly, there are no less charismatic actors than Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman. In fact, their appeal is in their pastiness, not in their screen presence. What's more, the music can't compete either. Great songs are dwarfed by the never-ending onslaught of CGI visuals, which, after a while, become tedious. We get it, already. The moral of this story is that you still need one to make a good movie. Nothing can replace pen and paper. Unglamorous though it may be, a good script is everything. The filmmaker's previous effort with Romeo And Juliet worked precisely because he had a great script to begin with. The production design was icing on the cake. With Moulin Rouge, icing is all there is, and a satisfying meal it does not make.

When I went to see Moulin Rouge, I was expecting it to be many things, visually magnificent, a tragic love story, musically splendid, etc. But more than any of these things, it turned out to be... goofy. Go figure. Following a Bohemian poet, Christian's (a boring Ewan McGregor) journey through the underworld of the nightclub/bordello Moulin Rouge and his disastrous romance with its biggest star Satine (an embarrassing Nicole Kidman) proves to be, of course, a Luhrmann feast for the eyes, but generally lacking in substance. The movie is told through flashbacks as Christian tries to recall the story of his life for the past few months. Since entering Paris, he has met and befriended a wide array of Bohemian artsy types, such as a directorial midget with a speech impediment known as Toulouse Lautrec, (played by a desperate John Leguizamo), a meaty ringmaster, Harold Ziedler, (an inconsistent Broadbent) who owns the Moulin Rouge, and the only hilarious character in the film, a narcoleptic Argentinian (played to indulgent perfection by Jacek Koman). Our somewhat charismatic hero is immediately thrust into writing a musical production, which he bases on his own love battle for Satine with the rich underwriter of the production, the Duke, played by Richard Roxburgh in an acting approach more one-sided than Rambo. Through all this, Luhrmann interweaves plot gimmicks stolen directly from Shakespeare in Love, a visual atmosphere that assaults the senses and actually crosses the line I never thought Luhrmann could cross, that of over extravagance. Too many quick cuts and fast speeds alienate the viewer and can't draw the audience's attention away from the general cheesy air of a cardboard production. All this, the plastic performances, the poor humor, and worse romance could be excused as a mediocre production, were it not for the million silly references to pop culture which not only fail to amuse, but also place the audience out of the movie. From Christian singing Celine Dion to a ridiculous dance version of Madonna's Like A Virgin, these devices disappoint and reduce the entire film to a shallow joke.

I give this movie 2 stars. One for the visual originality and one for Ewan McGregor's voice.I was honestly really disappointed when I watched this movie. I watched it because I was curious. It had been given great feedback and after I watched it I couldn't really understand why.I recognize that it's visually different from any other movie, but the story is probably the most unoriginal thing I've ever seen. It was really boring. And it's not just that, it also felt like I was watching a movie without a plot, only visual effects in a random compilation of scenes with a romance that just appeared out of sudden.

It seems to have been a long time since a movie has broken the boring mold of Hollywood screenplays and cinematography and produced something as unique and exciting as 'Moulin Rouge'. A truly splendid movie that I think will mark its generation as much as 'Showboat' and 'Hair' marked theirs.

This film was enchanting, and that's the best word for it.  You feel almost like you've been pulled into another world, leaving all your cynicism at the door.  This movie takes all of your guilty pleasures, all the things you love to love all alone, and makes it okay to love them right in broad daylight with everyone watching.  It is intoxicating in its beauty, surprising in its originality, and utterly dreamlike.  Ewan McGregor, who's not such a shabby actor in previous works, outdoes himself time and again - the "bohemian ideals" he espouses (truth, beauty, freedom, and - above all things - love) are clearly shown in every expression, be it lovelorn, tormented, or wholly joyous.  Nicole Kidman turns in a solid performance as well, sometimes hilarious - sometimes poignant.  It is, however, Mr. McGregor's film."Moulin Rouge" captures the quintessential nature of life - that everything we think is bad can be good and that everything we think is good can be bad, and that everything - good or bad - is magical and wondrous and should never be discarded as unworthy.  Greed, lust, purity, artistic ideals, betrayal, jealousy, sacrifice, salvation, truth, and love triumphant even in tragedy - it's all here, wrapped up in a package that takes your breath away and makes you laugh, cry, and sing (and yes, you'll already know some of the words). 
A masterpiece of cinematography, choreography, effects and wardrobe, this film will not change your life...it will remind you why you live.

I, like many others, am drawn in by beauty. And, with Romeo&Juliet and Strictly Ballroom being two remarkable movies, I thought, "This one is going to be great." I purposely stayed away from reviews until I could get to the theatre. Much to my dismay, the movie held much contempt for its audience. Nicole Kidman wanted nothing more than to display her talents and executed a terribly shallow role of a character that was very complex.Toulouse-Lautrec was reduced to a caricature of a dwarf with a speech impediment, when in truth he was the embodiment of Montmarte's bohemian scene. It was he who brought artists out of the church and into the newly invented method of mass production and made their art the icons of the age! He was at the center of a movement that later spawned the Beats, the Hippies, and all other degenerates who brilliantly create the words, art, music and theatre of their generations.The fact that the producers spent so much money to give the movie such visual splendor and so little on making it an important piece of art is a perfect representation of a lot of over-budgeted movies today. Couldn't the script have been clever, not trite? Couldn't they have used actual music from the period and given it a modern beat instead of using Elton John and Nirvana? Couldn't they decide whether the movie should be a farce or a drama, instead of something confusing in between? Couldn't the cast embrace the history of their roles (Zidler was great) and then create intelligent satire? I am so disappointed in this movie. I think I'll make myself feel better about the state of film making and go see Shreck.

Moulin Rouge is the most visually spectacular movie I have ever seen. The music is excellent, and I didn't feel the good old "oh my god here they go again with the singing!". Each song was a refreshing and unique interpretation. Can't wait to see what Baz Luhrman turns to next.

There have been very few movies I have purposely turned off before reaching the end (maybe two out of 1,000).  This just made the list.I dunno, maybe I just wasn't in the right frame of mind, but this movie was just a bad music video.  It was loud, the plot was utterly predictable (I didn't need to see the end to know what happened), the "modern songs with period sets" was simply a gimmick without purpose, the pace was unnecessarily frenetic, and worst of all, THE MUSIC STUNK.  I can deal with most of the other stuff, but when I watch a musical, I want the music to be good.  Duh.  Whoever says that Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor can sing are tone deaf.  I'm a musician, and I know good music.  This is not it.Want a "I never knew he/she could sing!" movie?  Michelle Pfeiffer in "Fabulous Baker Boys" does OK (not great).  John Travolta in "Grease". Tom Hulce (Mozart in "Amadeus") in "The Hunchback of Notre Dame."Want a fast-paced, off-the-wall edited, frenetic movie?  Requiem for a Dream.Want a good musical?  Little Shop of Horrors.  Any Disney animation. The Wizard of Oz.  The Sound of Music.  Singing in the Rain.  Heck, even Purple Rain (OK, it's more of a musical documentary, and the acting stinks, but you get my point).Want good Ewan McGregor?  Trainspotting.  Even Phantom Menace.Want good Nicole Kidman?  Not sure what to tell you.Want a quirky comedy?  Pee-Wee's Big Adventure.Want a loud movie?  The Fellowship of the Rings.Anything but this movie.

I'm not a fan of musicals.  Or of Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman, and half of the cast I had never even heard of. But this movie was awesome!  I mean it's probably the best movie I've seen in my lifetime.  The movie starts out kinda campy and annoying, but the Green Fairy and the Abstinse stuff was just hilarious!  And when they finally get down to it, the Moulin Rouge nightclub is probably the most beautiful spectacle of lights, music, color, and excitement I've ever seen.  The camera was like a rollercoaster, twisting and turning almost to the point of giving me a headache.  And the music, it was amazing.  One of the coolest things about this movie is how you can mix Madonna and Nirana and come out with something that totally fits with the movie.  But deep down this movie has a very emotional core.  At the end of the movie, everyone, and I do mean everyone, in the theater was either bawling hysterically or trying to cover up the fact that tears were running down their face.  Go watch the movie, it's one of the greatest you'll ever see, you might be surprised when you realize a week later your watching it for the third time wanting to see it again.

I decided not to watch this film in the theater.Just didn't interest me. But working for Blockbuster, I saw how it rented. Then the employees (male, imagine that) that saw it told me it was good. Yet I still put it off. Then, shortly after Nicole Kidman won a Golden Globe for it, I decided..why not?Awesome!! I am watching it right now, for like the 12th time. Bought the DVD, soundtrack. Nicole Kidman, her voice is awesome.But Ewan!!! My god!! He is beyond belief! If I could sing like him, I'd quit acting. The score, the singing, the directing, and the, of course.........acting is superb. If you like tragic love stories, this is for you. If you like musicals, this is for you. If you like something different from every other movie you saw in 2001, then this is DEFINITELY for you!

Not being a great musicals fan, I didn't expect to be overly impressed by Moulin Rouge. However, from the opening scene it was clear that this was no ordinary musical. The sometimes overwhelming mix of colour, sound and psychedelic imagery was just fantastic. A tour de force of imagination, glorious photography and brilliant set-pieces.You'll either love it or hate it - but don't pre-judge it. Go see for yourself.

Review title: How musch were the reviewers bribed
Review_body: Cliched, poor story line abysmal presentation. Jim Carey had the "Cable Guy" now Nicol Kidman has had Moulin Rouge. Some one in the last days of their existence has decided to put every bit of sickening sentimentality and bad choireography to produce this travesity. Cannibal the Musical (Trey Parker of Southpark fame) has more class than this insult to musicals

This movie was so tacky, I couldn't even sit through the whole thing. Art direction was great - yadda yadda. But that doesn't make up for the music. It was unoriginal "modern art" bulls***. I felt embarassed watching it.
Hey, here's a novel idea, why not get a good and talented song writer/musicians together to write some real songs with wit and character, and get a good writer to come up with a decent story. Maybe then it'd be worth watching...

I found this movie to be absolutely wonderful.  Amazing camera work, great actors and a superb musical.  The costumes were great too.  It was just a fun movie to watch -- a feast for the eyes! Furthermore, Nicole Kidman (who surprisingly could sing and also played a role that was much different than I expected from her) and Ewan McGregor were compatible chemistry-wise and talent-wise.

Love may conquer all but this dog of a film. What seemed like a lengthy wait for some point, finally turned into a painful realization that this nonmusical isn't a parody( Darn, a Technoglitz Lampoon of a Musical Romance might have been fun!) and isn't literary, historical or poignant.  It is a cartoon of itself: vaguely comic,two-dimensional dialogue and vapid plot, absolutely mangled medley of "Top of the Chart Love Hits" from yesteryear, and endlessly ridiculous camera and computer gimmicks that define the entire work.  As this hound lumbered into a second hour of artless musical fragments, we literally raced to the exit in relief.  At the dollar movies in record time--what a shock!!

I saw this film last night and was blown away.I have been reading many negative comments about the way the film was edited quickly. If you people took notice, you would see that the editing is only very fast towards the bigining of the film. This works brilliantly as it shows how much fun and how hyper the Moulan Rouge club is. The editing became less hyperkinetic as the film goes on. Stop complaining!Anyway, the film was brilliant and Nickole Kidman and Ewan McGregor have STUNNING VOICES! John Leguizamo is hilarious.I can't wait for the dvd, Baz Luhrman has said that he wants to make it a more beefed up dvd then the mighty Fight Club dvd.

In the past year, there haven't been many films to cheer about. Only a handful of films have excited me this year. Bridget Jones's Diary, Shrek, The Others and of course, Moulin Rouge. I have to admit the first time I saw the trailer for this film, I wasn't too thrilled about it. I had heard numerous rumors that the film was overbudget and honestly, it just wasn't good. Boy was I surprised! From the opening logo, it pulls you right into it's world. The performances of both Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor are phenomenal. They really keep the story moving at such a great pace. Now I have to also admit that I am not a huge fan of musicals but this one takes the cake. The music is extraordinary and both stars capture the feeling so well of each song they sing. I was so impressed with the art direction, costume design and everything. It's great film, not for everyone though. Give it a chance though, i'm sure you'll love it!

"Moulin Rouge!" is one of the most magnificent and most entertaining music-driven spectacles ever made. From its visual opulence to its visionary amalgamation of classical storylines, the movie is a stupendously original and intoxicating romantic tale that may spark a new generation of high-tech musicals (like the recent 'Chicago') and draw a diverse array of audiences back to the multiplexes for a chance to drown in the vibrant energy and manic zest of a good, new-fashioned cinematic show. The movie is a triumph in film making. Everything from the art direction, to the costume design, to the cinematography, to the fast-paced editing techniques, to the eye-popping visual effects, the movie is a dazzling feast for the senses. But don't let that mislead you into thinking the movie is all in-your-face giddy. No, the movie succeeds also on the level of subtle romance (the chemistry between the movie's two lovers is absolutely sizzling) and compelling melodrama.
It's impossible not to admire the film simply for its wonderful performances (Nicole Kidman turns in one of her very best performances ever)and directorial style. However you slice it, "Moulin Rouge!" is one of 2001's best films!

Review title: You need to invent words to describe it.
Review_body: It's very rare for me to rate a movie 10/10. I usually give this only to movies which are almost flawless, and I haven't found many.This movie is perfect. There are few films you like or think OK, and there are ones you need to wonder at, if you'd have to achieve what they did, how could you do that? How did they do it? I think, this movie sets a standard no movie ever will repeat. The difference is there, in between, the difference which separates the professionals who are brilliant in their work, put everything they have, work hard and achieve great things, and the geniuses. This is something I couldn't imagine, couldn't invent. And I can only bow down with humility and thank the creators for the chance that I could see it.I feel it silly to list everything, to say it was great, because everything was great. Pacing, effects, music, acting, singing, editing, directing,... I would give an Oscar for everything there's one and for the rest I'd make new categories.Thank you Baz Luhrman. You made me feel richer inside.
My favorite movie ever!It's a perfect musical..everything about it shines and scream perfection.Can't even write to describe it!

It's been a while since a good film came along...This is one ! It has no sence of telling the what's and why's, but it is a must. Nicole can sing and act, I assure you ! Great little romantic drama, with some great interpretations of songs from Nirvana, Madonna, etc... Go see it if you like dance, music and grandeur !! MOULAAAAAAAAAN !!

At last, movie that combines the past with todays music with a little comedy. Felt during the movie that I wanted to be in the Moulin Rouge also, dancing and jumping. I had to had the soundtrack right after the movie ended.

Take a silly story, shallow characters, bad singers, and much too much on-screen clutter, mix with some modern ditties, and you get the mess that is Moulin Rouge. Instead of developed characters and story, we just get a lot of flashy imagery, which at times was amusing, but mostly just gave me a headache. Perhaps if I cared one iota about the shallow, silly characters and their superficial troubles, I would have liked it more.

Review title: We've been taken for chumps! - brilliantly!
Review_body: Yes, this is a brilliant movie. Visually dazzling; purposefully stunning.And it is satire with us, the paying audience, as the victims.Like the theatre of the grotesque that was contemporary with libertine France of the Moulin Rouge's historical heyday, the audience are being made to confront their own pretensions.The original practitioners were more honest, though. They would use ordinary buckets of poop on their stage. The poop in this elaborate plaything is a vast, elaborate artifact, but it is well aimed.Just as in the old original stage happenings, we gasp, discuss and admire. What fools we all are. And that is exactly the message that the writer and director of this gaudy thing is conveying.One cannot deny that he did it successfully.

Review title: Wonderful review of last years songs!!
Review_body: Usually I don´t enjoy musicals, but Moulin Rouge! is an exception.The color of the film is annoying, the photography wonderful (I´m not an expert but I know when something likes me).Ewan McGregor surprised us with his versatile voice and Nicole Kidman is so spectacular that I think that´s impossible not to fall in love of her at first seeing.If you want to enjoy with a film Moulin Rouge! is one of the best elections that you can select at this moment.I hope that you like it at least half as much as me.

For those who truly can feel the movie. A lot of people have said to me Dan, what a boring movie. but how wrong they were because I left thinking, every time I watch the movie I see it in a different light, a different meaning. based on the classic theme, of good and evil. if you make out who the characters are and the reasons for there actions, you can see through the screen into the True world of Moulin Rouge. Any one who is a movie freak, This one I give 9/out of 10 and recommend it. it lacks one because the beginning was badly opened. but you all will be quickly draw to it. Asid..

Review title: Must see (to use a common phrase)
Review_body: Being only a film connoiseur in spe, I must confess, that I have spoken the following phrase on several occassions, these are, however, listed below in reverse chronological order:This is the greatest movie I have ever seen!!!(Listing of earlier incidents follow)101 ReykjavikAudition (Odishon)Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Wu Hu, Zhang long)Dark CityA French movie, the name of which I can't remember, but that touched me deeplyMost of the movies conforming to the Danish "Dogma 95" dogma (yes, "Dancer In the Dark" is one of those).This is, however, the first movie, that I have refrained from describing in other words than those, the cause of which being, that though I hold my knowledge of my native tongue to be rather exceptional (I disclaim it being English, lest I make a fool of myself), I have not been able to find words that do this masterpiece justice!

'Moulin Rouge!' was one of the greatest movie experiences of this year, the acting was great, the songs and instrumental score are outstanding, the art direction and the costumes are brilliant, and Baz Luhrman did a good job for making another 'Moulin Rouge' movie, filled with drama, humor, romance, insane jealousy and tragedy. For the audience who love musicals, and 'Romeo & Julie', 'Moulin Rouge!' is really worth seeing, and even if that the movie slow downs at a time with the many love songs, there is a dramatic and exciting ending of the movie. Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor is a very nice pair in this movie, but even the two bad guys of the movie steals the scenes, and they does it nice too, with their flamboyant acting.

Review title: Muppets would have made it better!
Review_body: This movie was tacky, garish, and derivative.  I say to those who "love it", have you people seen a real musical with original music?  Like maybe "Fiddler on the Roof", "Grease", "The Sound of Music"?  Pick any Disney musical from the past fifty years and it would be better than this nonsensical mess.  The only way I can think to make it better would be to turn it into a Muppet movie.  Miss Piggy would be a much better Satine (as she would say, "at least Moi can speak in a French accent").  Kermit would be Christian and Fozzy (Waka, Waka, Waka!) would make a great Zidler. Mix in some "humans" like Dabney Coleman or Elliot Gould as the Duke.  Gonzo would make a terrific Toulouse-Lautrec and Rowlf (a dog) would be the perfect Narcoleptic Argentinean. I'm telling you Dr. Teeth and Rizzo Rat would fit this movie like a glove.  Wouldn't that be better?  Throw in catchy muppet songs and some wacky adventures and then you would have something to watch!

For me Moulin Rouge is one of the best films, if not the best film I have seen this year.I was really overwhelmed, and I had not expected it at all.The way of filming, the scenery, the casting, it was for me 100% successful, convincing.  But above all this is the film of Ewan Mcgregor, he is astonishing in his  performance, he IS Christian. I only knew him from Emma (with Gwyneth Paltrow), as Frank Churchill with the awful wig , and also there he proves he is a good singer.  But what he is showing us in Moulin Rouge is a total different Ewan,he certainly is one of the most versatile, talented young actors of the moment. I really do hope he will be able to enchant us again, maybe in the new Phantom of The Opera, he would be the ultimate Raoul !

Review title: worst film I've seen in years
Review_body: What a dreary experience Moulin Rouge was.  It's the worst film I've seen in years.  The story was unoriginal and mostly predictable, the songs mainly banal (though I admit there are few American musicals whose songs attract me much), and Ewan McGregor can't sing - he just opens his mouth too wide and sounds come out.  Nicole Kidman made quite a good fist of her singing opportunities, though.  She, and maybe Jim Broadbent's comic talent, were the only aspects of the film worth the trouble of sitting through it.  (I did so because my wife mildly enjoyed it).

Wow!  I have not seen a worse movie this year.  Then of course I like reality too much.  But if I want fantasy or escapism, I can see "Lord of the Rings" or a fine French movie "Ma Vie en Rose".  This waste of celluloid has little to redeem it.  The lone exceptions were the wonderful Jim Broadbent, the fine British actor, who seemed to be the only one in the farce that understood what being campy and over-the-top was.  Nicole Kidman, with her smooth milk skin and lovely looks unfortunately is as interesting as a glass of milk.  I was quite surprised how well Ewen MacGregor could sing.  Or was that his voice?  I am very capable of suspending my disbelief for a movie, but this mess, with its insertion of modern pop songs into turn of the century Paris was so forced and incongruous I left the room frequently (fortunately I didn't go to the theater for this).  I know the whole rational of musicals generally using music that is not specific to the era of the musical itself (i.e. "Oklahoma), and the attempt was to be over the top and tongue in cheek;  but I didn't have tongue-in-cheek; I had drool on cheek.  8.2 out of 10 on IMDB.  What a disgrace!  This film was a colossal waste of time, money, and energy.  Poor Tom Cruise is all I can say.  This obviously broke up the marriage.  Or was it the simpering "Jerry McGuire"? At least Nicole took of her privates a bit in "Eyes Wide Shut", which displayed her only true attributes as an actress.  I would have given it a zero on the voting scale, but they don't offer that.

Anyone who has seen this movie will tell you that it was by far the best performance by an actor this year.  Forget Nicole Kidman.  Ewan McGregor was the runaway star of this film. His character's love for the courtesan was so real. I truly believed every aspect of his character: his joyous outlook on life, his heartfelt belief in love above all else, his spontaneous and beautiful rendering of song (especially 'Come What May' and the 'Elephant Love Song').  Forget Gene Hackman, Denzel Washington, or Russell Crowe. For your consideration, Ewan for Best Actor!

When watching this movie I had never been affected by the previous hype, thus I did not know what to expect. I didn't even know it was a musical. All I had heard/watched was the Lady Marmelade video on MTV.Needless to say, it was a pleasant surprise. The potpourri of incredible actors, both leading roles and supporting cast; and inventive usage of modern and old songs gave the movie an incredible presence. Laughing and crying at the same time. Amazing.It's really a simple story, yet it moved me quite a bit unlike most other movies.9/10.

The odd practice of using modern rock music to portray the early 20th century was interesting at first but soon became tedious. The audience is set up early to expect a roller coaster ride of visual effects and absurd situations, unfortunately, neither of which are ever delivered.I found myself wondering if I was supposed to be laughing at this or walking out. I was overjoyed when it finished because at last I could go home and watch paint dry, which I'm certain would have been much more entertaining.This is a movie that either takes itself too seriously or not seriously enough, and its only redeeming feature is Nicole Kidman in lingere.

Review title: Bolero dancing lovers (could include some spoilers)
Review_body: It's can-can! Moulin Rouge bounces in the rhythm of director Baz Luhrman's heart. Man who woke us up in the mid-90's with his "Romeo and Juliet" adaptation has brought his new child of revolution into world after a few years of processing. Moulin Rouge is a bohemian musical and most of all love story. Ewan McGregor plays writer Christian who sings himself into parisian courtisan Satine's heart with such speed it makes your stomach  whirl. Not the developing of the lovestory but the set it develops in. Pop art's most known remarks using set decoration and music make a positively psychedelic combination. From the first minutes to the last this story takes the viewer into a wishes-filled world of love, honour -and of course- paying fees. Luhrman's passion for music and dance is admiarable. He continues (in his own, original way) the legacy of 40's and 50's movies which musical numbers where filled with skilful coreographies and colourful costumes. The soundtrack is packed with hits from the latest decades (such as "Roxanne" and "show must go on") and all new music including the should-have-been-nominated-for-best-song-academy-award "Come What May".Kidman and McGregor's performances are great. Christian is filled with little-boy like enthusiasm which makes him lovable. And yes, he can sing. Kidman is, for the first time, actually likeable. Her Satine is emotional and clever woman to whom Cristian offers a chance of her life. The couple play greatly together which makes their "from love to despair" story enjoyable. Otherwise quite ordinary triangle love -theme get's new dimension by the colourful characters and visual setting. Jim Broadbent is father-like but business-wise Zidler and John Leguizamo makes small but important role as Tolouse Lautrec. Inspite of all things fast (and quite furious,too)Moulin Rouge succeeds in which it's supposed to: convince the viewer that the greatest thing is boundless love. All I needed was a happy ending!

Consider a film that will stir your all feelings:Love,humor,happiness etc.Moulin Rouge is one of these rare films and it's not exploiting your feelings and abusing your senses.It's sometimes coming into such a moment that you are becoming disabled how to act cry,laugh or what?But this situation's main reason is perfect acting and harmony between Mcgregor and Kidman.Yes their performance is giving strength to each other's performance and this harmony is what making this film such a modern classic.Yes if we look as a musical film it's not actually putting music to the front but putting this love story to front and using music and songs to increase the effect of the film and becoming successful.In another words We can use drama as a genre for this film,because using music doesn't actually make a film musical,but this film can be put into a sub-genre and can be classified as musical-drama.But it has very big inspirations from musical atmosphere,all these funny and colorful world are main body of musical films.Luhrmann uses these both things(drama and musical)in a successful way.A beautiful lady(actually a bitch)sells his body till she sells her heart to a handsome and poor writer.Also this ironic side of story is enough for a musical-drama.But As a conclusion:Moulin Rouge is a very brilliantly made and harmonized film.

Review title: Left Me Cold-Does That Mean I Lack Passion?
Review_body: I didn't feel any emotions besides annoyance and discomfort during the two times-I gave it a second chance-that I saw "Moulin Rouge". I didn't feel the love and passion other people said they felt. I think the reason I didn't feel anything was because, to me, this movie is not even about the love which the characters preach so much about. First of all, the movie is more about jealousy than love. Jealousy represented in the silly and incredibly stupid Duke, idealistic Christian, and the prostitute that exposes the two lovers. Secondly, the word "love" is constantly used in vain in this movie. It is used to impress. Characters cherish inflated ideas of its importance. The John Leguizamo character keeps on using it to boast how he and other bohemians are so much better than others because they believe in "love." I agree with the other viewer who commented on "the blissfully ignorant use of...the word love" and mentioned the line from "The Princess Bride" ("I do not think you know what that word means"). It seemed as if the movie makers made the characters say the word "love" over and over again, so that if they repeated it enough the movie would be about love.False love at the sake of art does not champion love at all. "Moulin Rouge" is no true "champion" for the love which is supposed to be its theme.

Review title: Style over substance - what's wrong with that?
Review_body: I saw Moulin Rouge three days ago for the first time, on DVD, and apart from the film, the DVD is very much worth seeing - buying even!You may guess from that comment, that I loved it. 3 days later, I'm still left with a warm glow. The film is unashamedly about love, and I can understand many people hating it, because it's not a substantive film, like perhaps "A Beautiful Mind". To me, its the opposite of that film, where you are perhaps led to believe that you a fly on the wall of the life of Nash. Moulin Rouge is about being aware that this is fiction, that these characters aren't real, and showing an idyllic form of love that perhaps everyone should strive for, even if we can never reach it. The Moulin Rouge was a nightclub, and even today when we go to a nightclub, in a sense, its about leaving the real world behind, having a few drinks, dancing like maniacs, and maybe even finding love. Nightclubs are not about substance; they're about leaving substance behind.The film is pure entertainment, a feast for the eyes, ears and heart, not for the brain. The frenetic pace, the colour, the familiar and sentimental love songs, the fantasy characters and the comedy which is absolute farce, make this film a unique experience. The audience is asked to sit back and enjoy, without really trying to preach or teach you anything. It demonstrates that film can be pure art, like a painting or music or dance, with no other agenda but to lift you out of the mundane ordinariness of life.Congratulations to Baz Luhrmann for getting this film made, in an era where superficiality can be frowned upon, and films must fall into a category dictated by marketing people. Congratulations to Baz Luhrmann for casting Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, who were intelligent enough to see what he was trying to achieve, and going out on a limb with him to achieve it. Congratulations to Baz Luhrmann for his originality, bravery and vision in avoiding formulaic or so called "worthy" film-making. He has proved himself a visionary before, and he proves it again with Moulin Rouge. It is a shame that the Academy have not acknowledged him this year, because surely this was a directing triumph. I suspect that Moulin Rouge will go home empty handed from the Oscars, but that is an indictment of Hollywood, not of this great film. It is not only the best film of 2002, but probably the best film of the past ten years.Nicole Kidman was incredible in her perfectly judged over the top performance, as was Ewan McGregor for his wide-eyed innocence and purity. And the singing? Brilliant.
