They looked like two people utterly in love, and gave those old love songs a depth of meaning that they never had before.Maybe I'm shallow, but I'll take Baz Luhrmann's style over Ron Howard's substance any day of the week.Ten out of Ten!

Darn it.I used to be a movie lover. I loved most good films whether they were drama, romantic comedy, war, western...even musicals. I saw Moulin Rouge two weeks ago, on DVD. Last week, I rented Legally Blonde, a film I expected to enjoy. I didn't. I thought it was most unoriginal, unfunny, and a bore. The following day, I bought Moulin Rouge on DVD, and I've been watching it since...(without/with commentaries, behind the scenes stuff, choreography etc...there's a lot to get through!)I have a sinking feeling that I'm trapped in a world where the only movie I want to see is Moulin Rouge. Every film I've seen seems to pale in terms of the enjoyment factor. Honestly, it's like a drug! Despite the sad ending, every time, it seems to give me a high.Thanks a bunch, Baz, Nicole, Ewan and the rest of your accomplices, you have ruined my cinema-going forever. I'm off to find a "Moulin Rouge Anonymous" meeting.P.SMake it up to Baz for not getting a Best Director Nomination. Give it the Best Film Oscar...because we'll never see the likes of Moulin Rouge again. We'll have two more chances to see Lord of the Rings, and we've seen a Beautiful Mind several times before...Shine, My Left Foot, even Iris!

A beautiful masterpiece that dazzles with colour and wonderment. A film has never moved me before in the same way. it is not the narrative so much that sweeps an audience off their feet, but more the clever manipulation of well known songs and the brilliant and original snappy editing. This film moves quickly through its plot without pausing for a moments breath. Enchanting to look at and heart warming to listen to.  How wonderful life is now Moulin Rouge is in this world.

This has to be one of the best movies ever made. Words cant describe it. All I have to say is that every single bit of this movie (the directing, cinematography, costumes, music, and especially the acting) is superb. I can probably watch it a million times and never get bored! It really makes me sad that the academy would award "A Beautiful Mind" (not that it isn't good) with best picture over this. The best musical ever!10/10 without a doubt.

Baz Luhrman has proved to be the bravest and most talented of all main-stream directors.  His gentle irony is incredible.  This irony may be the reason why this movie has done better outside United States. Americans simply are not used to irony or metaphor as means of telling a story. This is by far the best movie I have seen in many a year, and I predict it will influence future moviemakers.  We may have seen the first 21st century movie when we saw the 'Moulin Rouge.'

Recently my wife and I saw Moulin Rouge and I have to be the first to admit how wrong I could be. When she mentioned she wanted to see this film, I thought "oh God! This is going to be horrible!" and boy was I ever wrong.
This has to be the worst movie ever released (I am talking worse than such bad flicks as Yor, Armed and Dangerous, and even any cheese late night b-movie on Showtime.) I hardly could stand the sight of this so-called "artistic wonderment" without wondering to myself if it was possible to have this film banned as a cruel and unusual punishment.I have no idea why anyone would consider this movie a "GREAT" film other than those who spend their time talking about the esoteric qualities of Dadaism and the writings of Voltaire.The plot (?) was highly predictable and the characters were less evolved than those from "Dude, Where's My Car?" The only thing that could have made this film worse is the addition of the "cut-scenes" that are provided on the DVD version.I hate to be so harsh on this film that it seems has found some fan-friendly audience but I would rather wish that my friends live with a colostomy bag than to see this movie.

Man what a fantastic movie! I will go so far as to say that it is THE best movie I have ever seen. Such an emotional journey, with amazing performances, sets and fantastic music! I have watched this movie 50 times and it never ceases to amaze me! Nicole and Baz were robbed on Oscar night! If you haven't seen this movie - you need to see it, it is life changing!

I was REALLY looking forward to this. The opening credits only heightened the anticipation and for the first twenty minutes or so it was a magnificent spectacle, but then the film got bogged down in repetitive padding. The musical numbers seemed ten times as long as they needed to be and I started to get both bored and irritated, a mood which carried on to the end credits - a shame, as performances were great and the whole film looked absolutely stunning. But I would rather have had more of a script which did justice to the film rather than the same bloody Elton John song seemingly over and over again. I shall rent it out at a later date, just to enjoy the beauty all over again, but I'll be fast forwarding over a lot of the musical bits......

Review title: All that glitter is not gold!
Review_body: Moulin was a big beautiful, energetic waste of time. I give it's makers credit for creating a rather interesting diversion, from the norm. This movie really stinks as a musical, even though the staging of the production numbers was well done. Whoever sang for Ewan McGregor, should be arrested for assault with a irritating weapon of a voice. Ewan McGregor was convincing as a young man, hopelessly, foolishly in love with a very shady lady, with a cough. Let's face it, he must have been totally unconscious, not to have noticed. Nicole Kidman, was drop dead gorgeous, especially for a woman on the verge of death, I felt a little offended at this intermittent cough was used soley for dramatic effect. This woman had one of the most contagious diseases of all time, and would have infected many people way before these events could have happened. Kidman's characterization was arresting, but not enough to forget that she was a user, a manipulator, a cheap, overused woman. Nicole Kidman is very talented, but if she actually had the charisma to pull this part off, it could have mad a very interesting movie.Again, congratulations are in order for the movie's design. Generally high marks for the two major actors; for meeting the challenge of very difficult roles. I don't buy the idea of re-cycled music, even if it is fairly well utilized. With all the effort, that was put into creating a unique visual extravaganza; an equal effort to create a score to match, would have been an major accomplishment.I agree with the person who said this would have worked better as a stage play. I think it could have made a great stage play, even lacking the full movie glitz. Perhaps, this would have made for a more personal work of art, with a heart.

This is a glitzy movie on heroin if you ask me. If you crave flash, and color and lack of any real story you have come to the right place.Modern music in a turn of the century period piece? It is off-putting to say the least.Kidman is beautiful but her voice is not up to this. And frankly her character is tragic but not particularly likeable. At the end when you should be feeling for her you are actually just hoping the movie ends soon.McGregor is a little better but the herky jerky camera shots just leave you feeling more queasy than anything else.I was hoping to see a movie with some interesting characters, music, and an honest to goodness story. Instead all i got was a headache.

After due consideration, I have decided that the ever coveted last spot on my top 5 films of all time list has been filled by a captivating piece of cinematic brilliance called "Moulin Rouge!". To call "Moulin Rouge!" a film is an act of uninhibited slander, for it is nothing short of transcendental cinematic excellence. Baz Luhrman weaves such rich tapestry of well placed fades, camera movement and clever inserts of Christian's narrative typewriter that truly make this an example of modern day storytelling, full of the revolutionary bohemian ideals around which the film revolves, and not merely part of the money making hollywood bourgeoisie. The script is brilliant, with the writers finding clever ways of steering the character's converstations into classic songs, with tweaked lyrics to further the story. An example of this is how Ziedler artfully stalls the Duke from noticing Satine's apparent disappearance by saying, "you make her feel like a virgin!" which of course leads into a slightly comical rendition of Madonna's "Like a Virgin" performed by two men, one slightly overweight, one slightly under. The cast is stellar. Ewan McGregor proves he has what it takes to be one of Hollywood's top leading men, with a great range of skills that is not limited to a withdrawal sickened Heroin addict or a Saber wielding Jedi. John Leguizamo as the diminutive Toulouse, gives his best performance since "To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything, Julie Newmar". And no words can be said to describe the Beautiful Nicole Kidman except "stunning enchantress". All these elements combine to create one of the best films of 2001, but of all the aspects of this multifaceted masterpiece one rises above the rest. The Score. The songs, unlike in most musicals, aren't an uncomfortable break in  the flow of the film. In fact, not merely musical interludes, the song and dance numbers all help to further the story by driving home emotions that are intensified for the audience, by the powerful music with which they are delivered. An example is the full orchestral Tango scene in which the Argentinean explains to the crestfallen Christain, why one should never fall in love with a woman who sells herself, via a latin flavored version of Roxanne. I am not one who usually enjoys musicals, in fact most drive me insane, so it came to me as quite a shock that I loved this movie as much as I do. When i first saw it I regarded it as good and not much more, but after re-watching it a few times, I've been captivated by the sheer joy of imagining a world full of fun and fancy, magic and mystery, and of course true love. Not only was it artfully directed and beautifully written but it was also an example of a genuine love story. And when it comes down to it, that's all Moulin Rouge really is. A story about Love, a never ending, undying, perpetual, and all encompassing love.

This is one of my favorite movies and in my opinion the best musical ever. Nicole Kidman is a brilliant actress.  And Ewan McGregor, wow who knew he could sing....?  I love Baz Luhrman's work especially Romeo and Juliet so i couldn't wait to see Moulin Rouge and i was not dissapointed. The movie is non stop colour,music,song,dance and drama that kept me completely entertained.  And the sets and costumes were amazing. If you haven't seen this movie yet you must.It was "Spectacular Spectacular" 10/10.

...they had to mangle Roxanne.Their copious use of modern pop songs sometimes works, and sometimes doesn't.  Roxanne was one of those times when it definitely did NOT.I think if perhaps a slightly more original score were used, and the pop songs used a bit more sparingly, I could've given it a 10.Unfortunately, I just can't shake that horrid gravel-throated groaning narcoleptic grunting "Roxanne".As I said, there were times when the song selection worked perfectly (atop the elephant, "Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend") times when it fit in a humorous manner ("Like A Virgin") and then...the putrid rendition of Roxanne.ugh.Anyway, Obi-Wan shows some darn fine diversity here and Nicole Kidman, well...that was easily an Oscar-winning performance.  I like Halle Berry, but Nicole Kidman's performance was outstanding, I thought, and clearly overshadowed Halle BerryOverall, a fantastically creative and enjoyable ride.  Incidentally, you probably won't find this on TBS' "Movies for Guys who Like Movies" marathon list.

The average time between cuts must be about one second. All those relentless changes of camera angle made the movie exhausting to watch. After 20 minutes I cared more about sleeping then what happened to the characters. I slept for the rest of the movie.

i was late in seeing this movie, and i regret it sssooo bad. i fell in love with moulin rouge. the story swept me away, the actors gave breathtaking performances, the romance made me cry, and the costumes were fabulous. if you haven't seen this movie, definitely rent it.

Moulin Rouge is absolutely, overwhelmingly the most fantastical film that I have ever seen.  I cannot believe that I missed this movie in theaters and never bothered renting it.  I was so blown away by this film - which is funny, because it wasn't until I watched this movie that I remembered that as a child, I adored John Houston's Moulin Rouge.  That was a very different movie, where if memory serves me right, I felt very drawn and empathetic towards Toulouse Lautrec and the Can Can girls.  But it's ironic to see a movie about the same place and same period of time that is so true to the spirit of the Moulin Rouge and yet absolutely different and original from any of the movies that came before it.The cinematography is breathtaking.  I know some people criticized it as being too much but I could not get enough of it.  And Nicole Kidman was born to be Satine.  Ewan McGregor made me feel like I was a little girl getting a childhood crush all over again for the first time.  I cannot stress how much I enjoyed seeing these two opposite one another.  They're not a pair I ever would've thought of, but they work so beautifully opposite each other. The music is Wonderful.  So totally cool to hear Nirvana and Elton John and Marilyn's calling card and Material Girl all blended into a kind of crazy insanely cool operatic opus of modern culture.  Baz Luhrman is in a league of his own and his vision is nothing short of extraordinary.  I enjoyed his Romeo and Juliet due to the visuals and his unique vision of an often told story, but with Moulin Rouge he has graduated straight from grade school to a Master's Degree.Entirely it's own world - absolutely wonderful.  But most of all, exquisite. He has totally resurrected and redefined the genre of the musical and it is an astounding pleasure.  And Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor earned my undying support for taking a chance and committing themselves one hundred percent to the story.  I'm so thrilled that it paid off for all of them and their hard work.A high recommend.  And a gushing 10

There is nothing in this movie that one can complain about. Every aspect of it is stunning. Even though the first few scenes are at a fast pace, it sets the mood for what the Moulin Rouge is. It is clear that Baz Luhrman thought of every last minute detail. There is nothing in this movie that is out of place or missing. It is the symbol of perfection. The acting is brilliant, singing beautiful, and incredibly visually stunning. I can't complain!

*spoiler within*A perfect example of the decline of artistry in popular culture, not only in itself but in the insidious popularity it gained.  Moulin Rouge was repeatedly lauded for being "artistic" by its fans.  No description could be less apt.  The dizzying camera effects, the lavish sets and sequinned costumes, and the purchased rights to sample just about every pop song from the last thirty years: these are not the visions of an artist; they are the machinations of an egomaniac with a morbidly obese budget.All chance of subtlety destroyed in the first few minutes, Moulin Rouge goes on to state its three virtues: "truth, beauty, and most of all love," which it will repeat the names of ad nauseum.  Let's look at those one by one. Truth is utterly lacking in this film.  Set in a turn-of-the-century whorehouse, the production is glitzier than Broadway's "42nd Street." Neither this nor the utterly generic plot lends any bit of credence to its claims of truth.  Beauty is not to be found either, as the film is so gaudy that even Nicole Kidman can not stand out.  Her quiet, nymph-like beauty does not go well at all with her surroundings, and she appears pale and sickly (only foreshadowing the end by sheer dumb luck).  That brings me to love, which is the the most sorely lacking part of the movie.  At what point do the main characters fall in love?  Never.  Their relationship consists of idiotic musical numbers and the word "love" bounced back and forth faster than a ping pong ball carrying the plague.  Anyone duped by the embarrassing sincerity of Kidman and Ewan McGregor, both good enough actors to force out their hokey lines, clearly does not know what love is.  And "Sparkling diamond?"  Are you kidding me?I try to watch this movie every time it's on cable.  I *try* to watch it, but I've never forced myself to sit through five minutes of it since I saw it in the theater.  The musical numbers are too embarrassing (with the exception of the cover of The Police's "Roxanne"), the acting too earnest (with the exception of Jim Broadbent, who is always cool no matter what), and the dialogue too ridiculous (with no exception- none at all).

Review title: Satine must choose between the man who can finace her and the man who showed her true love exists.
Review_body: This movie was so beautiful. It brings me to tears, yet makes me laugh my head off every time I watch it.The acting was amazing..Nicole and Ewan have perfect chemistry. The singing was beautiful...as Elton John said "[Ewan] Sings [Your song] Better then I ever did!" And Nicole's voice just breaks my heart.The story was so tragic. It was beautifuly told by the best director of our time. Baz has such vision. I love him!

This is my favorite movie in the world. The music is great, the dancing is great, the acting is great, as you can see everything is great!!! Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor do excellent jobs singing, yes, those are their actual voices. I could listen to Ewan sing for the rest of my life. This is the one movie I recommend to everyone. So, go see it!

I love musicals, and I have to say that this is some of the best music that I've heard in a movie in a long time. My favorite was "Come What May", a duet between Kidman and McGregor, which was absolutely beautiful. They both have unique voices, not the best, but rich and powerful, and that's all that's needed in these songs. The only song I was disappointed with was "Like a Virgin", which absolutely sickened me and made me hate the song. I thought the tragic love story between Christian and Satine was beautiful, but a little overdramatic and overdone. Their love is best portrayed through the songs. The acting is excellent, especially on Kidman's part. I know the Moulin Rouge are like an abstract acting business, and while those aren't my favorite types of people, their costumes and makeup are very well done. The cuts are also a little too quick moving. The costumes are gorgeous, I love the flashiness of all of it. While I admit it was a little hard to follow, esepcially with all the quick cuts, the movie was great. 8/10

Back in 2001 when this film came out, my friend and I found ourselves outside the cinema with a choice; Enigma, that dreary-looking World War II film with Kate Winslet, or this, Moulin Rouge, which I had, after seeing the adverts, already decided was not for me.In the end we chose Moulin Rouge and boy am I glad we did.This is a wonderful film, with stunning sets and costumes, great music, and excellent performances.It tells the story of a young writer who moves to Paris to be part of the Bohemian revolution. Here he falls in love with Satine, a glamorous courtesan who works at the Moulin Rouge. Complications arise when 'The Duke' gains the deeds to the club and demands that Satine be exclusively his.Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman are delightful as the two lovers, while Jim Broadbent, Richard Roxburgh and John Leguizamo provide excellent support.Baz Luhrmann is a director of real visual style and flair, delivering a film that is funny and moving in turns.Musically, Moulin Rouge! is innovative and fun, with modern songs placed into the context of turn of the century Paris - standouts are the Tango de Roxanne, and Broadbent and Roxburgh's hilarious version of Like a Virgin, although there's also a song written especially for the film, Come What May, that is beautiful.This film may not be to everyone's taste, but I strongly urge you to give it a chance. And this is coming from someone who was resolved to hate it even before the red curtain had opened.....still haven't seen Enigma.....

Review title: A wonderful movie that teaches a lesson. (possible spoilers)
Review_body: If you ever want to learn about true love, you should watch this movie. It is amazing. At first it was a little weird at first. The bohemians talking and trying to make Spectualar Spectualar, however the movie got better as they enter the Moulin Rouge. The line from the one song, "How wonderful like is when you in the world." I love that one line. The songs, the dances, the characters. I fell in love with the movie the first time I watch it. I think it a movie for men and woman. Considering there are a few scenes in the movies that are "rated R" material. I would advise against children watching it. But it is amazing with a capital "A".

I have watched this film several times over, and I understand why some vote for less than excellent, I would have too after my first viewing.This is one of the few films that improves by watching it over. The acting is marvelous, the citations are endless, there is humor and irony almost in every sentence and there is strong moral message in it to. The combination is just perfect, the comedy part of the movie does not make it ridiculous and the dramatic part is tuned below corniness.I fell in love with Satine and the film, and I shed tears at the end every time I see it. I strongly urge everyone who have seen the film and do not share my feelings to watch it again

I have seen this film countless times as a child and even now I am not bored with it. The film uniquely visual and energetic. The story was cliché but directing, narrative storytelling, soundtrack, and cinematography made up for that. It was full of adrenaline and I think film does even give the viewer space to breathe.Nicole Kidman and and Ewan McGregor at at there best in this movie and they have chemistry in every one of their scenes.The soundtrack was indescribably delightful. It was like the combined the old with the new. For example, I Will Always Love You is an 80s songs but they remade for the film which sounded different but delightful at the same time.The film was an effective blend of tragedy and comedy and was almost like a cartoon (but that's made it special).10 out of 10.

Honestly the worst film I have ever seen. My wife said it was amazing so we just downloaded on Amazon prime. Absolutely dreadful! Not one person can sing or act. Maybe that was the point but I'm not sure. Makes mama Mia look good.

Someone artistic recommended this movie to me after I said I'd never seen it because the shorts hadn't appealed way back when, and the cast wasn't a drawcard for me either.
"Watch it, you'll love it." So I did, and I didn't... should have listened to my gut (meh)Barrage of colours and sound, felt under attack for a solid 2hrs. Found the tired tropes did not hold my interest or endear any of the characters to me.Ultimately, just not my idea of a good time.Finally, after we're told she has consumption, (TB, highly contagious from coughing, etc.), I was cringing at all the close talking and kissing between the pair of lovers. Or that could be my COVID-tinted view now....

I saw this movie over a year ago, and this is one of the best films I have ever seen! If you haven't seen it, I certainly suggest going out to your nearest store and purchasing it!!! Baz Luhrmann's masterpiece, featuring the lovely Nicole Kidman as a nightclub diva and Ewan McGregor as a penniless writer is one of the greatest love stories of the 20th century.The dancing, the singing... Nicole did an excellent job, and Ewan's voice just blew me away!!! I still sing the songs and listen to the soundtracks I have, and it is just something you either love and or hate. I have never seen such a wonderful picture, what else could I say? Even though some of it may not seem unrealistic (at times), who doesn't want a man singing to them like how Ewan does to Nicole? Besides that, they were in love, and who doesn't love a love story? I think Baz Luhrmann is an absolete genius and he is considered God in my eyes. He took the dive, along with everyone else involved in this project, and it was certainly worth the plunge.I am always using the famous quotes from the film, but mostly just this one... "The greatest thing you'll ever learn is just to love... and be loved in return."

'Moulin Rouge' is an experience. From the first seconds in the story takes you away to Montmartre, a bohemian place which you might have heard of, or you didn't even knew it existed. Either way the whole atmosphere and environment of this film will make you feel like you are there with the characters, and you are lucky to be the third person to see whats happening over there.I've watched this film many times, and every time it just amazes me, especially the music. The songs were always great. "Roxanne" and "Your song" were always beautiful to me. But except for those songs there are a lot of great musical pearls in 'Moulin Rouge!'. The passion that McGregor and Kidman deliver in all those songs is just amazing. I'm not too proud to admit it, but every time i hear "come what may" I cry. Because sometimes you have given up on love and when these two marvelous actors sing that song, it makes you want to believe again.For me the whole story is a masterpiece, because you are in a a story which tells about a theater play (kind of inception) while the two are connected in every way. Every time I see it I see more references from the story to the play, and discovering new things is always fun. When you've watched a movie once you already know whats going to happen in the end. But when you still want to watch it again and get touched by all the great scenes including the ending, you know that this movies is definitely worth a 10 out of 10.

Review title: The Magic of Musicals brought back to the screen! Woo!
Review_body: I love Moulin Rouge. Being a theater person, I love how the story and the feelings of love are communicated in song and fantastic dance numbers. It also had that classic playful feel about it like the old musicals of the 1950s had, with the cheesy grins to the camera and all. Plus the acting is so wonderful; making your heart float over clouds and then suddenly break. Every time I see this movie I cry, even though I know what it happens, it kills me every time. As a an admirer of Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor and John Leguizamo, all this movie did was make me admire than even more, for taking such a risk with this movie...because people either love it or loathe it (which is so sad for them). This movie also made me realize what I want out of love...and thats to risk everything for it...ah, also the character Christian is just one of the many characters from movies I would love to have in my ideal man...(Noah from The Notebook and Seth from The O.C) being the other two sides! So yes, this movie is adorable and the songs are so catchy. Especially the Elephant Love Medoly - learn the lines to that song and you'll never go back, you'll be hooked on musicals (Check), hooked on love (Check) and definitely hooked on the Moulin Rouge (CHECK!!!)

Review title: Stunning visual, great music and acting
Review_body: This movie takes a huge risk, with over-the-top melodrama, dancing and extravagant sets, but it works because the acting is strong and the music is great. There is a scene where they incorporate the song "Roxanne" as a tango with a huge ballroom full of dancers, while cutting back to a private scene where a courtesan is deciding whether to sell herself, and it's visually stunning with the song used to great effect. This was unlike any movie I've ever seen, in some senses a classic musical but unlike others because it mixes so many styles of music. The actors and the director should all be commended for putting themselves out there and making this work, at least for me.

I'll admit the first time I saw this movie I didn't really like it but the next day I watched it again to see if I missed anything the day before. And WOW. I understood so much more of it! And I remember the first time I saw it,the moment that Ewan McGregor opened his mouth to sing I was in awe.And now, I've seen this movie so many times i can scarcely count! It's definitely my favorite movie ever! Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor have such beautiful voices and they fit together. If you like musicals and a tragic romance this is definitely the movie for you! Baz Luhrmann did a absolutely wonderful job with this film. He took a big risk with this film but pulled it off and it became a hit! I know a lot of people who aren't really into musicals and such, but I got some of them to watch Moulin Rouge and they ended up loving it! This is the best movie in the whole world!!! I give it 10/10 stars!!

I don't write much but for this masterpiece I decided to express my feelings
I've finished watching Moulin rouge for the million time, and oh my God, every time my attachment to this movie increases, a genius film, a film not repeated for a hundred years, Baz I dunno where the inspiration came from but this is indescribable, everyone who worked in this masterpiece should be proud, honestly, I've seen all the films of director Baz and I didn't like any of them, but directing and writing this masterpiece has sealed art of cinema, and if only this film had come out it would have been sufficient to prove baz is a legend.Baz Luhrmann you are a genius thank you for this masterpiece, And thanks a lot Catherine martin.

My fiancée, whom I love dearly, had been bugging me to see this movie since we began dating. Now, she is a huge Star Wars fan, and I began to suspect this may have been a case of Ewan-desire and not so much for the movie itself. I still think that's the case. However, I also went into this expecting to enjoy it because I adore musicals. I pointed out that I would have walked out of the theater during the chaotic, pointless beginning but was glad she told me it was a good movie, possibly had a bad beginning. (Side note here: Why do movies perpetuate the myth that Absinthe does.. well.. anything? It's just an anise wine. It's a clean drunk and nothing more, people. Yes, Wormwood is an hallucinogenic... BUT ONLY IN DOSES BIG ENOUGH TO KILL AN ELEPHANT!!) My walk out instinct would have been correct. What a piece of garbage... from the music on down to the plot. The second I heard something from Nirvana, my guts recoiled. But I thought it was a onetime thing just to be cute. Then the movie went on and on and on and on with that crap. Hey, when you're writing a musical? Write at least one or two of your own bleeping songs. Unoriginal hack. Even the big romantic number, Come What May? I can't place it exactly but I am SURE I've heard it before.My fiancée can attest that I knew everything that was going to happen as surely as I could sing the next line of almost every song before the characters did. I said "She's going to die of some illness." about 10 seconds after she started dancing with Ewan's character. According to her we were told she dies at the beginning.. but I wasn't in the room yet. The plot was stiflingly boring and predictable, replete with the obligatory forced part wherein Satine tries to convince what's-his-name that she didn't love him. Blah blah blah money, blah blah dying. Blah blah all rich people are evil. Yammer patter whore with a heart of gold. Art and love are truth blah blah the show must go on yammer blah blah. *Yawn* At any point after the first 15 minutes I could have paused the movie, told her the rest of the story, and only have missed some pointless subplot about the proposed ending of the play.This gets a 2, at least, because.. hey Ewan can SING! And sing WELL. It's just painful to hear WHAT they made him sing.And I don't care what the directors and whatnot say. Nicole Kidman is not singing in this movie. She is so obviously lip-syncing it that it's painful to watch.MY overall advice? The beginning was a great hint that I would have been wise to take. This movie is all flash and pretty swirly distracting stuff....incidentally, nobody would ever refer to the famous dance as doing the "can can can". When you say it three times, it means something about Euclidean geometry.

The liner notes on the back of the DVD were very accurate: one said something like "there's never been a movie like this," and it was quite true. I have no idea what I had expected in this show, but it was not a cross between a musicale and an opera, with flights of fantasies between animated and live scenes, a lot of screaming and running around, and general chaos.There was quite a bit of pop music (oldies in 2006) which was not written when Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec was alive, and seemed like a cheap way to import music into the show. The original music was interesting, and Ewan Mc Gregor is cute and apparently able to sing! I will look for other movies of his.

What can I say? This movie blew me away. I remember the first time I saw it; I started it late at night, around midnight. By 2am in the morning, I was bawling uncontrollably, and then just sat there and worshiped every name in the credits list. Director Baz Luhrmann is simply amazing. The way he incorporated the music into this movie added so much to the plot. I have to say, my favorite musical part is when the Diamond Dogs come out singing "Lady Marmalade" and then the men come in singing "Smells Like Teen Spirit." You would think the songs were written for the movie the way they fit so well into the plot! I'm amazed every time I watch it. The acting that went into this movie was incredible. If you think about it, Moulin Rouge is a play inside a play inside a book inside an opera inside a movie. And yet, as confusing as that sounds, it works out perfectly. Kidman and McGregor are amazing together, and their accents are adorable. Besides them, I admire Jim Broadbent who played Zidler the most. He had a very complex character that was hard to express, and he nailed it. It's been three years since it's release and I still watch it religiously. That's how much I admire this movie. To not give this movie a ten, you must be either emotionally dead, or male.

OK, so i never intended to watch this piece of dribble but when you study film your forced to watch things that you wouldn't naturally view. when this film was screened in my "Australian cinema" class i wrote three pages on how awful this feature was. I wont elaborate on how bad this blemish on the Aussie screen is, all i will say is: the acting was terrible, even for such high caliber Thespians as Mcgregor and Kidman... the sets were poorly constructed... the composition was worse than a 1970's sci-fi... the women too ugly... and would it have killed them to have written an original soundtrack???? if this is the prime example of Australian musical cinema then please, let us never make another musical.the only people who will enjoy this film are the deaf-blind, and the retarded.please destroy all copies. this is something we should not pass down to future generations.

Review title: Great cinematography, pity about the plot and the dialogue
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is a stunningly beautiful film, with cinematography that manages to capture the flair of Paris in 1900. Unfortunately, that is not enough to make you overlook the ridiculus plot or the contrived script. From the moment Ewan McGregor first began to sing (in a send up of the Sound of Music), I knew we were in for something truly cringe-worthy. This scene was only topped by the version of Like a Virgin (Yes, Madonna's Like a Virgin) sung by the fat nightclub owner and the effeminate English duke. Even a wonderful performance by the ever reliable Ewan McGregor couldn't save this film. My advice: Save your time/money and a few brain cells.

I came with the expectation that this movie would be slightly strange, seeing as the director was the same as the one for Romeo and Juliet.  I was not particularly impressed with the filming in Romeo and Juliet, but I admired the rest of the film.  Moulin Rouge went way beyond my expectations for a movie.  I had no idea the movie was about love, as the trailer had been slightly confusing and vague.  What I discovered at the theater was a true gem.  The movie very unassumingly takes its place within the category of musical, though the music in no way draws from the plot or the acting, but merely draws you into the story.  Most musicals seem ridiculous in the way characters spontaneously break into a song or dance.  This movie was in no way ridiculous.  On top of that, the songs were familiar.  In A Knight's Tale, a use of modern music was attempted, but to some haphazardous effect.  In Moulin Rouge, the familiar music was wonderful because it was performed in an entirely new light.  For example, I am not at all a fan of Elton John's "Your Song," but Ewan McGregor performed it so beautifully and with such feeling that I could not help falling in love with it.  The acting was very impressive and believable, though Kidman was a bit over-the-top, but true to character.  On the whole, this movie had a beautiful message to contribute and was expertly and entertaininly conveyed.  A delight to watch

It would be easier to "relax and enjoy myself" if my visceral reaction wasn't one of a revulsion at the lack of originality (yes, I know how many seem to view this as "original", "brilliant", "dazzling", "visually stunning", et al more appropriately, ad nauseum]). Sticking modern pop songs in a movie about 19th century Paris doesn't cut it as original. Neither does quoting 3 different pop "definitions" of love (twice), "Love is like oxygen. Love is a many-splendored thing. Love lifts us up where we belong" and treating it within the movie as the world's most beautiful poetry while winking at the audience who know their origins. Plus for something to be visually stunning, the human eye would need to focus on an image for more than the 2-second instances Luhrmann gives the audience. All this added up to a director who was afraid to tell a story rather than a daring artist "reinventing" cinema or a movie genre. Luhrmann's use of these pop songs and quick edits were cheap devices and distractions that kept me from relating to the characters or caring for them for one second. In a word: bad; in five words: bad, bad, bad, bad, bad.

What a truly godawful movie.  The actors chew scenery in a manner that would put William Shatner to shame, the score consists of ruined, overproduced versions of songs, many of which sucked to begin with, and the direction is a non-stop bore-ride of empty gimmickry.  Even the much-lauded use of anachronism is unoriginal: see Ken Russell's "Lisztomania" or Alex Cox's "Walker" for examples of the technique that actually have some redeeming value, unlike "Moulin Rouge".A steaming pile of dogsh*t is still nasty, no matter how many bows and ribbons you tie around it.

Review title: Simply the MOST Beautiful Film I have ever SEEN!!!
Review_body:
Honestly. I literally had to be dragged into this film kicking and
screaming. I knew it had to be the worst movie ever made and I would not in
a million years pay to see such tripe. My wife insisted and alas I gave in.
Maybe only to keep her quiet.2 Hours 20 minutes Later......Moulin Rouge is an exquisite, tearjerking, mayhem filled Extravaganza.
Quite
Possibly the best film I have ever seen. I was so glad my wife forced me
into that theater, and I pity anyone who doesn't see it in a split
minute.Albeit the love story within the love story has been DONE to death but who
cares. This is certainly the most original film I have had the pleasure of
viewing in a long while. The Performances were top notch besides Nicole
Kidman who seemed to be in a daze for most of the film, But Ewan McGregor
knocks your socks right off!!! He has a voice that could melt butter and
his
acting is top notch.I recommend this film to anyone and everyone.Truth, Beauty, Freedom, and above all else, Love.

Review title: Simply the MOST Beautiful Film I have ever SEEN!!!
Review_body: Honestly. I literally had to be dragged into this film kicking and screaming. I knew it had to be the worst movie ever made and I would not in a million years pay to see such tripe. My wife insisted and alas I gave in. Maybe only to keep her quiet.2 Hours 20 minutes Later......Moulin Rouge is an exquisite, tearjerking, mayhem filled Extravaganza. Quite Possibly the best film I have ever seen. I was so glad my wife forced me into that theater, and I pity anyone who doesn't see it in a split minute.Albeit the love story within the love story has been DONE to death but who cares. This is certainly the most original film I have had the pleasure of viewing in a long while. The Performances were top notch besides Nicole Kidman who seemed to be in a daze for most of the film, But Ewan McGregor knocks your socks right off!!! He has a voice that could melt butter and his acting is top notch.I recommend this film to anyone and everyone.Truth, Beauty, Freedom, and above all else, Love.

Strangely alluring cinematic eye candy.Phenomenally well filmed, scripted acted and sung.Mr Luhrmann adds to the style of his last outing, Romeo and Juliet - which seemed to be a "near miss" to me - by drawing on influences as far apart as Guy Ritchie, Alan Parker and F W Murnau.A semi gothic operatic poptastic modern day contemporary masterpiece.Nicole Kidman acts an utterly convincing courtesan without letting us forget that this is in fact a story within a film, rather than a film about a story.Ewan McGregor keeps you from losing yourself in Ms Kidman's brilliant performance with a "no better than very good" input to the proceedings.Vivid colours form a kaleidoscopic - almost montage like - experience. Modern songs brilliantly segue one into the next and seamlessley enter and exit the script. An aural and visual treat.Don't miss it.

This movie won't appeal to everyone, with some occasional disorienting visuals and a whole lot of weirdness, but I loved every second of it. I just saw a free sneak preview and am planning to pay money to see it again as soon as it comes out, which should tell you how much I liked it. The most obvious influences are Fellini, Busby Berkeley, Bob Fosse's "Cabaret" and MTV, but there are a lot more. I can honestly think of no movie enough like this one to say "If you liked X, you'll like this." It is that unique and original.

I've seen this in the theater 13 times, so it would be safe to say that I like it.  I know people who don't who have only seen it on DVD or Video, and I can understand that because I've also seen it on DVD and it almost doesn't work in that medium.  You need the big screen with an audience to get the whole sensation.  The DVD did answer a number of questions about the editing of the "Come What May" scenes where it's choppy and people are not where they should be or are on stage and at the same time in the "audience". Sorry to hear that "Come What May" was not eligible for an Oscar because it was used somewhere in "Romeo and Juliet", but it's still a great song. In any event, the show will still go on and on and on. Bravo!

This unbearable movie is torture to sit through.  Witless, arch and heavy-handed, it is essentially a wan imitation of a Ken Russell movie. Nicole Kidman has all the charm of a dead codfish, but John Leguizamo is shockingly bad -- his performance is a textbook for bad comic timing.  And Baz Luhrmann shows a dreary lack of imagination in the obvious, uninspired songs he uses.  The absolute pits.

My wife and I came out of the cinema stunned. This is cinema taken to the edge. Presenting the performance as if we were sitting in a live theatre. The colours are incredible, so bright and vivid. Excellent settings and costumes. The essence of the age was captured so well. OK, so the singing voices aren't perfect, but the way the songs were intertwined was witty and amusing. And for a thirty something like myself I amused myself trying to spot the various song titles throughout the film. I can also understand the negative criticism. If musicals aren't your cup of tea this film would be dire. Indeed I was reluctant to go and see it and this is the only failing: i.e. as it is a musical it will put people off. But if you open your eyes to this feast of a cinematic presentation then this film will be very hard indeed to better. Here's hoping Nicole Kidman gets an Oscar nomination, as well as various members of the production team from the director to designers. A brilliant piece not to be missed.

Review title: Best on-screen experience since "Shakespeare in Love"
Review_body: Particularly given the slim pickings for grown-ups at the movies, "Moulin Rouge" is the best on-screen experience since "Shakespeare in Love."  The two films have a lot in common:  they both seek to define love, they both stress the play within the play (always an appealing technique), and they both are about male playwrights seeking the girl of their dreams. Wonderful direction, filming, and editing.  It truly will appeal to the MTV generation and their parents. Go see it!

Review title: If you Want a Massive Headache, Watch this Movie
Review_body: Gag me with a giant MTV spoon! This was like watching MTV for 3 hours without a break. If you like that sort of thing then go see this movie. If however you like movies to have an interesting plot, authentic acting, characters you can care about and a camera that stays still for a few seconds at least, then save your money. Nicole looks good but the sex-appeal is just not there. The music is silly. I felt sorry for the actors. The supporting cast is forced to do the worst acting of their lives. The whole thing is just an expensive failure in film making.

There are a lot of bad films, but at least, those are not supposed to be original, nice, etc... Moulin Rouge film (which it's supposed to be located in Paris, but that's just because the Eiffel tower it's shown) it's just an awful 2 hours video clip. The worst experience I had in a movie theater for the last 10 years. For sure!

My wife and I were pleasantly surprised that one of the inflight movies on the way to our honeymoon in Hawaii was Moulin Rouge. We, especially her, had been wanting to see it for a while. After the movie was over, we were spellbound! The music was tremendous and catchy. We literally could not stop singing the songs all week while in Hawaii. On the way back from Hawaii, guess what movie was playing again! We both looked at each other like 2 little kids and quickly grabbed our headsets so we could watch it a second time. The story is beautiful and heartbreaking at the same time. I highly recommend seeing it with an open mind. Seeing this movie with a closed mind will ruin its beauty. Remember, "All you need is love!".

I have only walked out of 2 movies in my life - including this one.  The only positive was that Nicole Kidman looked fabulous, but even her looks couldn't pull this off.  The music was beyond poor.  I found myself thinking of all the people who would be collecting royalties for the use of their songs.  I am a huge fan of the old Hollywood musicals that I believe Baz Luhrman was trying to pay homage.  Unfortunately, it seemed more of an insult.  I can't imagine why anyone would have backed this debacle.

Review title: How many cliches can one film hold?
Review_body: Truly truly awful - as a movie it fails due a complete lack of coherent storyline. As an artfest it fails due to the most amount of cliches and hackneyed 1-second scenes I have ever seen. And as a musical it is without comparison as the lowest form of musical intelligence. Who ever thinks that putting together OTHER PEOPLES songs is artistic should listen to Jive Bunny. And whoever thinks that poetry could be allowed to consist of quoting Elton John or Bernie Taupin's song lyrics should listen to this movie in 6 months. And once more, whoever thinks that Nicole can lipsync should at least be grateful she didn't sing live. She cannot sing. Period. The characters are banal, without any substance or body and the movie effects are very amateurish.Possibly the worst movie I have ever seen.....

Review title: Pure Theatre at the cinema!! "spectacular spectacular"
Review_body:
This is a film I've been waiting all year to see and I wasn't disappointed. The visuals are just amazing. The emotional impact of music and song in a film has been missing for so long it's great to have it back with this amazing treat. The acting was great (though a little corny at times), the set designs left my jaw gaping open and the songs were 'spectacular spectacular', the modern twist made you want to sing along as you watched. Well done to Ewan and Nicole who can both sing brilliantly!!This is arty blockbuster at it's best and a film you can see again and again just due to the pace and beauty of the production, pure theatre on the cinema screen. I've been waiting for a long time to see a love story where there's actual chemistry between the leads, the emotion seemed throughly believable. I laughed, I cried and I wanted to see it again once it finished. A cult classic in the making!!
Thank you Baz Luhrmann for giving me a throughly enjoyable evening, Please make more films like this!! The musical is back with a bang (and feathers)!!***** out of ***** I'd give this film more if I could!!! this is definatly in my top 10 favorite films.

This movie is great art.  It revived my faith in the medium of film and it revived my faith in humanity.I went into it not caring much for Nicole Kidman and expecting that the anachronistic use of modern pop songs would be a travesty.  Boy, was I wrong, on both counts.  Kidman was utterly fantastic (she has got to win an Oscar!) and the use of pop songs was delightful.  Ewan McGregor?  Well, I liked him OK before, but he captured my heart in this.  He was beautiful and luminous.  Everyone was.  They let their lights shine.  That's thanks to Baz Luhrmann.  He helped them to open up and do the weird scary stuff, like singing (which was so moving that it brought me to tears many times).  Yes, the script was negligible but look what they did with it!  Compare, for instance, to "Phantom Menace", which was an exercise on how to degrade the talents of wonderful actors."Moulin Rouge" isn't a perfect film by any means -- there's a section in the middle that feels disconnected and choppy, and I wish there was more dancing shown -- but no great work of art is completely perfect.If this movie doesn't win a cartload of Oscars then there's no justice in the world.  But even if it doesn't, I'll still treasure it.  Like the best films of all time, it catapults you to a different universe and brings you back changed for the better.Another opinion: my husband, a musician who has played in so many musicals that he hates the genre (and almost never sees movies more than once), has seen it twice.  He thinks it's the best movie musical ever made.  We can't wait for the DVD to come out!

although this story is a story that has been told a million times, the way it is filmed is unique .. the use of camera movements and light in this movie astonished me more then Pearl Harbor did .. the music, setdressing and acting in this movie is an experience that stands above the story and makes this a movie to be loved by all .. this is a story about love that translates an emotion into a dreamworld we all want to be a part of .. this movie is not only a joker of the day .. it's a prince of the night..

Review title: Not a blockbuster, but a piece of art
Review_body: For starters, I love Moulin Rouge.  It gets a 10.Moulin Rouge does *not* possess a very interesting story.  It's trite. What's more, the foreshadowing of the plot is so blatant that "shadowing" is not really accurate.  However, the movie is exceedingly artistic, and that is how it succeeds.By using a well-known story, the essence of which being classic although overused throughout history, Baz alleviates himself from having to concentrate on plot.  The movie does not suffer from misunderstanding, from which many movies with intricate plot lines do.  As a result, he is able to pour his efforts into *how* the story is told rather than *what* the story is.  It is the means the artist employs, not his/her subject matter, that keeps art enduring over the years.  This is the reason that I view it as one of the best movies ever created.  Long after summer blockbusters and feel-good or PC critic-choices fade into the background, Moulin Rouge will still be memorable as a movie that pushed the limits, shattering illusions of how cinema and musicals should be created.The basic framework of the movie is highly original for film and highly artistic in itself: the echoing of drama with music, the direct links between dialogue and impending action (e.g. Zidler states they will rehearse tomorrow the scene when the "lovers are discovered" and promptly he discovers Christian and Satine's love affair), and the collage technique - pasting snippets from other compositions, both musical and cinematic.  For those with a knowledge of 20th century music, Moulin Rouge has many artistic similarities with Luciano Berio's _Sinfonia_, the third movement.Layered on this framework is the acting, which is impeccable.  The four main characters (Christian, Satine, Zidler, and the Duke) were cast perfectly, and their performances are interesting, fresh, and convincing.  Nicole finally has chosen a role where she can really explore her talents, and in Moulin Rouge we can finally see why she is a big name actress.  Richard Roxburgh and Jim Broadbent handily juggle their comic roles with their more serious characterizations.  But Ewan's performance really takes the cake. His character is one, which, in practically every incarnation, is the annoying, hopelessly naive, nauseatingly optimistic boy-next-door.  Yet, Ewan's performance is so genuine and fresh (yes, fresh!); I never once wished him ill.  Ewan took a usually distasteful character and made him lovable.The sets and costumes were stunning and vibrant only when they needed to be. And Baz's use of sepia backgrounds produced wonderful contrasts throughout, but particularly in the second half of the movie.  The lighting was used effectively to complement the mood of the scene, not simply to illuminate the set nor to establish the mood in its own right.  The editing was also very effective.  The quick cuts can be daunting, especially during the Can-Can sequence, but I believe they are used to great effect, allowing Baz to keep only the most convincing shots of a take.  The performances of the actors can be contributed as much to Baz's editing as the actors themselves. In addition, there were unusual camera angles, which cast an atypical view of a scene.  My favorite is the shot after Christian shouts at Toulouse to leave him alone.  A typical shot would be a tight close-up to show intensity.  But Baz instead shows Christian's entire body sitting rather lifeless in bed, which really illustrates Christian's true emotions - sadness, despair - rather than the quick and easy emotion of anger.In the end, Moulin Rouge is a work of art.  Fruitful debate will stem not from it's plot, but rather from more academic discussions of it's technique and form - how the movie *reinvents* the Orphean myth rather than qualities of the myth itself.  And for those that enjoy it, Moulin Rouge can be watched numerous times.  There is so much detail and self-reference - especially some intriguing flash-forwards -  that one can pick up on something new each viewing.As for advice, if you need an intriguing, suspenseful plot, you will probably not enjoy Moulin Rouge.  If, however, you can enjoy a movie solely for its artistic qualities, I believe you will enjoy it.  Nevertheless, I suggest that everyone view it at least once - if not twice to pick up things that one cannot notice the first time - because it is truly a movie different from anything else ever made.

In the short time since this movie opened, it has become one of my all time favorite films ever.  Moulin Rouge is fast, furious, and gorgeous.  It will take you from extreme comedy to extreme tragedy and all points in between. Not one member of the cast is lacking.  Ewan McGregor is incredible as an actor and a singer.  The same is to be said of Nicole Kidman.  Jim Broadbent and John Leguizamo also give standout performances.  The music is familiar, brand-new and completely brilliant all at the same time.  It is said of this movie that you will either love it or hate it.  And I agree with that.  But I think most people that gave it a real chance loved it.  It's an unforgettable movie experience.  Vive Le Moulin Rouge!

Review title: Visually stunning, magnificently crafted musical genius!
Review_body: As much as I loved this movie, it is a difficult one to decribe in words. Ewam McGregor takes great songs and makes them greater, when you expect little but for them to be butchered.  The speed changes in the film give it almost a roller coaster feel, propelling you through what you are not sure is a musical, or a spoof on musicals.  This is honestly a movie I was dragged to by my fiancee, and I didn't expect to even stay awake through it, much less enjoy it, but I found myself going back to see it again two days later.One of the most captivating films I have ever seen.  Thanks Baz.

I totally agree with all those other contributors who've heaped such lavish praise on this movie.  As a spectacle it was stunning, an assault on the senses, but I don't think I've ever come across a movie where the views of the critics are so polarised.  It's either one of the best films of all time or else it's total garbage.  When I saw it at least 6 people walked out.  I guess some people don't like weird movies, and let's face it this is a weird movie, it doesn't obey any of the rules, and some people are obviously uncomfortable with that.But I do have one big criticism, and that is Nicole Kidman's performance. I did not believe for one minute that Satine loved Christian. She was too cool, she was too distant, she could have been wondering how the hell she got involved in such a movie, but she was not in love.  I've asked myself several times whether that mattered in such a surreal film where style triumphs over everything, but I think it does.  Love is the message, this is a film about love and Baz Luhrman could have found an actress who looked as if she was mad about the boy.  Instead we got Kidman trying to be Marlene Dietrich.It was still wonderful, but it could have been almost perfect.

I feel keenly that "Hollywood" seems no longer able to produce ANYTHING on screen that can reach the discerning public.  This film -- was it a film?? or a video-taped hopeful for broadway?? -- the "singing" was just so -- just so flat, loud, and emotionless, reminding one of a b-grade and copycat off-broadway score ... and one should not even mention that it was totally out of era (don't tell the kids - they'll believe anything we show them at this point) ... I thought this film (movie seems a better word) gross and disgusting in every sense. I worry some that we had to allow Nicole Kidman a flaunt of her assets on screen just before and during her much hyped divorce from whats-his-name. Along with the recent throw up of a re-made Pearl Harbor, (see Tora, Tora, Tora for a much better propagandic rendition), I feel most strongly about avoiding anything that is made in the hills of hollywood at this point.  If they are worried about revenue, they won't be seeing my money for years to come -- dreadful stuff.  Look to cable and the independents, and don't forget about the Brits and Europe for what is really counting on film.  I think the US film (movie?) society has lost all its "brains" to the dot.coms at this point. Disgraceful .......

This is the way film is suppose to be:  cleaver, funny, beautiful and - above all - entertaining.  The set design was breath-taking, the acting devine, and the story timeless.  Not once did I find myself bored or annoyed.  Instead, I managed to go through the whole store of human emotions in a span of a couple of hours.  I haven't had this much fun in a movie theater in a long, long time.

Probably the most frenetic movie I have ever seen, fantastic visuals, gobsmacking performances, earthshattering sounds, and mesmerising music.You just cannot go wrong with this movie, if you dont like it, then your heart is dead...

Review title: How Wonderful Life is now this film is in the world!
Review_body: I loved almost every second of this movie, hopefully this film will reinvigorate the musical genre. It really is a fantastic experience. Watching the film reminds one why you first started to attend the movies. The acting although slightly over the top by some is perfectly suited to their roles. Nicole Kidman is very impressive in her role and seems to now be in complete control of her craft, delivering on the promise that she showed in "Eyes Wide Shut" and "To Die For". Ewan McGregor is also very fine, and they both deliver the goods admirably when it comes to the singing. The musical numbers are simply inspired with the Roxanne Tango, Ewan McGregor singing Your Song for the first time, and Like A Virgin being personal highlights. The film itself is very funny but you may find that the tone changes somewhat in the second half and you should prepare yourself for it, it definitely tugs the heartstrings a little bit. The early sequences are very dazzling and fast moving reminiscent of "Cabaret" whilst the I believe the plot I believe can be interpreted as being a modern day version of "the red shoes". The costumes and sets are very impressive and pleasing to the eye as is every other facet of the film. Director Luhrmann has shown great visual panache in the creation of this wondrous film and turned what was an audacious undertaking likely to be rubbish into the benchmark by which future musicals will be judged. Overall, this is the best film that I have seen this year and I would thoroughly recommend it to anyone who loves music, movies or life. 10/10

Before I saw this movie, I heard that you either love it or you hate it...I LOVE it!  I can understand why some people don't like it...after all, it wasn't anything like what I was really expecting (I hadn't looked into the summaries very much).  If you try to take it seriously, then you may become irritated with the use of late-20th century music in a film set in 1900. Or maybe you are offended by the parody of the Sound of Music (which happens to be my all time favorite movie) or the operatic rendition of Madonna's "Like a Virgin" or the medley of Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" with Fatboy Slim's "Because We Can" or John Lennon's "All You Need is Love" with Dolly Parton's "I Will Always Love You."  However, I challenge you to look beyond the dates and titles and just let the movie take you along for the incredible journey.  It's amazing how well it draws you into the atmosphere of the Moulin Rouge and, if you're like me, then when it's over, you will surprise yourself at just how into it you really were.  I was amazed by the overwhelming amount of emotion, intrigue, and dazzlement that I experienced while watching this film.  It captivated me more than any other recent movie.  It truly is a film that captures the essence of the Bohemian ideologies of truth, beauty, freedom, and above all else, love.  Watch this movie, and be reminded that "the greatest thing you'll ever learn is just to love and be loved in return."

Review title: love and be loved in returned
Review_body: Just for that simple yet amazingly true phrase the film is worth every second of it. I'm still in awe of the film, it has not been two hours since I have seen it and yet still here I am writing about it. It might sound like a simple process but until I remembered my password it took me countless minutes and at any minute I could have given up in writing this comment. Yet no password would stop me from writing about this film. Few films leave me feeling as magical as this one and it is only fair that I give back some of the inspiration, love and awe that it gave me. After seeing a film as wonderful as this I believe everything is possible. Especially LOVE. Each and every person that has taken their time to write a comment here knows exactly what I am talking about. The rest who write just to put the film down, well I don't think I even need to comment on them... lack of something to do is a very serious problem. As a teacher of mine says: Run don't walk...

This is an absolutely magnetic movie, pulling you into the story every second! The colors and music are magnificent. It seems a little frantic in the beginning, but stick with it and it's a great story, and Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman do an awesome job!

This was the first movie I saw in the theater in about a year.  And this is definitely a movie you need to see on the big screen.  I felt like I was watching a Broadway show (at substationally less cost).  It is "just another love story" but it's not the plot that Spectacular, it's the entire movie - the music, the acting, the humor, etc.  Well worth your money.

Have just watched this brilliant movie on DVD through a projector and Dolby digital sound system. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone but have to add that unless you actually see it in a movie theater or on a large projector screen, it would most definitely lose its impact.It was like watching a roller coaster ride and the two leads, Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, were wonderful to watch. The blend of modern music was one of the aspects that I loved as a lot of the songs were old favorites presented in a different way.I cannot stress enough that this movie would not meet your expectations if watched on a small screen but the lead actors are a joy to watch and Nicole certainly proved that she can act, not to mention sing!

Review title: All Form, No Content: A disaster
Review_body: This film is all form and no content.  Moulin is an MTV style music video at heart featuring good music, fast editing, color, costume, cartoon-like characters, and weak and dreamy love story.  Moulin should have stayed true to its MTV genre and limited itself to 15 minutes in length.Beyond being a well produced music video the film failed miserably in every measure of a full-length feature. The story line was weak.  There was no chemistry between Kidman and the male lead.  This lifeless story is set amidst a backdrop of inane cartoon-like characters, and a twirling colorful headache of dancing and music. Extending the video format to more than 2 hours is a dismal failure.  If I were distributing this film I would do the decent thing and include the following warning label on the marquee: "This film is dull and tormenting, proceed at own risk".

Review title: A sensational explosion of passion and postmodernism!
Review_body: This film is not only brilliantly aware of its own fictionality but inspires you to go about what you do with passion. We should all put as much work into our projects as Baz Luhrmann does. Every single person involved in the production of the film was absolutely stunning. 'Moulin Rouge' blew me away with its whirl of colour, sound and emotion.

This film has absolutely no redeeming features. Even Ewan McGregor, a man who can bring even the lowest type of script and make it watchable (think A Life Less Ordinary). Baz Luhrman is a person who should never be allowed to write a script or have access to any form of writing materials. I can not even start to tell you how bad this film is. A fairly good cast gone completely to waste!

It has been said many times (here at this comments board as well as other places) that MR is one of those films you either love or hate. There is no real 'middle of the road' option here. For that reason alone, any serious film buff should watch it and make up his/her own mind. Take it or leave it - MR is an important film.Personally I took one long look at it. And another long look. And yet another. I was brought up watching classic MGM musicals as well as MTV. I may well be the target audience. MR's synthesis of old-fashioned musical magic (just note the ensemble work of the "Spectacular, Spectacular" scene) and what some critics have called 'postmodernism' (such as the Bollywood-meets-Marilyn Monroe scene) works for me. It truly does work even if the film sounds absolutely nuts on paper.Visually it is a feast. I cannot remember the last time I have seen such a beautiful, well-designed film. Aurally it is a feast too - I'm not going to give away all the delightful musical references, but some very inspired montages made me simultaneously laugh and gawk.However, the main reason it works so well is because of the actors. Nicole Kidman has been singled out in many reviews - and she is excellent and manages to lose her Icy Queen demeanour - but the film is an ensemble piece. Every tiny part is cast to perfection - at first I was admittedly not sure about the villaineous Duke, but I suddenly realised he was a sinister version of Cecil Vyse of "A Room with a View". It made perfect sense. Still, I do feel the need to single out Ewan McGregor. Baz Luhrman has described McGregor as an injection of warm blood into the film. It is easy to tell. McGregor is clearly having the time of his life dancing and singing his heart out. t puts a huge smile on my face.Usually I'm reluctant to give high praise to films - but to me, MR was a clearcut 10. It is a homage to the possibilities of cinema, it is a good-spirited celebration of The All Good Things In Life and finally it is simply just a fantastic film. But go see it for yourself and make up your own mind.

For all of the enthusiasm surrounding this movie, I found it to contain really very little substance. While many movie-goers will no doubt entertain themselves by pointing out the identity of all of the songs pilfered for use in this movie, they will hopefully not fail to overlook the fact that this schticky ploy, coupled with the uncomfortable cinematography and editing spearheaded by Baz Luhrmann, really makes the movie more annoying than endearing.Additionally, careful viewers will note a remarkably strong similarity in plot to another recent, far-superior movie, which I will neglect to name so as not to provide a spoiler. However, the aforementioned, nameless film is much better written, is more clever and intelligent, and really blows this movie out of the water.Still, much can be said for the colorful, vibrant set design, as well as the masterful performances by John Leguizamo and Ewan McGregor. Throw in a perma-beautiful Nicole Kidman, and you have a movie that might be worth renting. But if you've figured out which much-celebrated movie I've referred to earlier in my review, I would recommend it much more highly.

Some people will say that this movie is haphazard, that it rushes through things, or that it's just plain stupid. I say that some of those people should not have come in the first place - if you can't stand the heat get out of the kitchen. :-) The others ... well, I think you've got to remember what it is to love.This movie shows us all what real love is like. It's true, the story could be fleshed out a bit more, but then the movie would have been over three hours and that'd be a bit long. It's the perfect length. The two leads are wonderful. Nicole Kidman shows a range that's surprising, and Ewan McGregor, both looks and sounds like the angel he's supposed to be.Most of all, the music. That's what everyone's talking about. I for one think it worked. Like "Tango de Roxanne" - its gravelly undertone and sexy, rough beat, plus McGregor's high, clear background vocals. It's enough to send chills down your spine. Or the "Elephant Love Medley." Christian, McGregor's character, is exactly the type to quote high-flown 70s pop to his lady love. And it works.Christian, in conclusion, is the man every woman wants on some level. Satine is the woman who every woman would like to be. (In terms of principles, everyone - not lifestyle.) Outstanding. Just outstanding.

The best movie I have seen all year, and one of the best films ever made. This movie embodies all the charm artistry and flavor you should expect to see, if you see this movie you will not be disappointed. It will enchant and delight you from scene to scene.

I am so pleased that I didn't go to see this film at the cinema.I would have been distressed to have paid a fiver to see one of the worst films ever made. Truly awful. Don't bother wasting your time watching this.The music was anachronistic. The story was non-existent. The only highlight was Nicole Kidman. The only reason I thought about watching this rubbish was because she was in it.If this is ever on the TV again, I'll find something else to watch.

Review title: Completely its own film, and very good!
Review_body: Some movies are so unique that they seem to be the creation of a single mind, a single artistic vision, even if this isn't actually the case.  Such films would include Citizen Kane, Rear Window, The Draughtsman's Contract, the recent Oh Brother Where Art Thou? and, now, Moulin Rouge.  Did I love it?  Yes, in spite of the frequent use of quick-cut editing (cut to new viewpoint every .5 seconds).  Will most people love it?  I can't say, but I doubt it.However, with a movie like this, no one could have told me if I would like it, for no one knows me quite that well.  And if I hadn't seen it for myself now, in a theater, I would have seen it for the first time on a TV set, and (after my dazzled mind settled down a bit) kicked myself.If it helps, the trailer gives an accurate idea of the main plot and artistic style, but doesn't hint at the farcical humor, mostly in the movie's first third.  However, it only gave a hint of the total impact the movie would have on me.

This film was getting a lot of good reviews but I didn't think it was for me.  I didn't like the directors other films.  When I rented this film, I almost turned it off after the first 10 minutes thinking I was right about not liking it.  Then it just grabbed me and wouldn't let me go.  Once Ewan and Nicole met, I was hooked.  I couldn't believe they did there own singing.  I watched the closing credits three times in slow motion just the check it out.  I couldn't get the music out of my head.  I had to run down the buy the DVD two days later just so that I could skip to the music. Two weeks ago I saw it for the first time, and I have seen it in it's whole about 3 more times now.  WOW, sums it up best.

Review title: This is a musical for people who don't like musicals.
Review_body: This was easily one of the best movies I've seen in years. Rarely do movies have a visual force capable of stunning you into rapt silence; and even more rare are films able to further this with a soundtrack that can move you and ensnare you as well, if not better, than the images. Yet some how, through genius, magic, luck, or some combination, Moulin Rouge has managed to do both. In truth Moulin Rouge is a fusion of two fabulous films into one. A film of images capable of conveying meaning without dialog or music, and a film which you could feel and understand with out needing to see it. Much effort was obviously spent on both the visual and audio aspects of this film, and by choosing not to focus on one over the other, and sacrifice the songs for the story or vice versa, the filmmakers were able to make a truly unique, modern musical which those of us who have hated musical since childhood could enjoy. Moulin Rouge is a blend of old, established techniques with innovative experimental ones, resulting in a movie which could only have been made in our time, yet which has a classic feel. The acting is wonderful, the mixture of modern songs is ingenious, and the cinematography is at times simply amazing. The end result is a stunning film with unbelievable performances; a cinematic experience that people will be loving, analyzing and trying to imitate for year.

Review title: Were you people watching the same thing?
Review_body: What is the deal with this film? Over acting, over the top, in your face and obnoxious directing makes this film one of the year's worst. At times it wanted to be a good film and that is what people are liking. They WANTED it to be better than it was. At times, it could have been great, but Luhrmann's direction is all over the place, the script has pacing problems and the acting is laughable (save a fine performance from McGregor). The film made my brain hurt and I don't understand how this thing will get Oscar Nominations. The film is simply forferdelig!

Review title: Too boring to even be a campy cult flick
Review_body:
I recognize that everyone has different tastes but how can this film rank amongst imdb.com user's Top 250 of all time?  There seems to be quite a few negative reviews from users on this site...I felt so embarrassed for Nicole Kidman in her first scene with Ewan McGregor in the elephant.  Probably the stupidest "Three's Company"-style innocent-discussion-mistaken-as-sexual-innuendo situation I've ever seen. Did this film have to beat me over the head with "the greatest thing you'll ever learn..." and the 4 tenets of the bohemian way of life.  God, I get it already! Love is great."Your Song" is beautiful.  But let's face it; wouldn't you rather listen to Elton John sing it?  Sorry Ewan, your singing just doesn't cut it.  As for the scenes in the club, does loud driving dance beat make for a good musical?  I'm not a fan of musicals but I'm afraid that was probably the best part of this completely uninteresting "love story".
If the insipid attempts at humor hadn't petered out toward the second half of the movie I could see this becoming a "Rocky Horror" style campy cult flick, but it's just too boring.  My ratings -- songs: 5; love story: 2; general storyline: 1.  Simply terrible.

After seeing Moulin Rouge I could only think Baz Luhrmann wanted to make the most spectacular, spectacular musical ever. And the only way to do this is on celluloid, because the music, the sets, the effects, everything is just too darn 'big' to perform on stage. A masterfully crafted film, every second must have taken careful planning and shooting. This film is a rollercoasterride of emotions, it starts of very high paced and comedial (is that a word?), then it becomes grand and romantic and ends in deep, deep tragedy. I was absolutely thrilled! Fantastic music, I bought the soundtrack the day after. If this film doesn't get the academy award for best music, than I'll eat my top hat!I voted 9 out of 10

Where did the idea come from that singing the first line of as many different songs as possible constitutes a "Medley?"  Or that using, out of context, the most popular hits from Rodgers & Hammerstein and other great song writers is acceptable?
