I was constantly hoping that they would complete at least one piece of music besides "The Sound of Music" and that Elton John thing; but no, they kept reciting bits and snatches of recent (and not so recent) pop songs ad infinitum - I wanted to tear my hair out after hearing nothing but sound bites of old favorites for what seemed like five minutes without a break.  And the Folies Bergere & Busby Berkeley cliches - this is not a movie for anyone with musical theater taste of ANY kind, only musical illiterates could like this piece of crap.  Not that Ewan McGregor or Nicole Kidman were bad... they did far more than then material asked for.  Also John Leguizamo was better than perfect as Toulouse Latrec, if one can use such a phrase.

When i saw it had 8,3 stars out of 10 in the ISONEWS vote, i had 2 see it. Now when i had i just have one thing 2 say!! HELP!! One of the worst movies this year. Stay away from it if possible!!!!!!! It's a god damn musical. The details was great but thats all in the movie that was, except mayB the different version of known famous songs.

A tragic tale of love in Shakespearean caliber, Moulin Rouge grabs a hold of your senses and never lets you go.  Moulin Rouge starts off at a frantic pace, in which you're thrusted from 0-60 within a blink of the eye. Beautifully directed by Baz Luhrmann, one can see his style from past works of Romeo & Julliet and Strictly Ballroom.  We all know that Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman can act, but surprisingly they can sing also.  This is a tale in which all hopeless romantics can enjoy.

My partner and I went to this film expecting, at the very least, to have an enjoyable time and, based on what we'd heard about it, possibly a 'life-changing experience'.This is the first film for many years where we both decided to walk out before the end.What is it that makes this film so appealing to so many and yet a complete anathema to others? Our taste is broad, we give most cinema a chance to engage and enthrall us, but this just left us looking at our watches and thinking of better things to do.Lavish in production it certainly is, with some clever cinematographic tricks that George Melies himself would have loved, but all this cannot make up for the emptiness of the storyline, the dodgy editing, the lacklustre choreography and the butchered songs.Why do people think Ewan McGregor has a good voice? He hasn't! Are people exposed to so much bad singing nowadays that they've lost all point of reference? Even Nicole Kidman's songs were dubbed in the scenes we saw before our exit.Maybe we missed the point of the whole thing, maybe by not staying for the end we missed some crucial and 'life-changing' finale. Judging by the comments of others like us - who thought this one of the worst films they'd seen for a long time - I don't think so. Even with all the hype, a week after opening the cinema was only about half full on a Saturday night - don't be frightened to stand up and be counted all you other Moulin dissidents!

Going to see to  Moulin Rouge on it's opening night was a night i will remember. Baz Luhrman should be praise for his baby. People may have thought a movie musical was a sure firer flop. Also critics began to doubt it when it was delayed so many times and had to move to different places to be flimed.The acting was excellent. I was a huge ewan mcgregor fan before the movie came out so i always knew he could sing but, Nicole Kidman? She blew me away! I think that the song "Some Day I'll Fly Away" was one of the most touching parts of that movie. And Jim Broadbent! Bravo Bravo! he was amazing! And Like a Vrigin! HAHA!I smell some oscars indeed. Best Actor for Ewan McGregor, Best Actress for Nicole Kidman, Best Supporting actor for Jim Broadbent, Best Set Design, Best Costumes, Best Song for "Come What May" and of course best movie and director.I predict they will all be nomanited but, i'll like to see the movie that can top it!

Although when the movie started I felt it is a strange one , but as the movie rolled on I loved it, I loved the romantic scenes ,loved Nicole acting and loved the songs. One thing that I don't get the meaning of it ,is why the author used too much old (well known songs).

This movie taught me many things including NEVER TRUST REVIEWS!!!! Most reviews of the Moulin Rouge said that Baz Luhrmann pushed this movie too much. I thought that it was perfect. This movie is high on color and high on energy. "You will leave the theater feeling exhausted" People magazine said. This is completely false. You will leave singing your favorite tunes of the movie hoping that one day you will be as much in love as Satine (Kidman) and Christian (McGregor). (Well, thats what I felt) This is a must-see for everyone!! This movie has it all: love, suspense, tragedy and above all MUSIC!!!! Go see Moulin Rouge for a spectacular movie experience.

This film was yet more proof of Baz Luhrmann's great vision in music and movie-making. His music is so deep, you can't help but be drawn into it. I believe this movie has set a new precedent for musical films. I don't know about the rest of you, but I hope with all of my heart that Baz Luhrmann keeps making films and beautiful (to put it mildly) music. I also hope with all of my heart that someone out there keeps Ewan MacGregor singing. Why did it take so long to get that gorgeous voice and man out there in this kind of role?!?! His singing gives me the shivers (yummy kind). Keep it up, Ewan MacGregor! Another good one, but not as good as Moulin Rouge!, is "Down With Love." Ewan's acting in that, too, is delicious!

Review title: See this show, before it shuts down!!
Review_body: 'Moulin Rouge' is probably one of the best films I've seen all year. It's the cinematic equivalent to being tied to a four-poster bed, having your eyes pinned open, ala 'clockwork orange' and having a mixture of honey, sugar and vaseline smeared over your eyeballs whilst Nirvana and Elton John let off fireworks just behind your ears. Lovely!! The screen chemistry between Obi Wan and Kidman is hot, hot, hot. They can both sing (Ewan struggles sometimes but I think that just adds to the movies charm) If I've got any criticism it's that, the film is predictable and, like Jim Broadbents paunch, it does start to sag a bit towards the end. In all though, I thoroughly recommend it, for pure escapist entertainment. Finally, I've got to applaud Mcgregor and Kidman for tackling these parts, it's this kind of diversity that sets them apart as two of the best actors around at the moment. Hats of to Baz Lurman's outrageously over the top direction. Every scene could be framed and placed lovingly above your fireplace. It really is *cliche alert* a rollercoaster ride of a film. Get on board!! See this show, before it shuts down!!!

Review title: About as classy and dazzling as Skankilera & Lil' Kim in the video
Review_body: I can't remember the last time I saw a movie this odious.  I appreciate musicals; I am not opposed to vulgarity or exaggeration; I like Bowie and Madonna as much as the next guy.  But after being barraged with this film's raunchy idiocy for about two hours, I was entirely desensitized to the costumes, the tolerable singing, the heroes' predicament.  Not even its mockery quotient made viewing it a worthwhile experience -- I was far too irritated to enjoy a good laugh.On the bright side, watching this atrocity will likely have the effect of making the other movie we rented last night seem brilliant in comparison. That movie is Legally Blonde.  In fact, this movie makes the film I had previously held to be the worst of all time look rather brilliant . . . that would be Urban Menace, in which Snoop Dogg plays "an insane urban preacher bent on revenge."  Oddly enough, though, that movie earned 1.8 stars on this website, and is #50 on IMDB's list of the 100 most poorly ranked films. Moulin Rouge, on the other hand, earned a respectable 8.1 at the time of this review.  Perhaps some scheming 12-year-old girl with a crush on Ewan McGregor wrote hundreds of reviews under different user names, and stuffed the ballot box?  I can only hope so.In retrospect I see that the horrifying spectacle that so offended me last year -- that is, Christina Skankilera, Lil' Kim, Pink and Mya prancing around in teddies and hotpants and wrecking a reasonably good LaBelle song -- was perfectly appropriate.

Too many people will try to convince others of the greatness of this movie. I say, just walk in sit down, and let go of all your reservations. Whether or not you think this is "your kind" of movie, it is worth the $5, $7.50, $9, or $10 you may spend on it just to see a little of another person's imagination. It is a rare thing indeed to be able to look at something and know you are seeing exactly what the person who made it was seeing. Give in to the campiness, give in to the wild colors, give in to the amazing LOVE they share. GO SEE MOULIN ROUGE!

I was very surprised.  I was coerced into seeing this movie by various friends.  I thought I would hate it.  After seeing the video of the "Lady Marmalade" song, I was completely turned off to the notion of seeing the movie.  I really liked the movie, and am very glad that I saw it on the big screen.  In fact, I saw it as part of a friend's film class, and he said he was going to show the first three reels after his night class, and I went back to see the first part again.  The first hour of that movie was one of the most spectacular things I have seen on film.  I would urge anyone to see this movie.  I will agree that it is not for everyone, but one may be surprised by it like I was.  Since it is a musical, you have to give it a chance to be what it is.  People don't break into song like that, but it works here, like all good musicals.  It also goes from campy to serious to funny to sad, all in the space of a few minutes.  Most films don't seems to do this effectively.  This one does.  Again, I would urge you to see it if you haven't already.

This movie is so great!  The music, dancing, story-keeps you glued to the screen.  This is the first Nicole Kidman movie that didn't make me sick. Now I completely love her and can't wait to see what's next.  Ewan McGregor should really have his own record contract!  I would recommend this movie to anyone.  Everyone needs to see it!  A great modern-day musical!

Review title: Get through the first 10 min. and you'll be in for a fabulous ride!
Review_body: Although the beginning of this film has turned off many viewers with its frenetic dance number with glitter and can-can dancers, if you will sit through the first ten minutes you will truly be in for a fabulous entertainment experience.  The way Luhrman has woven together a heart-wrenching love story with contemporary music and incredible design elements carries you away into a fantastical world.  It is set in 1899, but because Luhrman isn't obsessed with making it the traditional "period" it enables the audience to identify and suspend their disbelief. The well-trained, but not overly-crafted voices of Kidman and McGregor are refreshing.  The songs serve as an extension of their emotion, not a showcase of talent.  AS the story soars forward you find yourself laughing and crying, hoping and wondering at the characters and what they choose. It is a beautiful story, give it a chance!
An EXCELLENT picture.  Went into it quite ambivalent, but walked out a convert.  Never seen one of Baz Luhrmann's films until now and am quite anxious to check out Romeo + Juliet.

This movie blows the old paradigms away. Boy meet girl/boy loses girl/ yadda yadda. Now do it as Salvadore Dali would have. After this, who but a preteen could sit though Grease or even Singing in the Rain. It destroys the old concept of a musical, but it may also set the bar so high that no one will ever make a serious musical again.It happened in art (painting), where all that is left is retreads and attempts to shock. This may be the last musical worth seeing for quite some time.

Admittedly; I approached this film reluctantly. "Historic/Romantic musical describing the short yet passionate fling of a writer and a cancan dancer, that stars a Scottish and Australian duo as the leads in a very French film that uses well known songs to create an artistic thriller?"- I thought.But don't miss out on this fantastic viewing experience. It hits every single note and it is just amazing.First it introduces you to the simple life of bohemian Christian and then it throws you headfirst into the promiscuous antics that take place in the Moulin Rouge, the courtier (Satines) place of work and residence. Then it reels you into a tale of epic love when these two worlds meet, through the young and talented pair (Christian and Satine). All is blissful until complications ignite, which are initially hilarious but ultimately heartbreaking.This film is a roller-coaster of genres; you'll be crying so heavily you won't believe that you were rolling around in hysterics ,mere scenes ago. Artistic, tragic, hilarious, musical and historical; This film is pleasing on so many levels that just watching it wont be enough, you'll have to Google it and download all the songs to your iPod. Forget R&B, Come What May and the Elephant Love Medley will be dominating your playlist.UNBEATABLE FLAWLESSNESS.

Review title: What a romantic dream of a movie
Review_body: I'm not surprised that so many (not all) men don't appreciate this film. I'm not surprised that they obsess over the fact that they've heard the music before, over camera angles and other minutia.  Many men are like that. They can't let go and embrace sentiment.  Most are simply not capable.  How any ordinary movie goer or critic could see this movie and not be moved by the intensity of Christian and Satin's feelings for one another is beyond my comprehension.  When I saw the film, I was flabbergasted at how much attention had been paid to complaining about unimportant trifles.  Shocked that so many had proclaimed that Christian and Satin had no chemistry, I nonetheless sat enraptured whenever they were on screen together.  That so many could have watched this and felt nothing for the two lovers is a sad sign of just how jaded young people have become in this day and age.  It's SAD.  It's not surprising, though.  Critics panned "It's a Wonderful Life." What do they know?Ewan McGregor is a romantic the likes of which I haven't seen onscreen in many a year.  I thought I was jaded until I saw this film. What a voice on that man!!  I was thinking, "Oh my goodness, that's Renton the toilet boy singing like Harry Connick, Jr.!!"   The girls beside me were swooning whenever he sang, as was I.  What a perfect wide-eyed innocent. That this actor can convincingly portray characters as diverse as Mark Renton and Christian is a testament to his phenomenal talent.   There aren't many actors who are his equal, and Nicole's star power should certainly be elevated by her charming performance.  What a cutie she is!!  One can understand why Christian was so captivated by her.As for the rest of the movie, what is everyone complaining about?  It was a wild, dizzying, gaudy, decadent spectacle of a ride--as Baz intended it to be.  This world was intended to be surreal to the extreme.  It wasn't meant to accurately reflect 1899 Paris.  Of course it wasn't!!! So you get a little dizzy, so what?  The ride was wild and the reworked music was a hoot. Let go and *enjoy*.  Are you all grumpy old men?   It's not often a movie stays with you like this.  It's the first truly great film of the year. Bravo Ewan, Nicole, Richard Roxborough and Jim Broadbent.  A 9 out of 10. (Okay, that one point I took off is a concession to the fact that even *I* got a little too dizzy in some places.  Switch to decaf, Baz. LOL!!)  But that's okay.

Thank you Baz, for bringing music, excitement & above all..."Love" back to the big screen!  Your "Moulin Rouge" movie is the best I've seen in 20 years!!!  Wow!  What terrific performances by Nicole Kidman, Ewan McGregor, et all!  My fingers are crossed, in hopes that your movie wins ALL the upcoming awards...especially Oscar's "BEST PICTURE", "BEST DIRECTOR", "BEST EVERYTHING"!!!  It's very much deserved!!!  Bravo!!!  Keep'em comin'!

I thought that this movie was another Hollywood offering; another weepy love story that I'd discard from my head as soon as the final credits roll up.I was never more wrong.From the moment the opening credits were presented - for how else do you describe it? A little man conducting an invisible orchestra with so deep a passion that you cannot help think it as ridiculous, the sombre opening, then the sudden jolt when time line is reversed, back to where it all began. And scenes after scenes edited faster than you can catch them - you'd think this was some sort of bad cinematic decisions they had made in the cutting room.But this movie got away with it, because it was a perfect fit for the whole scenario: I've never seen anything like it before, and like a child looking at a new specimen, I stared and stared and tried to take it all in as much as I could. It was chaotic to the extreme. Whoopi Goldberg said it succinctly during the Acadamy Awards: "I guess Moulin Rouge! just directed itself." It was a compliment, because I cannot imagine how did Baz Luhrmann direct such a feast for the mind and soul without breaking the whole story.In short, this is the revival of musical in the grandest scale ever.

I loved this film ... the first part with the digital "fly-by" zoom-ins was a load of fun ... the parodies were right on key ... the "justification of the musical" scene in the elephant room was a laugh riot ... i expected a little more from the sad ending ... but all-in-all i would say that if DIDN'T plan to see this one ... bite-the-bullet ... i think you'll enjoy it...

What else can you say?   -- It's amazing to look at, visually.-- It's a completely original & downright brilliant concept.-- It's wonderfully performed by everyone on the screen.-- The musical (re)interpretations are simply thrilling.I have a feeling this will be the first DVD that I actually WEAR OUT from over use!

Passion, glitz comes alive in this beautiful love story. Ewan McGregor plays lovable and innocent writer name Christian hoping to fall in love, while meeting gorgeous Satine played by Nicole Kidman. Their love affair is filled with passion, but the Duke wants Satine all to himself. With a decision to chose the Moulin Rouge or Love. A mind-blowing film with wonderful acting, Ewan and Nicole are outstanding together. The song Come with May comes alive and is a lovely piece of music. Leaving the viewers in a aw. A must see movie if you're a fan of either Nicole or Ewan. Not only there acting ability showcase wonderfully but their singing voices are top notch for actors.

Review title: Thank you for creating something so spectacular.
Review_body: Phenomenal. Thank you to Baz and the cast and crew for such a phenomenal creation. Ewan McGregor- you have just become my new favorite leading man. Baz- to you and your wife- please continue with these kinds of films- they truly are life changing pieces for us. And I am so happy to see a musical in the new milennium do so well.

This film just took my breath away! everything about it is stunning! faultless performances from the 2 leads, who suprisingly both have great voices. Perfect direction from Baz lurman, wonderful uses of the songs, such as the hilarius 'like a virgin'!!!!! a masterpeice. A love story you will fall in love with. stunning sets and costumes, hilarius in parts and very very moving. 10/10 a must see, the best movie since the shawshank redemtion!

Review title: Truth, Love, Beauty all exist in this film
Review_body: A love story in musical form, an operatic tragedy, a biting comedy, a riot and whirlwind of color and emotion, an eclectic mix of the old and new, and you only have to pay $5 to see it.  Nicole Kidman stars as the stunningly beautiful Diamond of the Moulin Rouge, cybical and money grubbing with a Dark secret.  Enter Ewan MacGregor, a penniless writer with "big talent"...  An Evil Duke and the connsummate showman, Harold Zigler have their own parts to play and either bring the lovers together or keep them apart...  If anything else, SEE THIS MOVIE.  Words cannot suffice to describe the emotional toes you will have to this film.

Review title: One of the greatest films of all time!
Review_body: Moulin Rouge! is in my opinion one of the greatest films ever made and I have never felt so strong about a movie. This story is about truth, beauty, freedom; but above all things, this story is about love. The movie is a classic for all times - It brings to light the hopes of all the dreamers in the world. The movie uses such splendid music to express the beautiful feeling of love. The movie is about love and it makes you fall in love! If you're a girl you are charmed by the smile of Ewan McGregor and if you're a guy you dive right into the eyes of Nicole Kidman. If you think they're ability to act is wonderful, they're singing is even better! I recommend you see the movie. If you don't like it the first time you see it, watch it again until you understand it. Nothing is greater than love, "Love is like Oxygen, all you need is love!"

Review title: The whole is better than its parts
Review_body: For me the film itself overpowered the actors to the extent that they appeared to be struggling to get out from under.Even so I found that I was moved by the story,which is the universal one and would quite likely be moving however it is presented. As an Australian it was good to see so many Australian actors.Did I imagine it or did I get a glimpse of Graham Kennedy? I certainly do not wish to put people off seeing the film.

Review title: no, no, no, no, no, no, no!
Review_body: What are you people thinking??   A touching love story??  Good singing?  Good ACTING???  It was a disaster!!None of the actors have a chance to act at ALL.  Notice the sound effects? It was meant to be cartoonish, yet the very worst Loony Tunes cartoon has more style and sophistication than this film ... and you can empathize with the characters more!The use of contemporary songs is tacky, overdone, half-baked and badly executed; the voices of McGregor and Kidman are doctored to boost up their obviously sadly lacking vocal chords.Even if you accept that this film is MEANT to be unrealistic and "spectacular spectacular", it still fails to engage even on that level. Jurassic Park wasn't meant to have a great plot, but at least you could follow the superficial character motivations!  NONE of this film makes any sense -- nothing follows even the most basic logic or progression!This film is horrible, and is ultimately very VERY boring ... for all those "escapetivists" out there, if THIS is good, then my question is, what could possibly be worse?

I went into this movie expecting to love it.... and it still surprised me. I also went w/3 guys who grumbled for the most part, but they liked it so much that I say it again w/one of them and had another one complain b/c he didn't get to see it again in the theater.  Can't wait 'til it comes out on DVD.

This movie isn't perfect, although few movies are.  Many people think Baz Luhrman's work is too odd and out of the box to enjoy, but that's just because Romeo + Juliet was so horrible.  Well, anything you held against Baz, forget about it.  Moulin Rouge is an excellent movie.  It is odd, and definately outside of the box, but it's the closest to perfect I've ever seen in a movie.  The music is so wonderful, you can instantly tell what the characters are feeling because it's familiar music!  Instead of writing a whole array of new songs, Baz just included the characters singing famous songs.  That may sound cheesy, but it works amazingly well.  Of all movies I've seen, none have portrayed true love this well.  In our modern world of one-night stands and divorces, it'll seem corny, but if you watch with an open mind, you'll see how perfect love is embodied in Moulin Rouge (ironic, considering the movie is about a brothel turned theater).  There's not much more I can say that hasn't been said already.  Just make sure you see it, preferably in theaters.10/10

Review title: A pathetic pastiche of half-baked ideas
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is a massive waste of time and money, and you should waste neither of yours on it.It is all at once juvenile, under developed, terribly scripted, poorly acted, woefully unfunny, singularily unsexy and, most importantly of all, hideously directed by someone who, time and time again, demonstrates that he doesn't know when to take his foot off the accelerator.What constantly amazes me is that such ridiculous out of control rubbish as this is seen as an example of some sort of new cinema. It isn't. It's just bad cinema. Baz Lurhmann has, like lots of other ambitious amateurs, a sort of "horror vacui". He has absolutely no comprehension of what to leave out, so he just throws it all in an attempt to cover up the fact that he doesn't know what he is doing.Please, please, please if you enjoyed this swill, watch the following as some sort of remedial treatment course to see what the TRUE masters of glorious excess are capable of. Watch Busby Berkeley. Watch Vincente Minelli. Watch Ken Russell (anyone who sniggers at that suggestion yet can still embrace Lurhmann is kidding themselves). Watch Dennis Potter. Watch Bob Fosse. Watch (selected) Alan Parker. Don't accept pale imitations!!!Above all, probably the biggest crime of this film is what could have been. The milieu is so fantastic that to have it vandalised in such a mediocre way is truly heartbreaking.

Review title: This film has run away with my heart
Review_body: Despite what people have said about this movie, I am going to be steadfast and say that I LOVED this movie!.  The shrill camp keeps the plot amusing while the drama keeps it interesting by giving the movie chops.  This "rhapsodic celebration of a cliche" is absolutely wonderful and as a future music major, I thought that Nicole Kidman's and Ewan McGregor's singing was exceptional for the role.  (Kudos to the two of them for toughing it out and learning how to carry a tune along with my heart).  The characters Satine and Christian portrayed by Ms. Kidman and Mr. McGregor were extraordinary works that made me feel what they felt(In my opinion, all characters in all movies should do this).  The slap-stick "drama" of the Bohos, the gregariousness of Harold Zidler, and the sniveling wickedness of the Duke only add to the texture of the film.  I encourage anyone with a song in their heart to see this movie, and to buy the soundtrack right afterwards. Suggestion to Baz Luhrmann:  Make a second cd with all of the orchestral accompaniment and other left out misc. music on it.  I'm sure everyone wants a copy of Zidler's and the Duke's rendition of "Like a Virgin"!All in all, this movie is on my personal top ten list as it should be on anyone else's.

This movie, like its show-within-a-show, is spectacular in the original sense of the word.  It is a visual spectacle unlike anything else in recent memory.  Baz Luhrman is to be commended for pushing the boundaries of mainstream American film.  Regardless of any other qualities, this accomplishment alone makes this movie a must-see for film buffs.Luhrman is a risk-taking filmmaker if there ever was one, and as such he is bound to make a few mistakes.  The movie drags at the end, unable to keep up the fast-cut, MTV-style frantic pace of the first two-thirds.  McGregor's character, while inherently likeable, is perhaps not such a great writer, as his narration grows increasingly cliched and saccharine.  Nevertheless, McGregor and Kidman have created characters that the audience cares about and will root for, and so it is not difficult to stick with the film through its flaws.The use of popular songs, often in unexpected ways, is arresting and sometimes laugh-out-loud funny.  This humor is a strength of the movie, as this film would have fallen flat on its face had it taken itself too seriously.  The music is done very well with sharp choreography and surprisingly good--even excellent--vocals.  In particular, the 'Roxanne' sequence is magnificently performed and edited.While there are moments in which 'Moulin Rouge' flounders, it more than makes up for it in its visual allure and boundary-pushing style.

Review title: The film is the most amazing film we've seen this century! An indescribable blend of music, fantasy, gripping reality of love and life, and an almost accurate portrayal of love...
Review_body: I have seen this film several times since it's opening, and, if finances and time allowed, would see it several more.  It's an amazing look at the beauty, freedom, truth, and, above all things, love, as the advertisements describe it.  Nicole and Ewan give their masterpiece performances here, being a triple threat, and it's a vehicle that showcases both talents' more than their past projects.  I wasn't a particular fan of the director until I saw this one, but will now follow his career.  I know this isn't exactly a review, just some gushing at a film I'm in awe of.  I couldn't recommend this movie high enough. Cheers!

Review title: Amazing! Should be required viewing for... anyone!
Review_body: This was one of the most amazing films I have ever seen!  A feast for the ears and eyes.  I am trying to coerce the world into seeing this film!  Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman prove that they can SING!  Often called a cross between "Rocky Horror Picture Show" and "Titanic," it is really true. Destined to be a cult classic.  So few films can successfully pull off such a sharp shift in tone.  The first 45 minutes or so is a complete farce, high camp.  Then it slowly down shifts until the end is deep tragedy.  And yet it works.  The music, the costumes, the performances, the story, the script, the visuals... it all works!!  It is almost like seeing a theatrical production. The film opens and closes with the opening and falling of a stage curtain, and some musical numbers are so elaborately staged that everytime I have seen it (three so far) the audience bursts into applause!A MUST SEE!!!!

Review title: The best film I've seen all year!
Review_body: En route to the opening night of Moulin Rouge, I got depressed over the (lack of) quality of the film's I had seen thus far in 2001.  But after the two-hour showing of Baz Luhrmann's remake of the musical, I had new hope for the future of cinema.  It was hands-down the best picture I had seen in years.I know not everyone will agree with my assessment.  If you didn't like Luhrmann's last flick, William Shakespeare's Rome + Juliet, you won't care for this one either.  The plot it highly predictable, especially since it's presented in flashback form and the ending is revealed in the opening scene. But that's what makes it enjoyable, as you can just sit back and enjoy the technicolor fantasy.  And Luhrmann doesn't hold anything back there, using both black and white and "brown-toned" film stock to contrast his brilliant colors, particularly of the color red. If the costuming and color scheme aren't enough to bedazzle you, however, the music will.  Kidman has a surprisingly good voice, and McGregor's is amazing.  But it's the songs themselves that will really get to you.  A short list of the songs includes Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit," The Police's "Roxanne," Elton John's "Your Song," and a rousing rendition of Madonna's "Like a Virgin"--sung by the Moulin Rouge's impressario, Jim Broadbent, no less.  In one scene McGregor and Kidman cite the lyrics to a dozen love songs.This movie is the product of an MTV culture, and those from the older generations won't be the ones flocking to the theaters.  If you liked the style of Romeo + Juliet or the wittiness of Shakespeare in Love and you're up for a different kind of film, this one's for you.

Review title: They don't make enough musicals anymore.
Review_body: When I started watching the film I was taken away by its opening with the conductor and then the music.  I have always wanted a film musical to utilize popular songs, their there, use them.  Musicals should take on that shape, maybe we will see another one in a few years.  And then that love story, I have not cried at a film for a long time.  I think the style was perfect for that atmosphere with all the colors that Baz Luhrman likes to use.  This was such an incredible film.

This movie is absolute genius.  The energy in this movie is overwhelming! The powerful music combined with an irreplaceable cast and crew is makes this movie on of the best movies I've ever seen.  It can go from being an explosion of music and movement, to a soft, soothing combination of melody and great acting.  Go see it. If the music alone is good enough for me to go out and buy the cd, knowing that Christina aguilar sings on it, means a lot to those who know me.  Once again, most magical movie out there.

For me the true meaning of entertainment, and the best test for rating movies, is: did I manage to get through the movie without looking at my watch? Did I become totally engrossed, absorbed, transported from this dull life to another world?On this count, I believe Moulin Rouge is true entertainment. It completely absorbed every part of this moviegoer's heart, mind and soul. It even did so for a short time after the film had finished, quite an uncommon feat.Nicole was beautiful. Ewan was nice. Mr Showman was outstanding. All are brilliant, cleverly overplayed caricatures.True entertainment, 10/10

I have to say I am a little biased-Luhrmann's Strictly Ballroom is my favorite movie.  So I expected a lot from Moulin Rouge and thankfully was not disappointed.  I can easily see how someone could be turned off by this movie.  It really wasn't advertised as a kinetic, quickly-paced musical. So if you weren't expecting that, it would be a shock.  And if you're looking for something like Pearl Harbor or Mummy Returns-DON'T SEE THIS MOVIE.  To me though, this movie was spectacular!  Ewan McGregor has long been a favorite and he displayed his tremendous talent once again as Christian. Who knew he had such a dreamy voice?  I think I audibly sighed when he started singing Your Song.  In the past I have not liked Nicole Kidman in the least, but she made me change my mind.  She was beautiful and was able to pull off the role of Satine nicely.  She was aloof one minute and charmingly in love the next.  I was enthralled by this movie the minute it started and was completely engrossed until the end.  I just can't wait to go see it again.

Review title: The Most Unique Film of the Year
Review_body: I just got back from seeing the well-talked about "Moulin Rouge" with this review in mind ever since I left the theatre, and I have no idea to start. There's just too much swirling in my head about this very classy piece.I suppose I can start by saying that Moulin Rouge is one of the most unique, innovative, and original movies in recent years.Directed by Baz Luhrman (William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet, Stricly Ballroom), and set in the end of the 19th Century Paris, Moulin Rouge is the story of young Christian (Ewan McGregor) a writer in his first experiences in the Bohemian Underworld of Paris,  and the lovely Courtesan Satine (Nicole Kidman), a well-endowed showgirl of the infamous Moulin Rouge Club/Brothel, and their ill-fated love affair. However, the club manager (played by Jim Broadbent) signs over the deeds to Moulin Rouge and ownership of Miss Satine to the Duke of Worcester (Richard Roxbourgh) in exchange for his funding for the greatest show Moulin Rouge will ever produce, and thus begins the ever-twisting love story of this magnificent movie.The performances of Mr. McGregor and Ms. Nicole Kidman (who, I might add, has never looked more gorgeous then she does here) are to say the least their best yet. Their love is believable, it's real, through the way they portray the character's emotions. No fabrication here like you see in your average romantic film. Cheers also to the exceptional works of John Leguizamo and Jim BroadbentThis film is both a musical and a love story, and Moulin Rouge is like nothing I've ever seen in either regard. The music is very important in this movie. One of the first true musicals to come out just for the silver screen in many a year, it uses what is called Anachronistic Music, meaning songs that don't normally coincide with the setting of the movie nor would you ever hear that kind of music if you were actually there. You'll hear from the cast bits from and pieces of "I'll Always Love You", "Roxanne", "Smells Like Teen Spirit", and even a full rendition of "Like A Virgin", as well as the fresh Operetta pieces, R&B, and Pop Singles made especially for the movie. The anachronistic music is used remarkably well, and it's one of the most innovative scores I've ever heard.The one thing that grabbed me over everything else is the cinematography and the setting design. Baz has quite a bit of fun with the camera with this one. There's a lot of coreography in the movie, and the camera becomes a dancer itself. You wouldn't expect a musical/love story to be such a visual tour de force, and I didn't expect it either, and it made me dizzy from time to time. He uses some nifty tricks such as pulling individual frames from the film reel (so that the film purposely hops and skips) and speeding up or slowing down the speed of the film, using both techniques together with the pace of the music. Concerning the setting, Baz has taken a somewhat realistic setting and turning it into a virtual fantasy world. He uses CGI rather for an artistic effect rather then for eye-candy like most films tend to show, and the result is a specacular world filled with illustration and imagination. The costumes, make-up, and set designs are incredibly elaborate, dazzling, and almost overdone. Truly one of the most beautiful films to come out in a long time.I can almost guarantee that Moulin Rouge will make an appearance at this year's Golden Globe and Academy Awards. Here's what I think it will show in- Nominations in Cinematography, Musical Score, Art Direction-Set Decoration, Best Actor, Best Actress, and above all Costume Design.This is the first truly superb film of the summer, and quite possibly will be one of the best of the year. If you haven't already seen Moulin Rouge, do so as soon as you can. I wouldn't recommend it to a person with little appreciation for Avant Garde moviemaking, but I'd recommend it to everyone else.

Anyone with an ounce of common sense, can see that Moulin Rouge is a fantastic movie.  Of everyone I have talked to most have said that it is a bad movie, but of everyone I've talked to that has actually seen the movie has agreed that it is a superb collection of music, acting and style.  The others have made their opinions based on the trailers shown to the public, and that is the only problem with this movie, the poor (and lack thereof) advertising.Some people complain that movie trailers show too much about the movie and end up ruining it for the viewer.  If this was what the Public Relations people from 20th Century Fox were trying to accomplish, then they have gone just too far.  First of all, the trailer does not even make it evident that this movie is a musical.   Secondly, there is no real clear indication of the plot.  The only thing that is clear is that it is held in the early 1900's by the costumes and scenery in the trailer.  This movie would have made much more money if the advertising was done better, and the only thing that can help bring in more money is the word of mouth of people who have seen the movie.The plot may be a typical love story, but the movie itself is far from typical.  Baz Luhrmann, is not only a director, but an artist.  His modern visions give the movie a uniqueness that makes it stand out and will make the viewer want to see it over and over again.  A big round of applause has to be given to Baz Luhrmann and Marius DeVries for their work on the greatest soundtrack I've heard in a long time.  The soundtrack is so good, that after seeing the movie I had bought the soundtrack the very next day when the stores opened, in fact I am listening to it now as I write this review.  People should not just see this movie because it is a good movie, but because it is so unique and different than most people are used to seeing. Very few directors and their movies ever break out of the molds that seem to constrain the rest.  Baz Luhrmann has already proved that he is able with his rendition of Romeo and Juliet and Moulin Rouge is no different. 
Overall, and in every small aspect, this movie is "Spectacular, Spectacular!"

I must say, I went in expecting to have a fun, engergetic musical(ala Grease), but came away from this movie teary-eyed.  The film draws you in from the very beginning with it's exciting, visually stunning atmosphere. Ewan McGregor can sing very nicely, thank you and Nicole Kidman has a charming voice(somewhat like Olivia Newton-John's).  The movie alternates from High energy wackiness, to very high drama.  Moulin Rouge uses music from everybody from The Beatles to Madonna("Like a Virgin" is used in a scene that has to be seen to believed...a real hoot!).  My only complaint is that the charming Kylie Minogue was only used very briefly as the Green Fairy in a very memorable moment.  See this film, bring some kleenex...but you'll smile, you'll cry and you will be entertained!

Review title: Your eyes and ears will not be disappointed
Review_body: I highly recommend Moulin Rouge!  Baz Luhrman of Strictly Ballroom, Romeo & Juliet fame has reinvented the musical for the MTV generation.  Moulin Rouge rocks!  Literally!  Aside from a couple of slow spots the film is a visual feast for the eyes.  The colors, choreography, cinematography, costume design, set design, direction, and editing all combine to make it one wild ride.  I must also mention the treat for the ears.  Kidman and McGregor prove not only their acting merits but their vocal abilities!  McGregor throws himself into his character and sings his heart out.  The excitement and joy in his expression just make you want to believe!  There was one musical number that I was not expecting and I was completely overjoyed. Judging from the audience reaction in the packed theater the crowd totally whooped that scene up!  You'll know which one I'm talking about when you see it.

Satinne is an aspiring actress who is stuck performing for Moulin Rouge until she is discovered.  One night a Duke is in attendance at Moulin Rouge who will give Satinne her big break.  Christian, the writer who wants to be discovered, is also and is mistaken for the Duke.  Christian and Satinne meet and sparks fly, literally, while the real Duke is jealous.  The visuals are amazing in this movie and the songs will keep you humming and kicking your feet.  Go see it!  I was very unsure about seeing this movie, but reluctantly went to see it with friends.  I had no idea what it would be about.  Within five minutes I was loving it.  It is a whole new musical about love.  The songs were great, and I loved the use of many titles in the Elephant Love Medley.  The fact that Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor actually do their own singing really impressed me.  I particularly enjoyed the "Truth Beauty Freedom Love" theme....Get the soundtrack!  And I don't mean for Lady Marmalade......

Review title: At last, a movie with a moral!
Review_body: A fantastic musical! I loved every second of the "SPECTACULAR, SPECTACULAR!" I can't understand how "A Beautiful Mind" won the Best Picture Oscar over this magnificent production.The moral that is given in "Moulin Rouge" is something that I firmly believe in. "THE GREATEST THING IN LIFE, IS TO LOVE SOMEONE AND TO BE LOVED IN RETURN!!!"Throughout the centuries philosophers have tried to describe what life is about with thousands upon thousands of words used in each of their complex discourses. I wonder what the ancients would have replied to the moral stated here? The only philosopher that I can think of that comes close to giving us something so true and yet so simple is Jesus Christ.Joseph Campbell abridged these words of wisdom even further when he said to Bill Moyers during an interview shortly before his death, "FOLLOW YOUR BLISS!"BRAVO!

Review title: YOU WON'T SEE A BETTER FILM THIS YEAR !
Review_body: Or perhaps for years to come . Don't let others dissuade you from seeing this film . I know that you most likely will love it or hate it but do make your own judgment . I myself have seen it 22 times in the theatre & will return again . I hope the Academy will take note at Oscar time for Best Picture & Actor & Actress for Ewan McGregor who was without a doubt ,born to play this role & Nicole Kidman who has languished in many a boring film . I know many people cannot stand this film , but if you look at the overall numbers on IMDB, MOULIN IS TIED IN OVERALL RATINGS WITH SHREK ! Do yourself the greatest favor this year , see it & JUDGE FOR YOURSELF !!!!!!!!

Review title: One to simply be enjoyed, rather than analysed (SPOILERS)
Review_body: The reviews I have read on the subject of this film seem either to say "This is the best film I've EVER seen" (probably for around a week) or "Anyone who felt anything other than total disgust at viewing this film is an imbecile". I can see where both sides are coming from, and I think that aspects of both are true.Moulin Rouge is the kind of film that has the capacity to greatly inspire you, assuming you are willing to forgive its weak points (more on that below).  Its message is crystal clear and poignantly delivered "The greatest thing you'll ever learn..."  I am not the kind of viewer who watches films searching for weak points to make disparaging comments about at a later date, so the fact that I did sense that some aspects were not of the standard the remainder of the film deserves is proof that they are easily apparent.  However, I loved this film.  This was in spite of, or perhaps even because of, the several things that were bad about it.First, the good points.  Most undeniably the cast.  Nicole Kidman simply casts a spell as Satine (though for Gods sake stop her pouring emulsion over herself, or whatever the hell she does to get a distinctly unsexy white sheen on her skin), and Ewan McGregor, who has always seemed mildly annoying to me, also puts in a very good performance.  Jim Broadbent doesn't put a foot wrong as Zidler, Richard Roxburgh manages to pull off the trick of being both a caricature and occasionally exuding menace - the final scene with him advancing toward the stage brandishing a pistol had genuine ferocity about it -  and all the other supporting actors live up to expectations.  The one character who annoyed me throughout was "Nini Legs in the Air".  First of all, the woman is ugly.  Second, her spiteful comments to both the leads just made me want to slap the woman. I wasn't as annoyed as some by the constant changes in focus.  Perhaps I wasn't analysing it at a deep enough level to be greatly troubled by it, but after the mayhem of the first twenty minutes the cameraman appears to get his caffeine fix and reduce the jerking of the camera.  The direction was inspired, innovative, and a refreshing departure from the norm. I was also not troubled by the use of modern music, indeed in certain scenes it made the film.  My favourite scene, with the two leads serenading one another atop an elephant (ridiculous as it sounds), was touching, well choreographed, and exquisitely performed.Now the bad points.  Basically they all revolve around the one central problem - the plot.  Now fair enough, its not about the plot, blah blah, but basically, much as I enjoyed the "Your Song" scene, I couldn't see the two of them as a realistic couple.  So shoot me.  I loved the film, but its fundamental premise left me shaking my unashamedly idealistic head.Whilst I disagree that revealing the ending at the start was necessarily a bad thing, I do agree that the transparency of the plot inevitably lead to total predictability.  TOTAL predictability.  As in, after the first hour, I could have written detailed scene summaries for the second hour.That being said, I found Moulin Rouge to be a great film, extremely enjoyable, and able to be watched on multiple occasions with no reduction in that enjoyment.  I heartily recommend it to people with the ability not to delve too deeply into its underlying weaknesses, but to bask in the warm glow of its surface magic.  I don't know if its one of the best films I've seen in a while, but its definitely one of those I've enjoyed the most. An easy 9/10.

"Moulin Rouge" is not just a movie. It's a rollercoaster ride. And a thrilling one at that. Baz Luhrmann has created a truly unique movie experience- You may love it or hate it but I urge you to buy your ticket, strap yourself in and keep your arms wholly within the car because you're in for an exhilarating ride.Nicole Kidman and Ewan MacGregor are just great, but it's the visuals that give this a whopping 9 stars. I haven't stopped thinking about this movie since I saw it (twice) 2 weeks ago. The one feature that has not been praised, to date, is the extraordinary original music written for the film. I hope that a second album is released that includes this, especially the end title music. Stunning!

Review title: Excellent for the deep in thought
Review_body: The Moulin Rouge is a surreal image of Parisian life in the pre-1900's.  It embodies the surreal ideal in plot, filming, and music.  With an excellent performance by both Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman, this movie is not for everyone.  This movie is for those of you who can appreciate the surreal view and a deep ending.  This is not your "HAPPILY EVER AFTER" Story!But, sincerely recommended if you can see past the change and the early feel of the movie.

Review title: If you're a sucker for tragic romance, and music...you're in for a treat!
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is a great movie....for some people.  It's one of those "love it, hate it" movies---I, personally, loved it.  All of my friends loved it; in fact, everyone I know that's seen it has loved it, a lot of them have and seen it twice. Compare it with Baz Luhrman's "Romeo and Juliet" for the sweeping, tragic, romance.  Compare it with an artsy music video for the cinematography. Then compare it with your Greatest Hits from the Last 30 Years CD for the soundtrack.  It's about 1/2 opera, 1/2 dialogue.  Imagine such songs as "Your Song", "Roxanne", and "Like A Virgin" as key scenes in the movie, only all songs tweaked to be "broadway"nized. Ewan McGregor's performance is quite good, and his voice proves to be pretty decent, too. (I enjoyed his rendition of Elton John's `Your Song' better than the original!) Nicole Kidman is in a typical `unattainable goddess' role, with pretty good acting (not as impressive as McGregor's emotional performance), and with an I-Got-the-Lead-in-a-few-High-School-Musicals voice. Be prepared to be open-minded for the first 20 minutes (it's a little weird in the beginning), but to be delighted with the rest of the film. And BE OPEN MINDED! You should love it!

Review title: So bad that I almost cried...
Review_body: One of the worst movies I have ever seen.  Nicole Kidman was awful, and the use of the music in the film was so horrible.  The director's shots were beautiful at times, but after seeing them over and over again, I wanted to vomit.  Can't say anything else.  IT was so bad that it hurt.

Review title: Musical: A beautiful love story set in the Parisian nightclub, the Moulin Rouge. Based on the Greek myth of Orpheus, it's the story of a young poet who falls in love with a courtesan.
Review_body: This is the retrospective tale of a young poet named Christian, who comes to Paris in 1899 to become a part of the Bohemian Revolution. He there meets and falls in love with a beautiful courtesan, Satine. It soon becomes a thrilling love triangle between the two and the terrible and rich Duke. As Christian and Satine's love evolves, a dark force comes, proving to be devastating. Beautifully choreographed with incredible colors, actions and songs, this a movie you will never forget.

Review title: Moulin Rouge should be nominated for academy awards
Review_body: if moulin rouge is not given a nod by the academy this year then I'll be sure the awards are fixed. How else could one explain Russell Crowe and Gladiator. This year the academy should redeem itself- Members of the voting pool should consider Moulin Rouge for Best Original Song "come what may" best cinematography, music, (and musical adaptation) actress Nicole Kidman, actor Ewan Mcgregor, Picture, and best Director the true genious, Baz! I can't say enough about this film its amazing! I am hoping a second soundtrack comes out soon I definately want to add it to my collection- if anybody knows where to get the remainder of the songs from the movie, please drop me a line! Thanks

Review title: The Best Love Story In the World ! ! ! ! !
Review_body: The music and story is so nice. The music is so fast moving. And the story is more sad than William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet (1996).This is truth love between Satine and Christian.  Ewan and Kidman are the best singer in the show. Ewan singing is so sweet.

In my mind, this movie gets two merits:1. That it was visually stunning, beautifully superficially appealing.  By that I mean the settings, cinematography, musical numbers, were all brilliant. 2.  That it had one of the most predictable, corny, rehashed plotlines I've ever seen, was full of romantic rubbish that would normally make a cynical type like me nauseous - and yet this was all pulled off so well, and with such skill, that I didn't even mind it.  (To say "one of the most", I admit though, is pretty unfair, considering the state of most efforts at movies nowadays - let's just say that it didn't particularly surprise me, and, at least theme-wise, didn't really seem to step out of the mold).So that would be my only grievance: Yes, the plot is corny, yes, the theme is simple, and the random-spontaneously-combusting passion that occurs between the two main characters is very cliche.  This one gripe aside, I will now try to express why the movie is worth seeing even despite this seemingly major flaw.The visual effects are to die for.  So many scenes just dazzle with color and beauty - every detail, from ridiculously lavish interiors and buildings down to the costuming, is breathtaking.  Definitely worth seeing on the big screen - it is a celebration of movement and color.It is filmed in an interesting and unique way - not so different as to alienate its viewers, the all simplistic general public - but a refreshing change from your everyday style.  Combine these with excellent choreography and the Moulin Rouge is a whirlwind of textures....a sort of living scrapbook is the only kind of way I can describe it.The singing is surprisingly good.  Kidman shines.  I didn't think too much of McGregor's voice, but he pulls it off well as well.  The inclusion of contemporary songs works so well, no one could even think of criticizing anachronism.The movie is cheesy: but when it's cheesy, it's glossed to perfection.  The love ballads are set in the stars, glitter and rosepetals galore, with big corny musical numbers inspiring emotion and awe despite themselves.And it's funny, too.  Spoofs galore - hilarious in contex.I don't know anything about excellent acting, so I won't presume myself informed enough to lecture you all on that.  But from what I, in my simple peasant ways, can see, Moulin Rouge is a fantastic effort.  The inherent "cheesiness" of the plotline is never evident; everything is believable, and earnest.  I don't think the plot has any major surprises, but the strands of the story are interwoven skillfully. It dazzles, enthralls, and flows beautifully....and worth every penny to see it in full glory on the big screen.Moulin Rouge has something for everyone, I think...innovative camera work for the film techniquers, visual splendor for the eye-candyists, lots of sparkles, music for the musical lover as well as the contemporary music lover - contemp. music placed so innovatively throughout the film, a heartfelt story for the romanticists, a comedy for those who want light entertainment.And even for cynics like me, always on the prowl to find originality and abuse cliches....for taking something so, so simple, and creating a great and enduring, and penultimately lovable film.

Review title: Best Movie of the year so far.
Review_body: In my opinion this move was absolultey amazing. Baz Luhrmann did an amazing job with everything. I loved the visuals and the way they used songs that came out up to 80 years after the movie took place. The movie made me laugh,made me cry, and made me think. The three favoriate things for movies to do to me. The movie was absolutely amazing.

Review title: After one hour I walked out and got my money back.
Review_body: Normally, I will watch any movie to the end.  This movie was the exception. Now "Moulin Rouge" joins "Top Banana", starring Phil Silvers, as too unbearable to sit though to completion in the theater.  After over an hour of watching quirky camera work and being assaulted by cute but trite music--I was forced to bail out. Satine should have died within the first half hour and taken the rest of the characters with her.

You know why people love this film. Its not its technical brilliance, its not its throwback to the golden musical age of Hollywood. Its supporting characters extremely poorly written and many of the stylistic experiments don't quite work out. But why then is it worth watching time and time again? Its the closest we can see on a screen this far to true love being shown on screen. Its able to bring out the Bohemian in even the most cynical among us and though as a piece of cinema it may not go down as the greatest work it undeniably is a beautiful artwork of some kind and must be remembered as such so that we don't forget just why we continue to listen to silly love songs.

Review title: Simply, the worst movie ever made.
Review_body: Where do I start? The awful miscasting of Ewan McGregor. The horrible music; like Lloyd Weber on a bad acid trip. Kidman's terrible lip-synching. Kidman's lack of stage presence. A story line which has been done a thousand times before, all better than this. Camera work which was like The Blair Witch Project, only in Technicolor (I kept reaching for my Dramamine). How did this movie EVER get financial backing? If not for the headliners, it would have run 1 week, max. Or stayed in the can forever. Where it belongs.

This movie continues to amaze me because of how awful it is. It does't work as a comedy(because it's not funny)not even a lame one, and drama?.....seriously?...I can only assume that the decision to use non singing actors to try and sing the horrible songs was done for comedic relief. So far I haven't spoken to anyone who liked this movie, and when it comes up as a rerun the offending channel is turned as soon as possible. The actors that were in this train wreck are good actors (but terrible singers), so the blame for this turkey probably lies with the director/producers.....who are probably saying to everyone now,"Well, we thought it was a good idea at the time.".....oh, and to top it off, this movie won an Oscar or two?.. that goes to prove that it's not the quality of the work, it's who you know in the business...btw, I am in the business...

Apparently people either love or loathe this movie.  I encourage readers to check the poll numbers.  I had decided to give this movie a '10' - a rarity for me.  And then when I look at the numbers I see that over 40% of the people polled give the movie this top grade!  Ordinarily the scores for the top movies peak at 8 or 9. Peaking at 10 is quite interesting, esp. when the average score is relatively low.Conclusion: you'll love it or you will regret having seen it. I loved it enough to watch it three times on a flight from Europe to DC.

The long wait was worth it.  After much secrecy during the filming here in Sydney, Moulin Rouge sprung to the screen to a very appreciative home town audience.  Whilst not being a huge Kidman fan, it was great to see her in the role of Satine and together with Ewan Macgregor made a great screen couple. In my opinion all the cast were faultless.This film was camp with a capital "C" and incredibly entertaining. Brilliant sets, costumes and an exceptional soundtrack with a clever use of the contemporary.  Ewan McGregors voice - wow!  It's not very often that I feel like singing along at the movies but with Moulin Rouge not only did I want to sing along, I wanted to get up and Can Can!So good to see the Australian film industry getting more acknowlegment worldwide through the success of such a film like Moulin Rouge.Sydney - the new Hollywood?  In reality probably not - but we like to think so anyway.

I have never liked musicals and was only attracted to this film out of curiosity. But, the film captivated me and I enjoyed almost every minute! The cinematography is superb, the acting is of a high standard, and (much to my surprise) I didn't even want to run out screaming when they started to sing - my usual response to musicals.

Review title: The Best Movie Ever moulin rouge
Review_body: The Moulin Rouge is the most amazing movie ever. Its my favorite movie. The songs Are fantastic and i have been singing them in my head all day. Christian (Ewan McGregor), a gifted writer with an idealistic outlook on love, sets off for Paris . He moves into a lowly tenement right across from the notorious nightclub that is the Moulin Rouge, where girls do the can-can... and more. It is here where Christian befriends a dwarfish Toulouse (John Leguizamo), who wants to put on a musical production to further the Bohemian movement. He wants Christian to write it and have the most beautiful and famous star of the Moulin Rouge, Satine (Nicole Kidman), to play the lead. The ever-so-romantic Christian falls madly in love with Satine, but things get complicated when the wealthy financial duke of the production wants Satine for himself. Satine is torn between the two, but like a true actress, she knows that the show must go on.From the trailers, one would not think that "Moulin Rouge" is a comedy, but in fact, most of the film is. I was very much surprised how well this worked for the film, not only because we knew the lyrics and could sing silently to ourselves, but also these songs fit the situations perfectly. I was totally absorbed by the film's amusing absurdity. There were original numbers written for the film, which were also good, but it will be the ones that are recognized that will be remembered. Nicole Kidman was great as Satine, and I also admired Ewan McGregor's performance. Credit is to be given to anybody who can act as well as Kidman. Despite a bit of a shaky start, "Moulin Rouge" regains control and maintains it for the rest of the film. It is an enjoyable surprise that will make you laugh and sing along. Go check out this movie if you can-can.

If you are a fan of musicals, don't miss this film! Nicole Kidman turns in what I argue is the best performance of her career. Ewan McGregor is memorable as Miss Kidman's love interest -- and what a voice he has! You'll never be able to watch Star Wars without thinking of this movie. Hot!

Ultra-romantic, operatic in the grandeur of its ambitions, gorgeous to look at, musically astounding, witty and exuberant, endlessly inventive, and loads of fun, Moulin Rouge floored me. I don't think I have enjoyed a movie as much since my childhood, meaning that it transported me out of this world into its own unique universe the way Saturday matinees (didn't matter what was playing) did when I was a child. (This is not to claim that Moulin Rouge is as great as, let's say, Grand Illusion; but there are different kinds of masterpieces.) Kidman and McEwan are both splendid and of course both are splendid to look at. The supporting cast is uniformly superb, John Leguizamo especially endearing as Toulouse Lautrec. Sets, costumes are a delight. The film's musical director and whoever did the orchestrations/arrangements should both win the Nobel Prize in Music (if there were such a prize); musically Moulin Rouge is an absolute tour-de-force. I certainly can understand why some people might hate this movie (those, for example, with no sense of romance or humor; or those who find opera or, say, musical theatre, inherently ridiculous). And I know it's a much over-used word . . . but Baz Luhrmann is clearly a genius.

Review title: A musical of a different color
Review_body: I must say that I never saw this movie when it was in theaters but it was on demand last night so being bored i decided to order it and watch. It was brilliantly done but I can see where the negative reviews come from. The camera spins and created dizzying shots in which colors and shapes blend with pop songs such as Like a Virgin and Diamonds are a girls best friend. I would still suggest seeing it because I have seen nothing like it.....as some mentioned earlier it would probably be a good spring board for getting someone into musical film and theater. On a side note, I had no idea that Ewan McGregor could sing so well nor Nicole Kidman for that matter, they alone make it worth enduring the film.

I have nothing against glitz, and most of this movie is goofy and operatic and ridiculous and does not take itself seriously.  To that extent it is watchable.  But then at the end, all of a sudden we are supposed to be affected by the pathos of Satine's well-telegraphed demise.  Baloney!

Review title: Wow, one of the best of best movie
Review_body: Haha maybe i m last person reviewing. But without reviewing i can't hold my nerves after watching such a beautiful movie and direction. Perfect works of imagination..... This movie will live with me forever and ever. Love 😍 is for this moment and hatred live forever with suffering.

Review title: A love-it-or-hate-it experience. I hated it.
Review_body: I just saw MOULIN ROUGE! the other night on Netflix and I thought it was one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Completely self-indulgent, contrived, soulless, and pretentious. And yet people keep calling it one of the greatest movie musicals ever. It's literally all style and no substance.There were many things about this movie that annoyed me so I'll try and keep it to a minimum.1) The plot: I've never seen a romance in a movie that felt so fake as in MOULIN ROUGE. Kidman and Gregor have no chemistry on screen but to be fair that's probably more of the director's fault then theirs. They keep saying crap like "love will shine through" or "love will conquer all" or the popular "the greatest thing you'll ever learn is to love and be loved in return." Give me a break. I literally counted how many times they said "love" in this movie and it was 126 times. (Although I may have lost count during the Madonna number when the chorus sings "Love!" a dozen times every 5 seconds.) The love that this movie babbles on about isn't real love. It's formulaic, planned, polished, and fraudulent Hollywood romance. The relationship between the writer and actress never felt true because whenever their relationship was in danger, it was because the one-dimensional Duke threatened, never the two in love. That Duke only exists to the convenience of the plot. Real problems in a relationship come from the lovers like their personalities, life choices, etc. There's more to love than just pure romance. It's about getting past problems and working through them instead of just waiting around and doing nothing hoping that "love will conquer all" in some clichéd climax. There are better romance films out there (musical and non) that actually show real love like CASABLANCA, GONE WITH THE WIND, CABARET, LOST IN TRANSLATION, and more.2) The characters: These people seemed so non-existent. In fact, the characters in this movie weren't characters; they were set pieces that could move around, sing badly, and make stupid faces at the camera. There are great actors in this movie like Ewan McGregor, Nicole Kidman, and Jim Broadbent; yet, director Baz Luhrman favored their costumes and bedrooms more than their acting. A real shame and a real waste of potential.3) The editing: Based purely on this aspect, I believe MOULIN ROUGE! was made for people with severe ADD. Not one shot lasted more than 3 seconds. All it is is just people mugging at the camera as it zooms from one room to the next. It's as if Luhrman is afraid that the actors will distract from the movie's style so he yells CUT!! right before the actors summon a real emotion. Characters should never be upstaged by the visuals; the visuals are there to add to them and the story. Ironically, this MTV-style approach actually hurts the movie's look because we can never get a good look at the amazing art direction. These sets are fantastic! Let us see them! 4) The music: My friends kept telling me how brilliant and innovative the soundtrack is and when I saw the trailer I thought I was going to adore it. But when the McGregor character first sang "The Hills are alive with the Sound of Music!", I groaned thinking to myself, "Great, it's a jukebox musical." For those who don't know, a jukebox musical is a musical that uses already existing music for its "score." It's damaging Broadway right now with shows like American IDIOT and preventing musicals to move forward artistically. It should be used as an homage to great composers and their work, but nowadays it's just a cheap move to enhance album purchases. I guess in MOULIN ROUGE it's supposed to show how love is universal in all kinds of music but it makes the movie seem anachronistic. Plus, if a movie like MOULIN ROUGE is going to have this much hype around it, it better have original songs. Some people say "Come What May" is the only original piece but I've done some research and it apparently was used for Luhrman's previous film, ROMEO+JULIET. It wasn't even written specifically for MOULIN ROUGE. (It's an awful song anyway.) I can't stand it when people praise this soundtrack because there's nothing really brilliant about simply rearranging and orchestrating existing pop songs and having them sung horribly. (Kidman is not a singer! Why is she used in this and NINE?!) 5) The directing: Pretty much everything I've complained about is because of Luhrman's direction. People wonder why he never got an Oscar nomination for Best Director. It's because he didn't care about the story or characters, only the sets and costumes. It's actually kind of amazing how much he didn't care. There's no sense of pace, subtlety, or consistency. There's nothing wrong with trying to make your movie look spectacular. But if your story and characters fall flat, then the images just become something nice to look at and dissolve from the audience's memories once the movie's over. There's got to be something else that gives the film its drive other than clothes, art direction, and choppy editing.Well, that's all I can think of for now. Hopefully I didn't rant too much. Obviously I'm in the minority but that won't change my opinion. But who knows? Maybe I'm just "missing something." I just wish people would acknowledge and admire real musicals instead of a collection of pop songs pretending to be musicals.

Review title: Erm, not bad, not keen on Nicole though
Review_body: This has got to be a film you either love or hate.  I went in there thinking it would be great and fantastic (my boyfriend went in thinking he would hate it).  I came out cold and he came out jumping for joy.  I knew I was hating it as soon as I started looking at my watch.  If I love a film I don't care about the time, but I was clock watching.  I didn't enjoy the start of it. Everyone was OTT.  It was everywhere.  I understand that it was supposed to be a crazy time.  It did my head in.  One could argue, it is a musical and it is a theatrical piece.  Bobbins!  It still was trying too hard at the start.  Got to say that Nicole made a good entrance, but for some one with Consumption, she had a good set of lungs on her and looked well.  As if! Do you know, but when I was little I always thought that Consumption was something that people who ate too much food got.  Anyway, that aside.  I like how they did new songs in the old setting, but I hated how they kept enveloping different songs into each other.  And (perhaps it's because I'm a female and it is the law that females end up hating female leads if they are very beautiful), but I felt no sympathy for Nicole's Satine.  I just couldn't wait for her to die.  She was a completely cold character that was not sold on me at all.  I thought that John Leguzi-whats-his-face was fab at Toulouse Lautrec and the Narcoleptic was a great part also.  I preferred Romeo+Juliette and Strictly Ballroom.  They wiped the floor with this film. Perhaps it's just me not "getting" it, but it was not the best film I saw this year.

A bleary evening in London was threatening at which point the idea of seeing Moulin Rouge was cast in my direction.  Not having heard much of it, knowing about the famous night-spot in Paris and having seen a less than invigorating trailer left me a little unsure.  I gave into peer pressure and we took our seats.From the very beginning of this movie I was hooked. It was the saline in my cinematic drip from minute one to minute 127.  Left brain-dead by the usual Hollywood fare, this rocked me into consciousness and had me by the short and curlies all the way through.You can read elsewhere the details of the plot, so I'll refrain from a refrain, but if you are after an all-out cinematic assault in the way cinema was intended, then you need to see this movie.  Not only is it a welcome break from the more moronic Hollywood releases of, well, most of the time, it is a genuine emotional rollercoaster and visual triumph.  Mash that in with glorious pastiche, sharp wit, spellbinding set dressing, photography and choreography and you have a real treat.Don't be put off by the fact that it is a musical.  It is a musical triumph. In fact everything worked so well that I was left floundering in my seat until the end of the credits, as was nearly everyone else in the cinema. Extraordinarily refreshing movie making.

Review title: One of the very best movies ever,...
Review_body: After seeing Baz Luhrman's Romeo & Juliet I was very anxious to see his latest, Moulin Rouge. All my expectations came true, and became overruled by this movie. This experience is one I'll never forget. This isn't just a story about love or a romantic comedy. This film is a masterpiece filled with visual miracles and breathtaking music. The singing voices of Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor surprised me, they sound great! By the way, not only the film, the soundtrack is also a wonderful album. I think Baz Luhrman is one of the most innovative 'visualist' in movie-land! And I'm looking forward to his new project (if he's doing one,...)My advice, go see the movie and find out for yourself!

Review title: This film is utter and complete TRIPE!
Review_body: This film is utter and complete TRIPE! What on earth were they thinking of? The story line is banal, the script is tenuous, the imagery is at best dubious. To call this film a work of art is to grasp for meaning that is not there. I would rather be beaten with a stick than have to watch rubbish like this, and not a small stick either.

Review title: The one musical love story I wouldn't miss for a life
Review_body: Well, I came out of the theater shocked, thrilled, sad, amazed, literally with my jaw somewhere in the ankle area. I never thought that a musical (I think that is what they call such movies) could appeal to me so strongly, none to say a love story. Moulin Rouge was imho the best love story I have ever had the privilege to watch. Many of them are typical, only the scenery changes. Here the scenery is blown to such shocking contents that you feel as if being in a theme park of some sort. And it's not a crappy theme park. After a movie, besides the "feel" of it I always try to analyze it's good and it's bad points. After Moulin Rouge I could not find any weak points. The directing was great (thx Buz :), the acting (I could not imagine a better line up, all the roles were great), the COSTUMES, the scenery, the drama! I hope you won't take me for a freak but I just came back from THE SHOW and I'm still hot over it.You will have many great moments while watching this movie, from mad laughter, through sadness, despair to contemplation. Great job.

This is an excellent movie, but not for all. You have to be very open-minded as Moulin Rouge was directed by Baz Luhrmann. He is a directing genius, but puts a twist to his filming that some movie goers might find "too weird". If you like unique films, this is the one to watch! Also, the score is wonderful. Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman are amazing! My favorite movie ever-- I'm obsessed with Moulin Rouge!

Review title: When was the last time a movie made you cry?
Review_body: No movie _ever_ has made me feel as strongly as this one. An enormous catharsis, that's what this movie is. The strongest of feelings: love, sorrow, jealousy, etc. Absolutely everything in this movie just fits in, from the ultra modern camera action to the themes that are as old as man himself.The basic story is actually a very shakespearenian tragedy - reminding of Shakespeare In Love and the most recent version of Romeo And Juliet (which was, by the way, directed by the same man than this one). From the opening scene it's obvious that there will be no happy ending on this one, and the whole plot could very well be crafted by Shakespeare himself.Also this is a musical, in a way it follows the footsteps of many former musical classics, like Singing In The Rain for example. But most of all this is A MOVIE, an audiovisual experience at it's best! Very rarely, if ever has there been such a collaboration between the direction, cinematography, acting, music, and script as in Moulin Rouge! Watching this movie was like taking a giant load off my back, it somehow freed me of any bad thoughts I had, a catharsis as I mentioned.Besides, this movie made me cry, a thing no movie has accomplished in at least ten years, and that really is a compliment from a movie freak like me!

Review title: I have seen this film many times and it never gets boring.
Review_body: (NOTE this comment contains a spoiler) Here's what I think of Moulin Rouge!. When I watched this movie for the first time, I was thinking that it was OK. But then I watched it again and I loved it. But to most people this movie seems weird, not to me. It wasn't weird at all, to me it's just "Spectacular".There are many reasons why I love this film. Here are all of my reasons for loving this film. I liked the first half of the film a lot because it's very fast paced. The second half of the movie is when the drama kicks in and still very good. I loved most of the songs that are sung by Ewan McGregor & Nicole Kidman. Finally I think Nicole Kidman & Ewan McGregor are perfect in this film, their acting and singing are just amazing!!.And now the downfalls of Moulin Rouge! since I liked "Satine" so much, I didn't like that at the end of the movie she dies.
