The movie takes a lot of chances, and isn't afraid to do completely unconventional (even absurd) things.  This is not a "safe" movie in any sense of the word. To enjoy it, you really have to just let Baz take you through his vision; if you expect it to cater to your preconceptions of what a movie or musical should be like, you're going to be disappointed.However, if you've got any imagination at all, and you want to see something truly different -- go see this film right now.  It really is something special.

I enjoy [most] operas when I choose to attend them.  Perhaps the reason I enjoy them, but not this pseudo-opera puke-frenzy, is that I can take in the scenes and enjoy them rather than be dizzied with gratuitous and intrusive editing.  This film hints that it contains incredible visuals, but it never lingers long enough to permit verification.  I just remember the color RED! This flick will probably kill more than a handful of epileptics.
Perhaps it's optimized to be viewed while high.   If someone has tried it, please relate the experience...A positive note:  the DVD has lots of extras and some cool features to tweak the setup of home theaters and surround-sound.

Review title: an average movie that could have been so much better
Review_body: If this movie would take itself a bit more seriously it might derserve the 10 points it got from so many viewers. A lot of the music scenes reminded me of silly comedy movies like Naked Gun, Austin Powers and the like. That is not what I expected from this movie and not the way I think it should have been made. An embarrassment to Hollywood. (watched the trailer to The Ice Age obviously)

If I could give it a 0 I would.  And even that is being generous.  No depth of characters, no deep plot.  Everything was almost perfectly predictable after seeing the first 30 seconds of film.  The use of popular music from the 70's, 80's, 90's was tacky, distasteful, and distracting.It's no wonder only 12 people were in the theater during the second weekend it was open.

I just went to see Moulin Rouge, and was totally awed by it.  The way the songs were intermixed was spellbinding.  I went in with one concept, I didn't know too much about it, and came out with a greater appreciation for the art of the movie musical.My two favorite songs was Madonna's "Like a Virgin", sung by all guys no less, and "Roxanne" sung by the "The Narcoleptic Argentinian" in a great gravel voice.  It was an experience that anyone who loves musicals would enjoy and reminiscence about for a long time.All in all, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys musicals.

This movie plays like a two hour MTV video, which I guess is good for some, but for me a five minute running time would have been appropriate for the material.  I don't know how else to say it, but I think this is possibly the most boring and uninteresting movie I have ever seen.  Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman are fine actors, but this movie utterly and completely wastes their talents with stale characters, flat dialogue and crass, in your face cinematography.

Review title: Film making that soared and took my breath away
Review_body: Moulin Rouge engages the audience in a whirlwind spectacle of film-making...full of surprises and humor, color and motion.  A feast for the soul...and the senses...the best meal I've had for years.

Review title: Pure eye candy, but not much else.
Review_body: Fantastic scenery, but my kingdom for a plot!  Tired, re-hashed love story set to poorly remade disco-remixes of popular songs from the 70s and 80s. With the herky jerky camera shots, I couldn't even enjoy what was probably outstanding choreography. Probably deserved best costume award, but nominated for best picture?! Egads, was this year's crop that weak? The lavish sets and costumes keep me from rating this piece of poorly written tripe a 1, so I'll be kind and give it a 3/10.

You'll have to watch it 2 or even 3 times to see everything that's going on. Any actors worth their salt would have been propelled to stardom in this movie.  Shame about ewan's voice bought what he lacked in ability he made up for in enthusiasm.  A feast of colour and movement.  Excellent viewing.

Review title: I have a new favourite film
Review_body: What can I say?  This movie had me going from laughing hysterically to crying, well, hysterically within minutes.  From the opening scenes Moulin Rouge had the aura of Baz Luhrmann, who in my mind is one of the best directors on earth.Nicole Kidman and Ewan MacGregor were perfectly, if unexpectedly, cast in the lead roles.  Having the mixture of well known songs (listen for Madonna's Like a Virgin and Nirvana's Smells like Teen Spirit) and originals kept the movie interesting and exciting.As I left the cinema, along with my friends (one of whom was sobbing uncontrollably) I could hear many fellow movie goers proclaiming exactly the same statement as myself: 'I have just found a new favourite film.'

It's a GREAT movie!! If you like Beatles, David Bowie, Elton John, Madonna, T-Rex, Paul McCartney, Joe Cocker, Kiss, Nirvana, Queen... , then you got to see this movie. Ewan and Nicole are excellent... It's a simple love-story told in a complicated way, and it's never boring. ...And remember: Music is feelings...( 8/10p )

What an incredible film, in all aspects.  The acting, the music, the direction, the writing.  I wish I could create like that.  At first I didn't think I would like it, even though I am a sucker for a musical and a good love story. And, as viewers already know, this is a story about love.  The classic "boy-gets-girl, or does he?" story with some exciting twists and turns and laughs and tears along the way. I was pleasantly surprised by Nicole Kidman's and Ewan McGregor's voices. They were beautiful (on the eyes too lol).  I'll never listen to "Your Song" quite the same way again. "Come What May" makes me wish I was getting married all over again so I could have that as my wedding song. I'm speechless at this point except to say, see this movie- if you haven't already. And if you have- go see it again!  Buy the DVD!  The additional material is incredible!  I got it for Christmas and I've watched it so many times my cat is singing the soundtrack with me! LOL!

Never before have I seen such a classic story about star crossed lovers told in such an original and captivating way. Right from the start when we are thrust into a CG Paris, straight past the Eiffel tower and into the Moulin Rouge, you know what kind of film it is going to be. A colourful, beautiful film that manages to be side splittingly funny and heart wrenchingly tragic at the same time. This is a true masterpiece that confirms Baz Luhrman is just getting better and better.

For the first time in ages I left a movie theatre pleasantly surprised, as opposed to totally disappointed. Moulin Rouge has restored my faith in the film industry. This movie is full of colorful imagery, creatively combined music and last, but certainly not least, a fantastic cast. I have to admit, I had my doubts as to wither Kidman and McGregor could sing. My doubts were laid to rest. Both hold their own, with McGregor showing he has quite a singing talent. At the end of the movie the entire theatre say in silence and watched the credits go by. The movie has that effect, it leaves you spellbound.

Review title: Fantastic, a stage musical, only bigger
Review_body: The summary says it all. It felt like a big stage musical, a Lloyd Webber or an Andrew Rice, but with a soundtrack everybody already knows. The actors were great, and played everything larger than life. And for all you Aussies out there, enjoy playing, hey I know that actor.....

Not since Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon have I been so enthusiastic about a film.Having just come from the cinema, I couldn't wait until to write this in case my mind forgets the small details. Moulin Rouge is quite simply fantastic.The directing, acting, cinematography, singing and of course the music are first rate.I was glued to my seat (a hurricane wouldn't of moved me) for the 2 hour duration. I didn't look at my watch once (which is unusual for me) my eyes where transfixed to the silver screen.The first 10 minutes you are thinking "this is very strange and what on earth am I watching". But when you get used to this (it doesn't take long) you are in amazement. Their is a 15 minute (approximately) scene near the beginning which leaves your jaw open right to the floor.Luhrmann has decided to give us can-can dancers, dancing and singing to the likes of Nirvana's "Smells like teen spirit" to name but a few. With close up camera shots, fast moving pace and flashy editing. Sure there is a few corny scenes during the films between McGregor and Kidman. But it is a true wonder to watch.You have got to watch out for the excellent re-working of Madonnas "Like a Virgin". The film was also just the right length another 20 minutes and it might of started dragging. 20 minutes shorter and I would of been annoyed.I have forgot to mention McGregor and Kidman's singing, ignore what all/some of the critic's are saying they really can and do sing. The whole perzaz, Luhrmann's flare for style and being unconventional are something else.I urge everybody to see this film. It is definitely in my top 5 of films seen at the cinema this year.Thank you for reading this far.

Review title: The best picture of the year
Review_body: It's been a long time since I have seen such an spectacular film, so amazing an full of color, movement, music and songs that my wife and I were delighted at the end of it. I don't usually go to see a picture twice, but this one is worth it. Spectacular directed, spectacular edition and spectacular actors. Beautiful, beautiful and beautiful. Go and see it.

Review title: Great movie, especially FOR PEOPLE WHO LIKE MUSICALS
Review_body: I really enjoyed watching this movie. A great musical! Another great movie with Nicole Kidman - as imho "Eyes Wide Shut" was too.Well, there are already so many comments at imdb on this movie, which express the same feelings about this movie as I have, so there is not much to add, except:I don't think it's a movie for people who don't like musicals. Maybe it is, if you do like at least romance and love stories. I think it IS a movie for people who like musicals - especially the Andrew Lloyd Webber-style ones:"Moulin Rouge!" is very Webber-stylish. If you like musicals such as "Phantom of the Opera", "Cats" or "Evita" or Michael Kunze and Sylvester Levay's musical "Elisabeth" you will like "Moulin Rouge!", that's for sure.

You laugh, you cry, you sit in wonderment as they, the director and the actors, throw everything at'you to make this movie special. The best part: Ewan McGregor...he gives Elton John a run for his money.The worst part: It ended.

Review title: Quite possibly the worst movie of all time!
Review_body: Baz Luhrmann makes Ed Wood look like Truffaut. At least Wood had no budget as an excuse. Luhrmann has made a movie of pseudo-pop style and absolutely no substance, a piece of frivolous camp which makes the fatal mistake of taking itself seriously. You are better off renting Rocky Horror Picture Show and watching an honest work of cinema.The film is a derivative, cliche-ridden two-hour music video. It has little to do with the real Moulin Rouge, either in setting, history, or people. Yes, we see Monte Martre and a red windmill, but they are scarcely recognizable after the computer animators got through with them.The script is absolutely dreadful, with no perceptible distinction between scenes of comedy and attempted pathos. The only clues we are given by the director are via his knee-jerk invocation of passe cinematic devices, like when doomed heroine Kidman repeatedly falls to the floor in skip-frame slow-mo. Otherwise, the characters whoosh around with cartoon sound effects, like Wile E. Coyote, making them less than one-dimensional -- a fractal dimension of about 0.3, perhaps."Moulin Rouge" will probably be remembered in film history as the apex of the "auteur gone wild with cash" period of the turn of the 21st century. It is destined to be shown in film schools as one of the finest examples of how not to make a movie.

Moulin Rouge has no unique or original story.From the start of time people talk of great loves that simply can't have a happy ending.What Moulin Rouge is all about, is a pandemonium a colours and scenes,a really divine soundtrack and an excellent cast.Furthermore it isn't just a boring,usual,sloppy film with a dull sky and some poor people crying all the time about their fate.Everything is happening so fast and you enjoy the crazy rythms of the ballet or the many funny qoutes and comical scenes.I think that it's the first true musical that is made after a long long time.And if your are in love you just can't stay untouched by this movie.

Review title: The Greatest Thing In The World...
Review_body: I remember when I sat down on my confortable chair that I could've ever imagined that this movie were going to be such a great "spectacular spectacular" as it is. First of all, I'd like to say that I've never been a fan of neither Ewan nor Nicole, but now I've realized that I have underestimated them. I was really astonished by the surprisingly great performance they made. My first impression when I saw and, above all, listen Ewan's "My gift is my song // and this one's for you", was that I, as Satine did, was going to fall in love with him. Later on I decided that they were the most enamoured couple in the world. Secondly I've gotta say that the Zidler's "Like A Virgin" has been, for me, one of the most funny times I've enjoyed in a since ever. And, what about the rest of the film? The Greatest Thing In The World...

A great story, an extraordinary soundtrack,the most beautiful city of the world: Paris. All that is Moulin Rouge! Nicole Kidman (the courtesan Satine) and Ewan McGregor (the english and poor writer Christian) are an explosive couple! See it, love it!!!!

Review title: Thank-you Baz, Ewan, Nicole, cast and crew
Review_body: Many of the other users have successfully captured my feelings about "Moulin Rouge", so I'll limit my comments to a simple Thank-you.To Baz Luhrmann, the entire production crew, Ewan McGregor, Nicole Kidman and the rest of the cast...Thank-you for the spectacularly, wonderful GIFT of Moulin Rouge!!  This is one movie I'll never forget and shall treasure as an all time favorite for years to come.I highly recommend this movie!!

Amazing costumes, amazing sets, amazing songs.  My favourite movie in ages. Loved the soundtrack! - Bought it the day I saw the move!  It blasts constantly out of my stereo.  See this movie - Ewan and Nicole are fantastic!

Review title: a TRUE feast for the senses
Review_body: This is by far the best movie I have seen since 1999.  I wanted to see it since I saw the first trailer simply due to my affinity for musicals, but I had no idea what I was in for.  It was the best musical every put to screen. They managed to capture all the theatrical elements while still effectively employing cinematic elements.  And Ewan MacGregor's voice should not be ignored any longer.  He was born to sing.  And as we already knew he is one heck of an Actor.  I was never a big Nicole Kidman fan, but she blew me away as well.  And with a supporting cast of relative unknowns (save John Leguizamo) they all played their parts to a tee.  Mr. Leguizamo showed us his voice talents as well.  Again totally unexpected.See this movie.  For your own good and to help perpetuate movies like it.

Review title: I feel very sorry for the film that I see next - this is wonderful!
Review_body: Visually stunning, it embraces the artificiality of its approach (never apologising for it) this is a heady film of verve and excitement. If not always hitting the mark bang on, it is never dull, never pretentious and never less than whole-hearted. Completely exuberant, I left with a smile, and more importantly I couldn't stop thinking about it for days afterwards. This review is everything the film isn't - see it.

This is the most colorful movie experience I've ever seen. I love it. To combine singed dialogue, complex computer animated scenes, thrusting mass dancing, wonderful absinthe-smelling insanity and make it all into a viewable movie - that's amazing. I can't wait for director Baz Luhrmann's next projects to come."It's a little bit funny - this feeling inside..."

This was definitely the best film i've seen all year - visually stunning! They managed to pull off a love story without making it corny and the characters were hilarious.   This is the first truly original film in ages - perfectly fusing old and new and many different genres.  There's  great music to suit almost every taste and most importantly - Ewan is fine!!!!

Review title: Moulin Rouge is The Matrix of musicals.
Review_body: Fast, brash, and relentless in sound and image. Nicole Kidman is a diamond in the dark, rough setting of this fin-de-surreal Montmartre. With a marvelous cast and endless surprises, this film takes you where no musical has gone before. Enjoy the trip.

Review title: Who needs a plot when you can have Truth, Beauty, Freedom and Love?
Review_body: This film has been slated by numerous people for a lack of originality and a feather-weight plot. Both of these criticisms I find hard to fathom. For one thing, I can guarantee that you have never seen a movie like this before, and are unlikely to see anything quite like it again. For another, the entire genre of love stories isn't exactly groaning with stunning and complex plot lines, so why should this one suddenly have to be judged by some monumental standard, particularly when it has so much else to offer?What makes 'Moulin Rouge' so special is not only the much discussed pace of the opening twenty minutes, or the way in which the perfectly chosen songs are fused and reworked into each other and the story, but the performances of the entire cast, from the evident enjoyment they display in the early ensemble scenes through to the love scenes between Ewan McGregor (who has a smile to die for) and Nicole Kidman, both of whom look stunningly beautiful and have real chemistry (they CAN sing too).The film also manages to avoid the law of diminishing returns, with each musical number or emotional twist being bigger/better/funnier/sadder than the last, no mean achievement when you consider the scale of the opening.I don't want to give away any details, so I'll leave it there and just urge everyone to see this film for themselves because it really is worth it - funny, sad, entertaining, overwhelming and very touching. Who needs a hefty plot when faced with all of that?

Review title: No words can describe the feeling
Review_body: No words can describe the feeling that I felt as I sat in the theater watching this movie.  I usually don't write reviews because a movie doesn't move me to.  This movie obviously did.  You were so sympathetic and urging to the romance going on in the movie nothing else mattered.  Ewan and Nicole made it ever so more wonderful as the perfect match.  Their chemistry was like magic and so was the acting.  In fact all of the acting was magnificent and you really appreciate it in a film with so many emotions like this one.Again I have to applaud on the directing and color used in the film.  It pulled you in entirely and considering what this film is about, thats pretty important.  It was all so beautifully well done, there couldn't of been any mistakes.  Kudos to everyone for their singing.  I loved it and plan to get the soundtrack as soon as possible.A beautiful movie that reached deep down, and touched my soul.  See it as soon as possible.

Frenetic MTV style adaption of a love story, pandering to that demographic. Colorful with great  music, but just too silly. Story doesn't hold the energy of this film together. One of these films that  came close to being truly different enough to define a genre (like Matrix) but seriously flawed and therefore comes off poorly.

This movie was like a wild rollercoaster ride in the beginning with a fast pace and striking camera angles.  The music is beautifully arranged and can Ewan sing!!!!  I saw it on Monday and was back again on Thursday and loved it just as much the second time.  Even with a sad ending, I left the theatre energized.  Simply wonderful.

There aren't really any words I could use to describe the experience of seeing Moulin Rouge for the first time, but I will try.Baz Luhrmann is known films that distance the audience from reality by use of dance (Strictly Ballroom), language (Romeo + Juliet), and music here in Moulin Rouge.  Yet in all of his films, the music conveys the meaning and the depth of emotion of the scene far better than just dialogue alone.Some people have criticized Moulin Rouge for its use of non-period songs, but in my opinion, the music is what brings the emotional story of Satine and Christian to life.  Luhrmann draws upon songs familiar to us--ones likely to tug at our personal heart strings and call up memories of our reactions to the songs--and interweaves them spectacularly to amplify the feelings going on at the time.  I couldn't imagine any sort of music that could define the particular feel of the Moulin Rogue club scene better than the mix of "Lady Marmalade," "Teen Spirit" and the "Can Can."  It gives a sense of the spectacular, the thrill, the eroticism, and the bigger-than-life sensation, to which defies description.  The Roxanne tango sequence was exceptional, using both the dramatic situations of the characters and the expertly woven dance sequence together, and using the music to build it into one the most brilliant sequences of cinema I've seen in a long time.The images of the film are as breathtaking as the musical scope.  The first half rushes by in an absinthe-induced dream, where the people and situations seem bigger and brighter, and the hallucinations are just as real as the people.  The style of the drab outer Parisian world seems to be cut from the same cloth as the early films and the degaurre-type photography, giving the sense of the old and the classic, but also the sense that the outer, older, non-bohemian world is somehow out-dated to the colorful, larger-than-life underworld of the Moulin Rouge.  And then, just as the theatre of the period was beginning to, the style swings from spectacle to more realistic.  Yet even these more down-to-earth scenes have visually exceptional and other-worldly quality.  As for the acting, I think that as a whole, the ensemble cast did a fabulous job, getting back to the styles of acting at the time, when pratfalls and circus-like conditions were the norm.As to the plot, I've heard many people call it "fluff," so to speak.  The plotline may be simplified, but the story--true love--is something that every human being longs for deep inside.  True love, in its most basic form, doesn't need fancy trappings or complicated situations, just as most of the emotions racing around inside our hearts.  It's simple, pure, and uncomplicated.  And this simple love story, conveyed through a brilliant score and heart-felt acting, has carried away so many people with its scope. That scope doesn't necessarily come from wrinkles in the plotline, but from the scope of the human heart and our capacity to believe in true love.I think that Baz Luhrmann and his team have creating a trancendant piece of literature that has touched many people already, and will most likely be rewarded come Oscar time, whether or not the rest of entertainment year picks up steam.In closing, I would urge you to see it, and appreciate it for whatever it means to you.

Baz & Co's Moulin Rouge is like oxygen; it lifts us up where we belong! Really, the IMDB ratings and the comments say it all. Moulin Rouge received some mixed reviews in the US, but don't let that stop you seeing this while you can! Anyone picking apart the plot totally misses the point. Anyone "mauled" or "bewildered" by their first experience really just has to see it again. It just gets BETTER AND BETTER. Like so many, I'll never get enough of this film; it feels like the best I've ever seen. Unlike for most films, getting the DVD will be a truly treasured moment, not just a nice way to test out the sound system. Short of heartfelt song, words really don't suffice.

Review title: Visually stunning, emotionally captivating, musically brilliant.
Review_body: One of the most amazing motion picture experiences to be had. The cast delivers magically from top to bottom, leads, supporting leads, dancers, all.  Nicole and Ewan prove beautiful and incredibly talented, musically and visually. John Leguizamo transforms himself magically. The directing is inspiring, cinematography is tantalizing. The use of color, texture, perspective and device is clever and entrancing. Thank you Baz for an intense experience that reminds me of the reason I'm a part of this industry.  As an artist, as a person.  Do NOT miss this movie.

When I saw the previews for this movie I thought it was a movie I would fall in love with.  Unfortunately the movie was NOTHING like the previews, at least the ones I saw.  For the first 15 minutes of the movie i thought this was going to be fabulous.  I even thought the use of Nirvana's song when first at the Moulin Rouge was a nice touch, the song was well used and appropriate.  Soon after that everything went to pot.  This movie was an attempt at a modernization of La Boheme...  La Boheme is a fabulous piece of literature.  A few years back a show came out on Broadway called RENT. This was an absolutely wonderful show, a rock musical with an entirely original score. Moulin Rouge was an insult to both La Boheme and Rent.
Aside from Beautiful costumes (which most sequences went entirely too fast to even catch a good glimpse of) this movie has few redeeming qualities. The plot is shallowed, cheesed out and lacking and the whole story brought to an elementary level.  It seems perhaps Luhrman used the renditions of 80s songs to gain the interest of younger generations that might not have gone to see the film if they knew it was a musical all its own.  Gilbert and Sullivan style 80s songs do not a good movie make.  If they had went to the trouble to make an original score I would have been impressed.  Seeing the list of people he had working on the movie there was more than enough creative people that that movie could have had original score.  Instead the butchered hit songs from a previous decade.  It was a show of bad judgment or cowardice of attempting a modern musical on it's own two feet.I truly appreciated Baz Luhrman's version of Romeo and Juliet.  It was good not only in art direction, but in modernizing a masterpiece as well. Luhrman did Not live up to his potential.

Review title: How wonderful life is now you're in the world
Review_body: I suppose you can love this movie... or hate it. But for me it's one of the greatest movies in the world. The colors (the chaotic spinning images as Christian enters the Moulin Rouge for the first time), the music (The combination of songs in the elephant love medley...How do you get the Idea they could go together SO well!), the acting but most of all the cinematography is just perfect: The flying hats, the singing moon (isn't it sweet), the green fairy (maybe there are some reasons to change my mind and become a lesbian... :-)no, just joking )... But also the cuts and camera and angles... Every detail is just perfect! I went into this movie several times and I can say only one thing: The intensity of the experience was bigger every time. You can just forget everything around you and get drowned into it. So really, the only thing I can say is, "how wonderful life is, now it's in the world".

I really did enjoy watching this film, but i would be hesitant to reccomend it to an unsuspecting audience.  The plot was incredibely banal, a golden hearted hooker meets lovelorn poet story.  Which will triumph in the end "True Love" or "Love of Money"?  The suspense might actually get to you, if weren't for the exceedingly effected acting style of the two main characters.  Not to say that all the acting is awful, John Leguizamo and Jim Broadbent were fantastic in their supporting roles, as were most of the other minor characters. Once i stopped paying attention to the plot and the lovers, however, i really enjoyed the film.  In addition to Baz Luhrman's eclectic genius, Something must be said for the absolute neon brilliance of Catherine Martin, the production designer (who also did such a fantastic job with Baz's other films, Romeo+Juliet and Strictly Ballroom)as well as the cinematographer Donald McAlpine.  The world they created was absolutely beautiful to watch. Everything visually was stunning to the utmost degree. However, while the gaudy decadence of the set and frantic editing pace appealed to me, it may overwhelm some audience members.  As a rule of thumb, if you don't like fast paced jumpy editing sequences (think MTV or Baz's other big hit Romeo+Juliet), you proboly won't enjoy the visual effects of this film. As a musical i couldn't decide if this made the cut.  Certainely the opening brothel number was fast-paced and exciting, but the majority of the rest of the songs were all sappy love song clips which i thought fell a bit flat. I just didn't feel the excitment of that opening song was ever recaptured throughout the rest of the film.

Review title: Does Baz have a machine that reads my dreams?
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is not going to be accepted by a lot of people.That is not a fact, nor is it my wish, it is my greatest fear.  I loved Moulin Rouge, on a level that is hard to articulate.  And while there were bits that bothered me, such as the giant gun hitting the E. Tower, on the whole it is wonderfully done.It holds one thing above all summer movies this year, it is 98% unique!  The 2% of it that isn't unique is so obscure that only the well read will recognize it.Please go see this movie, please take as many people as you can.

I just got back from seeing this incredible movie!  Can't say enough about it - it was perfect!  If you see ONE movie this year, let it be Moulin Rouge!  And, don't let the fact that it's a musical scare you off.  This is like NO musical you've ever seen.  Kidman and McGregor were perfectly cast, as was everyone else!!  The direction was perfect.  The acting was.....were they acting???  I was so lost in the story, I wasn't aware of any acting. The cinematography - spectacular!  Superb editing and continuity!  This movie is an emotional, visual and sensual feast and, without a doubt, one of the finest films I've ever seen.  I'm still stunned from the brilliance and originality of the movie.  As another "reviewer" said, see this on the biggest screen you can find.  (I saw it at an Imax.) Don't wait for the video release - it MUST be seen in a theatre and the bigger, the better! I've never reviewed a movie here before and probably won't again.  Usually, I can identify some element of a movie tht could be improved upon but not with Moulin Rouge.  10 out of 10!!!!Thanks for listening!

Thank you thank you thank you for this gorgeous piece of work! It is so inspiring and life-affirming that someone put so much energy and money and imagination into making this movie so extravagantly, magnificently beautiful. I've already been twice and will probably go back. People will still be watching this with delight 50 years from now, when most of what's in theaters now is long forgotten.

Review title: A film that will take your breath away.
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is the most touching film I´ve seen in the last ten years.Music makes you feel if you can fly. Ewan & Nicole do believe what they say and sing.It´s the only way that the audiencie do believe the same. Luhrmann gave us a gift. Viv

Review title: Baby Do It . . . One More Time . . .
Review_body:
Absolutely fantastic. Fantastic as defined in the dictionary.
The quantum leap beyond Cabaret and All That Jazz.  The medium was used to it's fullest. MR presented highly effective visuals via camera work and cutting - that could not be replicated in a stage production.   But scene after scene was  presented with a unique perspectives that also captured the energy and intimacy of live theatre.  The ultra tight close-ups - left you in a space where you expected to hear the chorus sweat.
Nicole Kidman; to die for. :-)   Ian McGregor's last scene with Kidman - - you would have thought that he was being cast out of Eden. The audience I saw this with, (a full house) applauded  - not only at the end -   but also on several occasions during the movie at the end of song and dance numbers. Eye candy; brain food; heart moving.  What a beautiful piece of work.!!!!!!!!!!!   Go see it before it disappears from the big screen.  Go go go go go  . . . .
TBP

Review title: Cinematic masterpiece: a mesh of colour, movement and vision
Review_body: This film, definitely one of Baz Lurhmann's finest, is a brilliant combination of all the elements that make a good film. I'll keep this review short as you really should just go experience it for yourself, but I want to say that it is undoubtedly a piece of cinema history. The style of the photography, the art direction, the performances, and, yes...the music all combine in a surprisingly moving film. Make your own mind up over this one, and don't just listen to what others say. It must be seen before it can be liked or disliked.

Because of my early birthday, I heard the ost before seeing the movie (it was a birthday gift from one of my friends). After hearing that amazing cd, I couldn't wait untill i saw the movie. Who'd thought that a movie about a city that I absolutely hate would make me feel they I do. But Buzz Luhrmann did the movie so... extraordinary. Listening to a 1900 singer singing "material girl" or to a pimp singing "like a virgin" just made me an addict to this awesome movie. Tough the reaction of many people (among them: My parents) wasn't too enthusiastic, and some even left it in the middle- I still believe that it is one of the best movies created ever, and the Oscars will soon prove me right.

Review title: This the movie for movie lovers.
Review_body: Great concept. Great story. Superb acting. Since the first opening scene your are taken into another world with such energy  and power that it is impossible to resist. You will be hypnotize by the color the beauty and the music  that surrounds you. This a great movie going experience,  you are submerged in the under world of Paris in the end of the 19th Century, where the only revolution happening is that of artist striving to express themselves through their art.  Watch it!, that is all I can say, I've seen this film twice and both times every time I look behind me people had a huge smile of satisfaction on their faces.

Review title: Not worth viewing (if you happen to like movies better than videoclips)
Review_body: I went to see this movie with a great lot of aprehension. Having seen previously Romeo+Juliet, by the same director, I feared that his interesting ideas were again to be drowned in his visual incontinency. I was wrong: Moulin Rouge does not have a single idea to be drowned anywhere, just pure, empty, incontinency. William Shakespeare was not there to help the director out of his visual mess. Everything that could be bought by money (acting, art direction, costumes) is very good. But not a single idea, or a passion, or any of that sort, dares to surface in this long and boring piece. Curious enough for a movie that stammers about the difference between prostitution and love.

I thought this film was absolutely awesome. There was so much to take in, that I need to go and see it again. The love seductive scene between Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor was the best in cinematic history, in my opinion. And the music was awesome.As you can see, I was a BIG fan of this film and I recommend it to everyone. Some people might see it just as a love story, but there is just so much in it, that it will appeal to all types.

I just come from the cinema and i feel still embarrassed from this wonderful movie. Ewan McGregor und Nicole Kidman deliver a strong and powerful performance combined by a superb soundtrack.Best movie i´ve seen this year.

Review title: This film reassures me that creativity is yet alive in Hollywood!
Review_body: I saw Moulin Rouge the other day and I have to say I was taken by the sheer "Spectacular Spectacular" production that was before me. I am a young film buff and have grown tired of the uninspired, money-driven stories that flood the local multiplexes, so a movie as original and exciting as this is a breathe of fresh air. I had no idea Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor could sing! Just the sheer splendor of the movie had me on cloud nine for the entire length of the picture. (For some reason I could watch Nicole Kidman do anything onscreen for days without getting tired.) Everything was excellent. In the season of mindless shoot-em ups and sci-fi blunders, and would-be comedies, it's refreshing to see a creative movie bold enough to tango with the likes of Pearl Harbor and The Mummy Returns.

This movie was one of the most beautifully filmed, acted, and directed films i have ever seen. I have seen very little films with this obvious amount of passion from every aspect of it. Everyone truly put all their blood, sweat tears and souls into this project.  It was a risk but a risk well worth it.

How can words express how I feel about this movie?  For anyone who believes there is such a thing in love this movie will emotionally move you to unimaginable heights.  Everything about this movie is awesome - the actors, the music, the story, the cinematography, the costumes, the ideas, the humor, etc...Ewan McGregor quickly rose in the chart of my favorite actors. I love him so now, he is a wonderful actor with an amazing voice that I was more than surprised to hear.  Nicole too.  She can sing and she does it well.  Who knew?  Tom maybe.  :)  John Leguizamo is hilarious...he hasn't played such a funny part since Too Wong Foo. The scene where Christian sings "Your Song" to Satine is wonderfully beautiful and romantic. This movie didn't even have to try, it had me at hello. :) This movie sends the viewer on a roller coaster ride of emotions and it is a ride that I will never forget. If you have ever been in love or wish you were, see this movie.  It's the way love should be.  "The greatest thing you will ever know is to love and be loved in return."  My heart rejoices as I reminisce.

Moulin Rouge is to 2001 what Gone With the Wind was to 1939.  It is beautiful, original, thought-provoking, and incredible.  Baz Luhrmann proves his genius for writing and directing through this work of cinematic excellence.  The wondrous combination of music with artwork with acting with camera drove me to laughter, tears, and goosebumps, all at just the right moments.  The film achieved at every turn the director's dream of transmitting an emotion from a screen and speakers to the very soul of an audience.  McGregor, Kidman, Broadbent, Roxburg, and Leguizamo meshed in a harmony not seen by me since Hunt and Nicholson in As Good as it Gets.  The characters, the actors, and the acting style fit together perfectly to produce a beautiful film about love, life, and loss.  Never before has a film enthralled me to such an extreme.  Not only a must-see, but a must-see-again-and-again-and-again.

Unfortunately I don't know english so well and I cannot express totally the extraordinary emotions this movie gave me. I've seen it the first time e then more, and another time again... e so on... Every time I discovered something new. I give all my thanks to Baz Luhrmann for this special gift full of music and colors, a joy for our ears and eyes, but first of all... for our hearts. In the name of beauty, freedom and love...

Review title: Ewan smiling is to die for!
Review_body: Ewan McGregor was never one of my favorite movie stars, but after seeing him in this movie I am definitely one of the converted. Star Wars was great..but this movie...his singing...his smiles...his passion...very very excellent.Of course Nicole Kidman [although too thin] was also beautiful in this movie...set design is more glorious than any movie this year for sure...but much more elaborate than any movie ever possibly.

Review title: I hate musicals, but I loved Moulin Rouge
Review_body: Let me start off by saying, I hate musicals.  Semi-interesting plot that is only slowed down by bad music and cheesy acting.  Moulin Rouge, however made me see it twice.  When I first heard about the movie and watched the preview, I liked the way it looked.  It instantly reminded me of something out of a Tim Burton movie.  When I saw that Ewan McGregor was in it, I was even more excited.  However, in the first 25 minutes, I was beginning to worry that the movie would turn out to be what it was: a french musical. But it significantly calmed down afterwards and room for acting was allowed. The acting of the film was some of the best acting I've seen, especially for a musical.  The music, the mood, the feelings that it inspired, all made me enjoy this movie.  I am very sorry that more people didn't give Moulin Rouge a chance.  Many of the bad reviews that it recieved on the IMDB were from people who walked out on it in the first 30 minutes.  Any fan of modern music and who loves a good story about love should see this movie.  Oh, and if you do see it, try not to take it too seriously.  It is art after all.

Review title: Incredible, outstanding, a tour de force!
Review_body: From the opening credits to the last frame, Moulin Rouge was so visually spectacular, imaginative and surreal, I was devastated by it. I have never seen a movie so visually pleasing. The performances by Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor were terrific, touching and funny. The whole cast was superb. The popular music set in Paris 1900 was incredible. I highly recommend this film. Sit back and enjoy ... you won't believe your eyes.

Review title: One of my favourite films, ever
Review_body: This film knocked me out. The amazing sets, imaginative use of the music and the excellent cast were all brilliant. Turning "Roxanne" into a tango was inspired. Loved the dancing,too. I've read reviews that said Ewan McGregor was the weak link - UTTER TOSH!! When Christian was pleading with Satine not to sleep with the duke, I was in tears. As for Nicole - she was beautiful - and no, I'm not gay!A hugely entertaining film. Loved it

Review title: Never have I seen such a delightful spectacle...
Review_body: This movie would be wonderful, whether it had no picture or no sound. Without the picture, you will miss the BEST cinematography (in my opinion) ever, but, you will witness a touching, musical, emotional, and sometimes funny story of Satine, the courtesan, and Christian, the poor writer. Without the sound, you WILL see the cinematography,but you will probably be able to figure out what is happening.  However, you would miss many original songs, and clever modern day medleys.  This movie is wonderful! GO SEE IT!

I've never seen anything like this ever on film! Spectacular Spectacular indeed! So much energy and emotion. And the wonderful use of music that I've come to expect from Baz Luhrman. Love is like oxygen...love is a many-splendoured thing...love lift's us up where we belong...all you need is love!Given, the general ill-fated love is nothing new, but Luhrman has certainly placed his mark on the genre with Moulin Rouge! A must see which is destined to become a classic.

Now, I'm only 23 years old.  So I'm not criticizing this movie because I wasn't raised on MTV.  Nor am I a conservative 23 year old.  My "recent" modern-style movies are "Requiem for a Dream" and "Fight Club."  Nor am I a fan of depressing, dreary movies.  I also like romantic, period pieces like `Sense and Sensibility' and `A Room With A View" (Which both of them I also consider funny and witty comedies of manners). I'm also a fan of Luhrmann's "Romeo and Juliet." I guess generally like hyper-camera work and romance to be separate from each other.  I associate dark lighting and fast camera work with darker issues.  I admit, I like compartmentalization.
"Moulin Rouge" to me was a big disappointment.  To me, `Being John Malkovich' is a creative movie because it was creative visually and plot-wise.  `Moulin Rouge' is creative visually-MUCH more so than BJM I add-but the plot line  is rather cliché.  And the character's names Christian and Satine?  Can you be more cheesy? Or does Baz mean Christian and Satan? Now, that's intriguing.

BRILLIANT CINEMATOGRAPHY!!! Kidman and McGregor ably handle singing duties. Roxburgh is appropriately menacing, lead actors are utterly charming, nice pathos. However, migraine sufferers beware as music volume is TOO LOUD!! And nobody needs LIKE A VIRGIN to be performed  for so long!!!!!

Although I've been a professional and semi-professional musician  for over twenty years and an avid movie fan for over thirty years, most musicals have always bored me.  Except for Jesus Christ Superstar, I don't think I've ever seen any more than once.  That is until today.  Moulin Rouge grabbed a hold of me and would not let go!  Only five or ten minutes into the movie I knew I was in for a real treat.  By the time we had reached the half-way point, I knew that I already wanted to see it again.  And again I did.  Immediately following the conclusion of the movie, I ran to the lobby to purchase another ticket.  While I had heard Nicole Kidman sing a few bars before, nothing prepared me for the real talent she has.  Furthermore, to listen to Ewan McGregor sing was worth the price of admission alone.  Not only does this movie make great use of modern music (some very modern and some recently modern) but it utilizes musical bits and pieces and storylines from other movies, plays, and even operas.  You'll even find lyrics from songs you may know being sung to different melodies and to other familiar tunes as well.  Watch closely, you may even see a few parodies of some other familiar characters, too.  It seems the more you know about music, movies, and the theatre, the more fun you'll have with this wonderful gem.  This one's the next in line for my video collection!

The easiest way to describe this film is that this movie has Attention Deficit Disorder and only very rarely does it take its ritolin. And when it does slow down, the movie still isn't good. Most of the film is comprised of meaningless cuts at an extremely rapid pace so that things are not on the screen for more than half a second.  And this just hurt my eyes.  Especially because the colors are vibrant and really leap out.  Its like watching a music video which is already too fast on fast forward.When the film is not going off at this crazy pace, it is then comprised of extreme close-ups.  The camera is so close on peoples faces that most of the time they do not even fit on the screen.  And for some of the people, like the owner of Moulin Rouge, it is way too close and down right scary.  A problem that I have heard most people had with the movie, if they had a problem with it, was the music.  And that was one of the few tolerable things with it.  Unlike the absolutely ridiculous music of A Knight's Tale, this music is incorporated into the movie well.  At least here they make it like the music is original, even though it isn't.  Don't get me wrong, I didn't enjoy the music, but its at least tolerable.There is not much good about this film.  The story is 100% unoriginal and the film hurts your eyes.  The tagline says that Club Moulin Rouge is an experience you will never forget.  And that's true, Club Moulin Rouge is an experience you will never forget, but not because it was good, but because you will get ADD from watching it.

To start with, its directed by Baz Lurhman so you know its going to be good...
But I never expected to be obsessed with this film 11 years after I first watched it for a school project!Considering the bohemian/absinthe induced-vibe that makes it all so unrealistic and fantastical, from a signing moon, to the green fairy played by Minogue; the talented actors, Kidman, McGregor and Broadbent are stunning and make it all very believable. You find yourself routing for the protagonists and detesting the antagonist - just as any movie should make it's audience feel.It is so full off mixed emotions, all the way through. It is somber to start, with a beautiful opening sequence featuring establishing shots and the wonderful character Toulouse, played magnificently by Leguizamo! Haunting, funny and tear-jerking, it really is not to be missed!

Moulin Rouge! is the best film I saw after many years, I haven't felt so excited over a film for a really long time. Baz Luhrmann managed to create such a unique and incomparable movie and he took a big risk: he created a fantastic world beyond the spectator's imagination. You feel like you're a part of the story, while the characters are likeable, (well, except for the Duke of course) and you find yourself rooting for Christian and Satine's, up until a point, secret love affair, with the hope that they'll get their chance for a happy ending. You get attached to the characters while there are quite a few humorous and pleasant scenes.Nicole Kidman gives an exquisite and unforgettable performance in the role of the most famous Moulin Rouge courtesan, she shines and she gives her everything to the role: she sings, she dances, she cries, she even shows her comical side. Ewan McGregor is a true gem, you can't help but fall in love with him when he sings to Elton John's Your Song. He incarnates a challenging role and he has, without a doubt, one of the most beautiful voices I've ever heard. Both of the protagonists go beyond their limits, while their chemistry is surpassing and very believable.The soundtrack is also a very strong part of the film, specifically Come What May and the chilling El Tango De Roxanne, both of them causing undescribable feelings to the viewer. As for El Tango De Roxanne, I never thought that a five-minute scene had the ability to be a true masterpiece. For me it's one of the best scenes in cinematic history as it goes from the tango, the rhythm, the infinite feelings it causes to the pain in Satine's sacrifice so she can turn her home into a better place. It makes you feel a hundred emotions all at once and you feel your heart racing, goosebumps and tears welling up your eyes as you feel for the heroine who has to pretend once again so she can make the Duke believe what he wants to believe.The entire movie is a breath of fresh air between movies with similar scenarios and the director breaks ground with his innovative approach despite the difficulties during filming. It deserved the Oscars it got and it causes a rollercoaster of emotions to the viewer, it even makes you want to fall in love so deeply that you act like a complete fool and sing your heart out on top of an elephant. Lastly, apart from the spectacle and the beautiful, colourful costumes that steal the show, it offers many beautiful messages such as the fact that it's better to have love and loss than no love at all and that, as Christian greatly put it, "the greatest thing you'll ever learn is just to love and be loved in return".

Review title: excess is not always a virtue
Review_body: so many people i know really liked this movie. unfortunately, i am not one of them. but at least i know why, too much. baz luhrmann, brilliant director, a visionaire, i just wish he knew when to say when. my impression of this film was that he felt the need to take every cool idea he ever had and put them all in the same movie. as a result of this overkill i found it difficult to pay attention to what was going on because i never really knew what was the intended center of attention, as opposed to extraneous contributions. had there been half as much...crap in this movie i would have loved it. it has a great story, it is a brilliant idea, and an amazing cast. unfortunately when all put together, with about a dozen other factors of equal intensity, it is overkill. like wearing plaid and polka-dots...and then putting a bright red bow on your head.

Moulin Rouge, despite its somewhat ecstatic beginning, is a genuine vision of the Bohemian ideals so often revered in the film: Truth, Beauty, Love, and Freedom. The film flows with such shocking beauty heart-wrenching honesty that it is difficult to remember yourself throughout the course of the story. A delightfully eccentric orgy of images and sounds, Moulin Rouge makes one cry from every pore in their body, makes them long for love and reality, despite its surreal and imaginative basis. The movie sets its own standards and guidelines. Baz Lurhmann is truly brilliant, and his creativity truly shines through this shimmering jewel of art and passion.

This is a visually stunning film! It is an incredible treat for the senses. This one must be seen on a BIG screen with BIG sound to be properly appreciated. The soundtrack and performances are wonderful, but this movie gets highest marks for production design and direction. The unique, fantastical world created here is reminiscent of the magic done by Jeunet and Caro but with some Peter Pan dust thrown in. The story is essentially very short and seems stretched out, but the extra space is filled with lots of moving fun. This is a period piece that doesn't stay in any one period. The special effects seem groundbreaking, and the refreshing thing is that the big budget F/X aren't used for car chases, fighting scenes or aerial acrobatics. It's high action romance. Highly recommended.

In my opinion you should watch this movie, because it describes life. Director's point of view on life is schopenhauerian: suffer is a part of it and we have to accept that. There is also another part of the movie, when everybody seems to believe in love: i think the final message is not that. It is not a movie about love, freedom; but about life, suffering and pain.

I really have mixed feelings about this one. It truly is a film like no other I have ever seen. The cinematography is absolutely incredible, no doubt about it; whatever artistic Oscars the film procured were well-deserved. The world that the film creates is stunning and the amazingly free movement of the camera solidifies spatial relations and brings the different locations together into a coherent whole. It really is fantastic work. That said, I didn't like--borderline hated--the film. The vast majority of "dialogue" is actually song lyrics (often rehashed) from familiar songs of the past 30 or so years. In this, it can be said that the film is often "catchy" and certainly caused the occasional smile, but really has nothing worthwhile to say. The plot would make Walt Disney jealous of its simplicity and really has nothing to add to the traditional "boy and girl want to be together but something's blocking the way". Perhaps it could be seen to be making a societal comment in its over-intentional hodge-podge of pre-existent ideas. At any rate, I guess I shouldn't be surprised that this formula still brings about success... But it was really irritating hearing the same trite, already-familiar lyrics repeated again and again. It was a musical melodrama pumped with so much false energy that I felt embarrassed for the actors at times and just wished it would stop. The acting of the two main characters was certainly average at best. The fact that Nicole Kidman was lauded for this performance truly makes me ill. But the incidental characters in the film were mostly much more solid and interesting, especially the "manager" of Moulin Rouge. I must wrap up: visually it's absolutely stunning and certainly worth watching, but it is emotionally vacant and meaningless.

Review title: Nicole and Ewan shine in Baz's magnificent realisation of a wildly decadent past Paris!
Review_body: Baz Luhrmann's magnificent film stands as his best work to date. Utilising the very best in digital wizzardry his team has produced a most stunningly fantastical visual treat that has to be seen on the big screen to be fully appreciated; for there is so much detail in this film it is sadly diminished when viewed on even a large t.v screen. That being said it was with great pleasure the film was reviewed again in the DVD format; with a lump in my throat I again heard Nic and Ewan sing that wonderful Elephant Love Medley in DTS, experienced the raw emotion of El Tango de Roxanne and felt as if I was at the Moulin Rouge during the Can-Can sequence.The production design, sound, musical scoring, costumes all outstanding and hopefully recognised by many industry nominations. Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor head an extremely talented cast that give their all for Baz. This is the most entertaining film I have ever seen and cannot recommend it too highly to anyone looking for a stunning visual and aural feast. See it.

You'll want to see this movie more than once to take in all the beautiful and stunning images that have gone into the production. Amazing costumes, exotic and Spectacular! sets, Truth, Beauty, Freedom, Love - what more could one ask for? Music!? a little bit of everything and plenty to jog your own memories of love and lost days.  Lightens the spirit in one easy sitting.

I love movie musicals.  The first one I ever saw was "Singing in the Rain" when I was in the first grade.  I loved it, and every other musical made during the fifties; the age of movie musicals. Movie Musicals of the fifties took the favorite music of the time, put a cute plot behind it, got some people who could sing and dance, and shot the film.  The audiences loved it.  Unfortunatly, that genre of movies faded away, and the movie musical died. . . until director Baz Lurhman brought it back. Moulin Rouge, starring Ewan McGregor and Nichole Kidman, is a fantastic movie musical, with all the qualities of one.  I feel that many people are looking at it from the wrong angle.  It is a great musical, WONDERFUL singing (McGregor and Kidman both have fantastic voices), and the color and costumes are great. Lurhman combined his first two movies (Strictly Ballroom, Romeo + Juliet) and created a fabulous display of color, music, and emotion. Lurhman's sence of color is fantastic, with the two themes of Red and White sprinkled through out the movie.  There are lots of little details if one looks close enough. My one complaint is that in the Elephant Love Medley, they really didn't need the "I Will Always Love You" in there.  Blech!!

Indeed, Moulin Rouge has struck many emotions throughout the showcasing. Moulin Rouge is a collage of laughter, tears, and pain.  Words cannot describe the mastery of the set and the creative application of 20th century hints here and there.  What an awesome film!!!  Vibrant in usage of colors and definitely a tear jerker!  I give Moulin Rouge a 10!!!

One of the worst movies I've ever seen. Fast forwarded through most of it. I cannot understand how this movie received a 'Best Picture' nomination! Made me lose a whole lot of respect for the Academy!

What can i say?? Absolutely STUNNING. I went in with my doubts, i mean come on, a romance/musical?? And what's more, i was taking my 19 year old BOYFRIEND with me!! But i HAVE to tell you, SEE IT! The editing was the more beautiful work I've ever seen, and from the very first moment i was hooked! Everything from the cinematography to the directing was perfect. The world you are taken into is magical, so fantastic that this movie now rates for me AND amazingly enough, my boyfriend, as the number one greatest movie to date (alongside Requiem For A Dream). Please, if you see nothing else in the next 5 years, treat yourself to the most awesome and inspiring artwork ever to grace us with its creative and beautiful presence)!

Review title: Moulin Rouge is What Artistic Cinematography is All About
Review_body: "Spectacular, Spectacular", the bohemians in Moulin Rouge couldn't have said it better. It is a film that is equally a classic, a work of art, and a musical. It is also brilliantly made in all its aspects, it is strongly emotional, a celebration of beauty, its soundtrack is nothing less than genius, the performances are truly memorable, and it is visually outstanding. This film is an extraordinary production that can only get better every time one sees it.In Moulin' Rouge the theme and sub-themes of the story are made clear by the characters themselves, "Beauty, Freedom, Truth, and Love", of course with love as the main theme. Christian, played by Ewan McGregor, is obsessed with love even though he has never fallen in love himself, the main plot revolves around his ideals about love. Throughout the movie Satine and Christian fight for love only to prove that it conquers all, as they beautifully play it in the song "Come What May". This is their secret song, and no matter what obstacles their love will be stronger than adversity. The whole film revolves around these ideals of the bohemian revolution, or better said: "the children of the revolution". So many films have been made in honor of love, yet this one stands out because it pays tribute to love with art, music, and consequently passion. It is impossible not to fall in love watching this film even if it is for the thousandth time.The story line of the movie gives allusion to several classics, such as "La Bohème", "La Traviata", and "Orpheus in the Underworld" (IMDB Trivia), yet it stands out for its originality. Another movie which it alludes to is, a stronger classic than the latter, is "Romeo and Juliette". Even if the audience is as cynical as Satine, Christian and the rest of the bohemians will draw them into romantic bliss.Even though the movie is a Tragedy it is made into greatness by the very basic ideals of the Greek Tragedy: it had to be made with such perfection and beauty that the spectator would walk away with a duality of emotion, both sadness for the heartbreaking outcome of the story and joy for the admiration of what they have just witnessed. What is more, whenever a movie starts with the ending the viewer can foresee that the film will be so great that is doesn't need a shocking ending, the movie's story line is enough.The acting in the movie was also worthy of awe, all five main actors, Ewan McGregor as Christian, Nicole Kidman as Satine, John Leguizamos as Toulouse, Jim Broadbent as Zidler, and Richard Roxburgh as The Duke made an incredible performance, and by performance I mean acting and singing. A couple of these actors had a previous positive reputation for their acting, however their singing will sure cause a shocking impression on the audience. The most memorable performances were those of Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman, they were so intensely in character that it is very hard to watch the movie objectively without getting absorbed into the sentiment of the film.Nevertheless, even though the singing of the actors was incredible it would have been nothing without the elaborate composition of the songs. All of the songs were covers for the most part yet it was seldom obvious. Most of the songs were individually composed of lyrics of many singers and bands and they were redone to fit the movie. These songs are so perfect for every situation that it would have been easier to compose new lyrics than to gather lines from other composers. Purchasing the soundtrack is almost as worthy of getting the movie itself.In addition, the costumes and the sets were so elaborate that they were as important to the film's success as the actors' performance, the music, and the plot. The movie takes place in Paris; yet it is a fantasy landscape of Paris that almost purposefully looks like a miniature replica, this setting adds to the fantastic world in which the film takes place. All of the inside settings are striking for their elaborateness and artistic quality, they add to the movie's creative, elegant, sexy, and dreamlike spirit.Moulin Rouge can also be described as very bizarre and this may be the reason why it does not appeal to all audiences. One of the main elements that make it so is the way the camera is used. It is not at all used in a conventional way; on the contrary, it goes to extremes so that it makes it unconventional. It is a combination of rapid tracking shots, spinning, coordination with the song (specifically in the song Spectacular Spectacular), and more. Even though the usage of the camera makes the movie very bizarre it is almost essential for its artistic structure.Many aspects such as the acting, singing, setting, costumes, use of color, camera movement, and theme, come together to make this movie into a brilliant work of art. However, as great as it is it does not appeal to everyone; because it is so unconventional it may not arise all of the emotions that it should, it may only cause confusion. Despite its unpopularity in certain groups, it is venerated by others. Moulin Rouge was the first acclaimed musical in this time and was the first of many more to come. It is also one of those movies that will be timeless and will only become better with time. Moulin Rouge can be concisely expressed as having heart.

Review title: Some people are not understanding "Moulin Rouge"...
Review_body: While scanning through the endless praises of "Moulin Rouge", I couldn't help that the reviews which criticized it were focused on one large subject:that the story of MR was completely useless and/or absurdly non-unique. Obviously, the reviewers know nothing of the filmmaker, Baz Luhrmann, or his extreme cinematic techniques that he has branded himself with as tradition. Luhrmann, previous director of "Strictly Ballroom" and "Romeo + Juliet" always uses his films as "upgrades" of previously famous stories.  "Strictly Ballroom", for example, uses the biblical tale of David and Goliath set to a ballroom showdown, while "Romeo + Juliet" gets the 90's gangster-mob upgrade in their classical Shakespeare story.  "Moulin Rouge", of course, does nonetheless with Luhrmann.  He uses a Greek mythological tale set to the crazy Bohèmian lifestyle of upper-Paris.I do not berate people for not enjoying "Moulin Rouge" (I, however, thought it was absolutely incredible), but I feel that many of these reviewers need to not only know the aspect from which the film is taking, but to watch the ENTIRE film (do not walk out of the theater and expect people to read your review with understanding) and then judge it -- do not discuss something you really do not know what you are talking about.

If someone asked me to sum up the essence of "Moulin Rouge" in one sentence, I would have to say, "an ultimate cliche with extraordinary originality."  I realize this is a contradiction, but what wasn't about this film? Outside of "My Fair Lady" I have never been able to stomach a musical, so when I went to see "Moulin Rouge" I was expecting to go to laugh at it. Strangely enough, I consistently found myself laughing with the film rather than at it (as well as crying). Every time a new scene emerged I thought, "here's my chance to scoff," but the film was able to pull me into the other direction EVERY TIME. If anyone wants to know what Post Modern is: this is it.  This film took pop culture and made it art...how is that possible? I'm still trying to figure it out.The film, first of all, cannibalizes itself. It's a story about a man writing a play based on the story as it unfolds, and he is writing out the story after the fact. So it's a story within a story within a story. But it is never confusing, surprisingly enough.  Secondly, there is a romance. How does one make a movie about a romance of this nature--very cliche--and pull it off? Ask the director and writer of the film and you'll find out.  I still can't believe I liked the romantic aspect, but I did. Thirdly, the film is a mixture of genres I haven't seen since "Blade Runner" (although I wouldn't compare the two)--a musical, comedy, tragedy, fairy tale, with some hints of film noir. Fourthly, the film, I don't think, has any original score; rather, it uses a mixture of music from the last thirty years--some so unlikely to be put together that one has to check themselves to make sure they are really hearing the song(s) they are hearing. What I find interesting about the score is that Kidman can sing "Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend" while the men below sing "Smells Like Teen Spirit," both in their original tunes, and they work together as if it was all the same song. And fifthly, the movie is obviously a parody of musicals (and parodies are almost impossible to pull of these days without being banal), which is why the mixture of music, the love story, etc. can be well received without indignant guffaws.Well, there were a couple of people who did guffaw and snicker...but they were sixteen year-old teenage girls with their boyfriends who went to go see the movie because of the Madame Marmalade video on MTV--they wouldn't know parody if Christina Aguilara told them personally. And many have been asking if McGregor and Kidman were lip syncing. Actually, no. Everyone in the film sang their own music and did it live (of course, I'm sure there was some "fiddling" around with the sound quality).Anyone with intelligence could see "Moulin Rouge" for what it is: a great film. Over the top? Yes. Silly? Yes. Contradictory? Yes. But strangely enough, it all works because it knows it is all of those things and plays off of them. I walked out of that movie thoroughly surprised at my respect for it. It was worth every dollar I spent and I'll spend it again.

Review title: A return to ideals and a value based life using a love story
Review_body: We have only seen Moulin Rouge five times so far, but I love it. I don't understand how anyone could not love it. The colors, dancing, and music are nearly overwhelming. The romance from many viewpoints is completely enjoyable. The ability of the director to bring the viewer's mind into a certain frame through the use of music that brings the viewer back to times and experiences in their own life, many times matching the storyline, is remarkable. We thoroughly enjoy this movie and plan to keep going to see and and absolutely buy it when it comes out. But, see it in the theatre, especially one with the best sound you can get. I have been so won over to Nicole Kidman by this movie. And Ewan McGregor obviously enjoys acting so much that you just want to keep watching him. The part of Toulouse was played exceedlingly well, and I feel that the scene where Toulouse speaks to Christian when Christian is lying in bed, should win an Oscar all by itself!

Review title: Moulin Rouge brings the art of film to a new level
Review_body: One of the best films of the 90's and I will tell you why. First of all, one of the most important things to remember is that this is part of Baz Luhrmann's Red Curtain series (along with Strictly Ballroom and Romeo and Juliet) in which he strives to make the audience aware that they are in fact watching a movie. He has used dancing, Shakespeare's language, and musical numbers in the three movies in the series respectively to do this. But Moulin Rouge does more. Luhrman creates a cinema in Moulin Rouge which is a feast for the eyes and a feast for the mind. He has an acute sense of spectacle in the piece. He takes the genre of "cinema" and moves it forward in. Saying that it's ok to make a musical in 2001, and ok to take the film in and out of fantasy whenever he wants. It's this pushing forward that makes the movie so great with new innovations in editing, sounds, graphics, and storytelling. It also helps that he had a fantastic cast including the wonderful talents of Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, who not only perform well on an acting plane, but sing beautifully. Even their singing style does not imitate that of the classical musicals. It is the film of the future in many ways and it starts right now.

After I saw this movie, I could think of only 2 words to describe it - CLEVER and BRILLIANT.  Nicole Kidman and Ewan MacGregor are amazing in the lead roles.  Jim Broadbent and John Leguizamo are excellent in their very funny supporting roles as well.  They can all sing, they can dance and they show such passion and emotion throughout.  The music is incredible!  I never buy soundtracks to films, but after seeing this film, I just had to have it. I have seen it twice now and would recommend this film to anyone who likes music, dancing, romance, comedy and quirky Being John Malkovich type humor. You never know Baz Luhrman is going to do next.  Being inside his mind would be the wildest ride.  The film is visually stunning from the Elephant to his take on 1900 Paris.  If you like "different" and "extraordinary" then this is the movie for you.

Review title: No Clapping but plenty of Walking...
Review_body:
Unlike the reviewer given to gushing that they have never before seen people clap at the conclusion of a film, I have. This was not one of them. A more acute observation in the theater I attended was the number of people who walked out in the first fifteen minutes.Those of us who watched the entire movie were reasonably well rewarded.The use of contemporary pop/rock lyrics as musical dialog was interesting, characters outrageous, vivid costuming and the sets reminiscent of other Art Films I've enjoyed. At the same time, the story line was a bit weak.Worth a look as pure entertainment. Pretty off beat.Enjoy.
Don

I went in without major expectations. I read many comments about the film and most of them dealt with the performance of Nicole - so I wanted to know.... In some aspects I can understand some criticism about some missing emotions in her character, but at the bottom line it was a real positive surprise. Ewan McGregor is great and the other characters are so strong!Also the colours, the cuts and the music is extraordinary.Such a great idea to bring modern songs in the time of the Moulin Rouge in the 20s.

The opening was impressive enough, little did I know the film was going to get even better. I walked out of that movie theater with my faith in Hollywood restored. It has been quite a while since I have seen a movie this good. The music is so outstanding that I wanted to get up and dance with every scene. More impressive were the shots, each one filmed as though it was a piece of artwork. The sets must have cost a small fortune. I couldn't be more pleased with this film. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD.

I think I've never written a movie review before...and certainly not in English, but I really have to say that I love this movie so much!! The plot is great, I mean, surly, sometimes it is a bit too trashy, but there is so much love in it...wow! And I can also tell you, the soundtrack is terrific! This music will definitely enchant you! And I am still deeply impressed by the voices of Nicole and Ewan. I had never thought that they could sing so well. This is one of those movies you love or you hate...and there is nothing in between. But if you believe in love and you like romantic music, great acting and costumes,... I can just recommend this movie to you!!

Like the song, this movie was Spectacular. I had wanted to see this movie for no particular reason, then I found out Nicole Kidman was in it and I had to see it. I am so glad I did. I bought the soundtrack soon afterward and I listen to it every day. This was one of Nicole's most excellent of movies. I was astonished by the fact that the stars in the movie were the singers as well. Nicole could have started a great beginning to a singing career. I believe Nicole could most definitely have the potential to start a singing career. I would hope that anyone reading this who is a fan of romance movies or even just huge fans of Nicole Kidman themselves, would treat themselves by watching Moulin Rouge!.

It's not very often a movie's visuals, music and romance stick in your head. I cannot stop thinking about Moulin Rouge!  Director Baz Luhrmann is nothing short of a genius.  The costumes, the sets, the songs, the editing, the vision...what a breath of fresh air!  Ewan and Nicole create musical magic.  I laughed, I cried, I sang along.  May this be the summer's biggest hit!  Long live Baz Luhrmann and his movie musical!

Wow!  I'm in love with this movie.  I rarely, if ever, return to the theater to see a movie for a second time.  The last time I did this I was about 10 years old and my mother gave me hell when I got home.  In the last 3 weeks, I've seen Moulin Rouge 3 times, and I still haven't tired of it.This movie gives and gives and gives, never holding back.  The combination of the beautiful sets, the story, the love songs, and the bold, bold courageous way in which all of it was done all combine to make a great movie, not just Oscar worthy, but a classic that may last years.  The set design is lush, full of brilliant eye popping colors and gorgeous sets depicting turn of 20th century Paris and the dark "underworld" of the Moulin Rouge theater.  Particularly, I loved the set in the Satine's bedroom, the vivid red and blue colors, hearts within hearts, and, of course, the elephant building where she lived.I'm not a lover of pop music, but I loved the way all of the music was used to tell the story of Satine, the courtesan, and Christian, the poet. Almost every time a song was introduced, the audience would titter as people recognized the most popular songs of the 70's 80's and 90's--which may or may not have been the movie's intent.  Nevertheless, each time this happened, I felt a playfulness here that eventually resolved itself into something deeper and more profound.  It was as if the movie was saying go ahead, let's have some fun here, but we're going to take you further than you originally expected, and I believe that Moulin Rouge did this from the very start, crescendoing to the very end, taking us deeper and deeper. Take for instance, when the song Touched Like a Virgin starts, we can't think of anything but Madonna, but upon further reflection, this song speaks so truthfully of Satine who's heart is opened for the very first time to the possibilities of love with a poor poet.  In this new context we find how well this song speaks to our feelings of open heartedness (virginity of the heart) when we are in love.Lastly, I was very taken with the story of the poet's love for the beautiful courtesan and her inner struggle between her love for him and her lust for wealth and fame.  The theme of love--the most important thing to know is to love and to know that you are loved in return--that love is at the core of our very humanity--that in spite of egoistic distractions, love is how we truly find ourselves.

Moulin Rouge was as wonderful a piece of eye candy as I've ever seen. The music was incredibly inventive, creative, and playful, and the visuals were as addictive as the "Green Fairy" that the characters regularly imbibed. Baz Lurhmann has scored another hit with the third installment of his "Red Curtain Trilogy". His flare for theater and dramatics really transfers quite beautifully to this film production. An impressive achievement! I've recommended this film to everyone that I know, and all who have seen it have loved it.

Review title: Best love story in the world
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is the most wonderful movie I have seen in a very long time. I can't believe it received some bad reviews,  because I don't have a single bad word to say about it.
