There was not one single song that would've surprised me in the movie. And yes, changing the words so they are aligned with the plot is one of the oldest tricks in the book. The fact that Moulin Rouge has been compared to some of the real musicals of our era is sickening. At least they tried to compose something new for the audience before...The plot was 90% predictable. The last 10% is made out of the scenes, which reach even deeper into the syrup than I thought was humanly possible. And when the music/dancing scenes were not powerful enough, hey, it's not a problem. By the rules of Moulin Rouge, there isn't a problem that couldn't be fixed by adding another 10 million light bulbs and flashlights, 50 extra dancers and perhaps a modulation in the song. Sorry, doesn't fix it for me.
Third of all, Nicole Kidman is beautiful, but in my opinion she really wasn't convincing as the beauty queen of Moulin Rouge.
All in all, except for the overkill of lights, fast cameras and tasteless music, Moulin Rouge didn't show anything we hadn't seen (as better versions) before. This movie surely was an unique experience for me, and I don't want to have that experience again...ever.

Review title: Moulin Rouge captures the essence of love
Review_body: 'Moulin Rouge' illustrates that one of the most important things in life is to love and be loved.  The movie is about a young man, Christian (Ewan McGregor) who travels to Paris to write about love.  Soon there after, he meets the beautiful courtesan, Satine (Nicole Kidman).  In a very Romeo and Juliet-like moment, they fall in love, but are pulled apart by outside forces.  Harold Zidler (Jim Broadbent), owner of the 'Moulin Rouge', tells Satine to make the Duke (Richard Roxburgh) believe she loves him so he'll invest in the 'Moulin Rouge'.  She tries to play both sides, but of course it catches up to her and she's forced to make a choice.  'Moulin Rouge' is directed and co-written by Baz Luhrmann ('Romeo + Juliet') and he does anything but hold back on his creative style of filmmaking.In any movie, color plays a role in how a movie is detailed.  In 'Moulin Rouge' certain colors stand out and seem to play their own part in the movie.  The color red traditionally symbolizes love and death.  The use of the color in this film is emphasizing the search of love for both Christian and Satine.  It also foreshadows the inevitable death of Satine.  Red is the first color the audience sees, when the curtain rises, and also the last color the audience sees, when the curtain closes.  Throughout the movie, red is used elaborately in costumes and setting.  The décor in both the elephant dressing room and the Moulin Rouge is mostly red and the majority of the costumes are red or red tone.  Even the title, when translated, means red windmill.Probably the strongest thematic element would be the music.  'Moulin Rouge' is a musical, telling the story through music and dialogue.  The use of music is unique in that only one song (`Come What May') is an original song specifically for 'Moulin Rouge'.  Songs such as `Your Song', the various songs from `The Elephant Medley', `Come What May', and `Roxanne' all reflect the theme of love.There are many movies that try to capture the essence of love.  Some succeed, some fail.  'Moulin Rouge' has definitely succeeded.  Throughout the movie, the bohemian's belief in truth, freedom, beauty, and love is echoed constantly from the beginning with Christian to the bohemians reciting the line in a song at the end.  As they say in the movie, the greatest thing you'll ever learn, is just to love and be loved in return.

Review title: I never knew I could feel like this...
Review_body: I never knew I could feel like this... Oh yea it's been a long time since I saw a musical, and what I feel for this movie I never felt toward any musical I saw. it's A great love story and I couldn't think of a more suiteble director than Baz Luhrmann for this film.

It is very easy to be pedantic about this film.  Many comment upon the direction, the lushness and the sheer energy of the project.
I was drawn to this film as I was to Romeo + Juliet, it just grabbed my attention and whooshed me along!
An eye smacking visual and audio treat from the opening curtains to the end of credits.And dosen't Nicole look sexier in this than any other movie.

Well, at first I can say that I expected a little bit different movie. But this took my breath away. It is a story about beautiful, all bridging love. The main actors were extremely good, they act pure love and I believe in them. But there was one negative thing. The knowing that Satine will die in the end. It took control of my mind and I could not empathize to characters' love, because every time then the things went a little bit wrong I expected Satine's tragic die. Nonetheless, the film was a truly original. It was fun to recognize really popular songs like "Your song", "Show must go on" and others. Some people can be a little angry, because they so loved songs were adopted to cabaret style music, but this is the main reason why this movie shows so interesting and different from other movies. Also, the mix of show and real characters' life took a huge enough part of this movie's exclusivity. I some words, I give 10 to this movie, because of inspiring love story and originals decisions.

I love this movie.I have been a bit late in watching it but i always assumed it would suck.I saw it on TV and figured I'd give it a try and it turned out to be so beautiful. The story is so beautiful and cute.I love the music they chose, it's so awesome and they fit perfectly.The actors chosen are perfect and sing so great.I love their voices.This movie is a must see.I have actually watched it about 5 times.I want the soundtrack!It's comical and dramatic all at once and is a really awesome movie.I suggest you go and watch it!The actors all did a wonderful job in acting and made it seem to nice.They were so cute together and the ending is just touching.The ending song puts the movie together for the finishing touch and they picked all the right times for the two to sing together.

This is a truly spectacular film with everything you'd wish in a movie: great music, wonderful acting, wonderful singing, beautiful romance and so on. the first time I saw this movie I didn't know what to think of it, it just blew me away, from the dark intro to the dramatic ending, now that I bought the movie I watch it every week to be blown away once more

As a "theatre geek", I was awfully disappointed with this film.  Yet again, Baz Luhrmann's cinematography takes center stage, his fast-paced camera movements and bright flashy set design overshadowing his characters and story.First, I must say I've never been a big fan of Baz.  In my mind, his masterpiece was "Strictly Ballroom".  There was a balance between visuals and story that made it a truly great movie.  Then came "R+J".  Shakespeare for the MTV teenage-set.  While I admired the idea, I held no love for the finished product.And the same could be said here.  "Moulin Rouge!" is nothing more than a splashy, musical rendition of "The Lady of the Camillias".  Most tragic is that while I adore Ewan and Nicole, I can't help but notice their lack of singing talent.  And the same could be said for every other actor involved. However, I am relieved that the musical numbers consisted of shallow pop tunes.  If I had to listen to Nicole Kidman attempt to sing the music of Porter, Kander & Ebb, or Sondheim, I'd be deaf.For the sake of the "Movie Musical", I wanted this film to succeed. However, I was left feeling nothing but pity for the genre.  So much so that I was prepared to loathe "Chicago" (definitely my favorite stage show) and was wonderfully surprised.I really admire Luhrmann's attempt, however I think he's better off sticking to original material.  If you want to see a great musical, watch "Singin' in the Rain" (essential) or "Cabaret".  And if you enjoy the story of "Moulin Rouge!", watch "Camille".  No one can beat Greta Garbo.

Review title: The greatest thing you'll ever learn is just to love and be loved in return!!
Review_body: Moulin Rouge is one of my favorite movies of all time, honestly.  It has a beautiful love story and is wonderful in every aspect.  Luhrmann's work was fantastic, the colors and the way that he used recent pop music in a story that took place at the turn of the century was awesome. Also, I fell in love with Ewan McGregor in that movie.  His acting as Christian and his love for Satine was completely believable. But, a lot of the credit also has to go out for Nicole Kidman who without the movie would probably not have been as good.  As I previously mentioned, I loved the music and I thought that McGregor and Kidman did an absolute marvelous job singing them. I must admit though, that my favorite song is El Tango De Roxanne sung by 'The Unconscious Argentinean' (Jacek Koman). The only flaw that affected me in Moulin Rouge was the fact that Satine has consumption, or tuberculosis. Tuberculosis is a highly contagious disease and the fact that Christian was kissing her as she died and was still alive one year later bothered me a bit. On a whole though, I have to recommend this movie to everyone.  If you're not a fan of love storys I'm sure you'll be able to enjoy the music and the color schemes! All in all .. I love it and I suggest that you go rent it/buy it today!

I don't comment on movies very often but after seeing that this movie rated a 7.7, I just had to put in my comments to get the rating more in line with reality.This movie was really a load of crap. Luckily, I did not see this in the theaters. Luckily (or unluckily) I borrowed a copy of the DVD so I wasn't out the rental price either but I did lose 2 hours of my life watching this awful mess.Having 2 stars singing is not enough to call it entertainment. Granted, they sang in tune but singing is more than just signing the right notes at the right time, much more and Nicole and Ewan gave us MUCH less.Even visually, this movie was off. Scenes were just too busy to be esthetically pleasing.

Review title: An Incredible Feast for the eyes!
Review_body: I believe that Moulin Rouge is one of the most amazing film treasures of all time.  The cast is loaded with spectacular star power and Baz Lurhman is one of the most talented directors ever.  The movie can be described in one word "Weird".But that is what makes it soo amazing!  It is different than all the other films we have in society today.  It also is a movie for people who really treasure every form of art, because it contains every kind. The Music is modern as well as the dance.  The costumes and set decoration are truly exquisite!And I would reccomend this film to anyone who loves art and craves for something different! P.S. Get ready to fall in love with Ewan McGregor!

Review title: Not more than life could this say more of what i see of life
Review_body: It's beautiful and real in its dramatic way. Although, it's unrealisticly told in a musical and in an unrealistic fantasy, it makes you love it with its thrill of hoping it could be real. Who could fall in love with a woman who lies to all the men she is with, but a pure hearted man who sees nothing else, the blinding effect of love. It makes you wanna believe in love and mankind. Forget everything you see in the news, but Moulin Rouge, a 2 hour tranquility of hope and love, is all you need. Maybe, it's that wish that we all could live in that world full of revolutionists who strive for our peace, but this movie has made me happy. It's full of hope and youth. I love this movie!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

This is probably one of the most difficult films I'll ever review because it is so amazingly spectacular! The work Baz put into this film is absolutely amazing and the result is something we've never seen or felt before. Through song and music, he is able to express our most basic yet essential emotions in ways words can't describe. The emotions expressed in the film are so beautiful and connecting to every one of us - it takes us to a place we've always had in our hearts and feel happiest at, but it's also a place we rarely ever get to experience in everyday life. Moulin Rouge fufills our desires and makes us realize there's more to people than just what we see. In a world so chaotic and violent as today, I look at this movie as almost essential to bringing us back to what matters most - love. Moulin Rouge most definitely takes us to the beauty 'love' and allows to fill the void we so often have trouble expressing. If you do want to be touched in a simple yet most beautiful way, please watch this movie and let your heart soar!

Moulin Rouge (2011), directed by Baz Luhrmann is an extraordinary musical that takes stunning and daring risks with actors, song choice, costuming, choreography and plot. It is perhaps one of the best, if not the best, musicals I've ever watched in the sense that the execution of the story is both breathtaking and entertaining. Luhrmann chose to use actors like Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor as his star roles which made his choice of actors seemed quite daring at the time to the public. However, the highly talented and capable duo made the film's zest far more alluring and impressive. Luhrmann's use of type casting also helped to make the plot far more realistic to viewers.The best thing that comes out of "Moulin Rouge!" is definitely it's music and performances. The plot allows the movie to continue rolling along, however it's soundtrack allows the audience to feel the immense excitement and enthusiasm radiating from the screen. The performances are powerful and intensifying. Aside from excitement, the movie creates a feel of fantasy, love and aspirations while still reflecting reality. The musicality of the performances were intensified by it's highly decorated sets and costuming. There are bursts of color and light highlighted in every scene, that emanate specific emotions to be felt among the audience.The film is a great example of dramatic love, that reflects some of the concepts produced by films like "Romeo and Juliet". It's Bohemiam and burlesque-like twist emphasizes the overall sexiness and passionate love from the characters and allows the viewers to be totally immersed into the musical. "Moulin Rouge!" is an experience that is surely a shame to miss out on!

ugh where do i begin, first of all your annoyed by the tedious group of performers prancing around. thanks for that!next thing to add to the already lacking believability's, modern songs with that time periodperfvy old mena man who falls in love literally the minute he meets her -_-singing! everyone suddenly knows the words to that so exciting it will run for 50 years thing, just Sooo bad and painful to watch cannot at all be taken seriously even if this was a pantomime id still walk out

Review title: love lifts us up, all you need is love
Review_body: I was one of those people that didn't see the movie at the cinemas, instead I waited for a friend to have a copy so I could borrow it from them.I have only just watched Moulin Rouge! and I was told that I would either love it or hate it.  At first, I didn't love it but I knew that I didn't hate it, so I watched it again the next day.  I was more used to everything (including Kylie Minogue's 'Green Fairy' character, at first I was just like 'the point of her being there is ... ?, but now I understand it).Before I wrote this review, I read a few comments on the message boards, and one person said that they special effects were so unbelievable.  That is the whole point of the movie - Luhrmann says in his commentary on the DVD that he wanted a world that was not perfect, but imperfect (as evidenced by Satine and Christian dancing on the clouds around the Eiffel Tower - honestly, how could anyone ever say that that scene was meant to be normal? The dancing on the clouds showed that 'love lifts us all, love is all we need'.  Even Satine realised that after just listening to Christian singing once, and she was a courtisan of all people.)Ewan McGregor did a great job in the leading male role, I've never seen any other movie of his but I'm now a fan.  I saw him in his Paris hotel at the start with his typewriter, and immediately loved him, even though I hadn't seen the rest of the movie.  I loved it when he started singing, absolutely loved it.  His singing won Satine over every time (the first time it stopped her heavy breathing and tiger sounds on the floor - that part I thought was hilarious - and when she tries to end things before her dinner with the Duke, when Christian suggests the 'secret song' so no matter how hard things got they would realise they loved each other.Overall, I thought the movie was well done.  Over the top, perhaps, but that was meant to be the case.  Luhrmann wanted it to be elaborate, colourful and high-energy.  He and his crew most certainly achieved that, but I think the real shout outs should go to Nicole (in particular, after seeing this I really think she deserved the Oscar) and Ewan, because if there wasn't any chemistry between them, it would have been Gigli's predecessor.9.5/10 for sure.

Review title: worst movie I've seen in a long time
Review_body: About the only good thing I can say about this movie is that Nicole Kidman looked HOT. (and normally she is NOT an attractive woman) This movie was bad in nearly every way. It was filmed like some sort of horrible Mtv Hip-Hop video. They have nothing to show and no story to tell, so instead the film makers use very rapid edits and cuts to keep you glued to it like children to a video game. I can understand Nicole Kidman being in this, because she got to be the super-sexy star and romantic lead. Euwan McGregor will do any garbage nowadays as proved by the StarWars crap. I guess the millions of dollars are worth it, but if you added up all Ewan's dialog for the movies he's been in lately it might be the worst in Hollywood History.This movie was so bad that I was actually offended.Don't believe the Hollywood hype about this one. And don't waste your time.

My girlfriend forced me to watch this movie. I admit the first time around i laughed at her for being such a girl and crying like a sissy come the end. the second time around i actually paid attention instead. WOW! the songs, the story, the special effects...EVERYTHING! it is possibly the most spectacular film i have ever seen. the opening establishing shot with paris from above that slowly zooms in and drives through the city makes me want to scream. the editing on the dance floor is madness. during the song come what may when theyre on the balcony and it zooms out is absolutely gorgeous! ewans voice in the tango de roxanne echoes in my head still.   the ending had me want to jump out of my skin. finally, the gun toasting the tower is genius.all in all, this movie is a must see and i mean that...until my dying day...

We live in a time where movies are produced purely to make a buck on whatever the "hippest" and most contemporary fad is in effect.Thankfully, we can always watch movies like "Moulin Rouge" on DVD.Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman deliver stand-out performances--as do John Leguizamo, Jim Broadbent, Richard Roxburgh and well... the whole damn cast was great, really.The story may not be the most original, but the style and deliverance of it is very much so.Baz Luhrmann deserves a great deal of praise for this flawless, beautiful film. A little wild, weird and "out there," but that's what movies are supposed to be, right? Go see the latest garbage out there if that's your thing, otherwise get some popcorn, rent the DVD, and check out Moulin Rouge. 9/10

Review title: A brilliant cinematic masterpiece. Director Baz Luhrmann is a genius!
Review_body: This is my favorite movie of all time. It's clever, different and visually stunning. The idea of using modern songs in a 19th century musical may sound like an awful idea, but it turns out beautifully, because the songs are modified to the actor singing them. Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor give some of their best performances in this film, as well as showing off their incredible musical talents. This is a movie you can watch over and over again without it ever getting old. It shows the time period like we've never seen it before and tells a romantic story through the famous Moulin Rouge nightclub. In my opinion it's one of the most romantic films ever and will forever hold a place in cinematic history.

I had been very curious about this movie for years before I saw it, and I honestly didn't think I would like it very much, but I was so wrong. It was a little weird at first, but throughout the rest of the movie I was on the edge of my seat and I loved every moment of it! The music is exciting and the story is very moving. I fell in love with Ewan McGregor's character and I got to understand and embrace the tragic story of Nicole Kidman's character throughout the movie. Baz Luhrmann successfully and skillfully combined comedy, drama and romance all into one great musical. The only reason I didn't give this movie more than eight out of ten stars is because it obviously displays very many sexual themes, so I do not recommend this movie to younger people. However, I strongly recommend it to anyone who thinks they may want to watch it. Enjoy!

Review title: A well filmed movie which is a little too frenetic for its own good.
Review_body: I recently saw Moulin Rouge in a college dorm, surrounded by easy-going fun-loving college students, and although they enjoyed the movie so much they could even sing along to the catchy tunes, there were certain things in the film that I was personally bothered by. The contemporary songs in the Bohemian Revival setting work very well for certain scenes, but some scenes, particularly the love scenes between Satine and Christian, would be much deeper and more emotional with conventional background music... The filming/shooting in this movie was refreshing, with camera angles everywhere and zooms all over the place. The effect is slightly overused in my opinion, but is in keeping with the overall "style" of the movie. Finally, the acting itself was not bad at all, with great acting and chemistry between Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, and some fantastic secondary roles. Overall a good movie, but perhaps a little bit overdone, as I guess all musicals are.

I love this movie! I've watched it tons and tons of times! If you haven't seen it, I recommend it, it's probably not what you expect it would be. It's not just some mushy musical. It's the best movie!! It's funny, it's got really great acting, and it's got great songs including Smells Like Teen Spirit by Nirvana! It's really good. Sad, but good. If you're feeling sad, don't watch the end. Stop it when you think the story is happy, because most parts are really funny and make you laugh a lot. My friend and I are obsessed with Ewan McGregor! He's hott! And he's also a very good actor/singer too. Nicole Kidman did a good job too. Must have been hard for everyone to do. Bravo to all!

My girlfriend introduced me to this film. The use of the musical numbers and the pure joy of just watching it reflects well. When watching this movie I go back to High School when we were producing My Fair Lady. We had standing ovations on every night. I never got tired of watching that show, I knew the lines as well as the actors, and it was a treat to watch. Moulin Rouge takes it's rightful place in my memories right beside it. I've seen Ewan McGregor's work obviously in Star Wars, and just seeing him belt out these awesome, awesome songs gives me get goosebumps. It's amazing what people can do when you least expect it. I had no premonitions when I sat down to watch this movie, and I was pleasantly surprised. My advice is the same, don't sit down and expect something that won't happen. Sit down and accept what Baz is trying to show you. I didn't even know he was the director until I came here to look the film up afterwards. I rarely give movies I watch a full star rating, but this one definitely gets it from me.

I'm having a hard time coming up with ten lines of text for this bomb. I'd rather have summed it up in one (see last two sentences of this comment). The only thing memorable about this farce is that it will likely become a cliché for bad taste. Recipe for Moulin Rouge: Come up with a vacuous story idea. Make it a "musical" by borrowing a bunch of sappy, irrelevant, historically inappropriate pop songs and wedging them into the "plot". Hire a couple of currently popular movie actors - singing ability not important. Add gobs of garish production, film effects and computer graphics. Add lots of sugar and pour (you may require a spoon to get this sticky mess out of the can). Absolute tripe! Anyone who enjoyed this movie is a bonehead.

As usual Baz Luhrmann has provided us with a masterpiece, a movie that will make you laugh, dance and cry. Whilst I can understand this not being everyones taste it certainly appealed to the artist in me with its combination of film and theater, and of course a story line about a bunch of struggling bohemian artists trying to make it big. The story line consists of Christian (Ewan McGregor) moving to Paris to pursue his obsession with love and the bohemian lifestyle, and much to his surprise being dragged into writing a play with a bunch of struggling artists. On his first visit to the Moulin Rouge he meets Satine (Nicole Kidman) and sparks fly! The 2 actors have a magical on stage connection that makes the entire movie seem so real, they really make you believe they are madly in love, I sometimes felt like I was inside the story line rather than just watching it, its so easy to get lost in! As is normal with Luhrman the movie is quite fast paced, brightly coloured, the sets are surreal and the acting is highly over the top, all of it making you feel as if you are at the Theatre. A lot of people don't like the fact that original songs weren't written for it but I absolutely loved the song choices, they were quite familiar which allows you to sing along on your first viewing of the film! With such a fast paced, bright, trippy movie we expect a happy ending were the lovers get married and live happily ever after, sadly this isn't so, throughout the film you will notice it get gradually darker and darker, and the ending hit me so hard that I was crying for an hour afterwords! This film is definitely worth a watch, and I know I will watch it again and again and again! If you like art and excitement and creativity, watch it. If you like logic, realistic acting and are strictly against cheesy music then stay away!

I can't remember how many times I've seen this movie but I was forced to watch this movie because it was the only movie showing that day (one screen theater) and my jaw absolutely dropped. Personally musicals aren't my favorite but this is an absolute masterpiece of a movie. I was engulfed by the emotion, music, and cinematography of this piece. The storyline is incredible and actors Ewan and Nicole deliver. An absolute must see date movie or at home. Be ready to laugh, be ready to cry, be ready to be angry, bottom line is get your movie going machine prepared for a roller coaster of a ride. I've seen this movie 50 plus times and the emotions run deep every time. Have fun.

Review title: Realizes what film can truly do
Review_body: I'm not going to sit here and give my personal opinion on things like acting quality, emotive reactions to the film, etc., because that ground has been trod into mud by other commenter's and boardcrawlers. All I wish to say here is that this movie is, to me, the realization of what the pioneers of film wished it to be. Think back to the Follies and the Gold Diggers shows of the 1920s. Though they were little more than filmed showing of stage productions, their influence upon Baz is readily evident in this film. And that's what he wanted.This movie, this trilogy (Simply Ballroom, Romeo+Juliet, and Moulin Rouge!, the Red Curtain Trilogy) is Baz's tribute to stage arts: Dance, Drama, and Music. In all three cases, he took pre-existing mediums of stage art and set them to his own, idiosyncratic tune before the camera. Flamenco was flamenco, Shakespeare was Shakespeare, and love ballads are love ballads here. This is why there is so little original musical material in this movie: it is a tribute. And, though I said I would keep my personal opinions out of this one, it's a 10/10 tribute in my eyes.

Review title: A Story About Beauty, Freedom, Truth, and Love
Review_body: I love a lot of musicals and I have to say that Moulin Rouge is one of my favorites. Baz Luhrmann, director of "Strictly Ballroom" and "Romeo & Juliet" directed this 2001 hit. The movie has extraordinary sets and dazzling costumes, not to mention the brilliant performances by Ewan McGregor, Nicole Kidman, and the rest of the all-star cast. The music in the film is mostly from the 20th century; unlike the story, which takes place in 1899. Here are a few of the songs and their original performers. "Your Song"  Elton John, "Like a Virgin"  Madonna, "Roxanne"  Sting, "Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend"  Marilyn Monroe, and "Nature Boy"  Nat King Cole. It also has one new song that was created for the movie. "Come What May" is probably my favorite out of all the songs. Not only is it an original, it is inspiring and tells the true story of the love between the two characters. One song in the film is quite different from its original performance. This is "Your Song," originally sung by Elton John but performed by Ewan McGregor in the film. The beginning of the song actually starts out as poetry. He then breaks out into song right at "My gift is my song." It really catches your attention because he sings very fortissimo. John's version is a lot mellower and it moves a little smoother. The key stays the same in both versions, but the notes differ from time to time. It's quite different (the film's version) but it's a really well done rendition of "Your Song." It's one of my favorite songs in the film!As mentioned earlier, the costumes are dazzling! Each costume helps to portray that character and their personality. The characters that are morbid and mysterious wore darker colors, unlike some of the exuberant characters that wore bright colors. The dresses are extraordinarily beautiful, each being very colorful and unique. The other costumes in the movie are great too! They are all very detailed, especially Nicole Kidman's dresses and outfits which had sequins, gems, and loads of other decor. The dancing/choreography in this movie is astonishing! Every dance routine is unique and very detailed. It helps the story develop better and gives the viewer some idea of what the characters are feeling. One that comes to mind is the "El Tango De Roxanne" dance sequence. As the story unfolds, the characters portray it in their dance. They use sharp, crisp movements throughout the piece to exaggerate certain lines. If the song gets hectic, so does the dance. If it's slow and mysterious, the dance is too.The plot is quite common as with most love stories. You know: boy meets girl, girl plays hard-to-get, another man wants girl, girl finally likes boy, they fall in love, other guy gets in the way of things, girl finally finds her way back to original boy, etc. Christian (Ewan McGregor) is a penniless poet who has traveled from London to France. He befriends a group of Bohemians, one of whom is Toulouse Lautrec (John Leguizamo). He also meets the woman of his dreams, Satine, a courtesan and star performer at the Moulin Rouge. Christian composes a play called "Spectacular, Spectacular" that ends up being pretty much about his experience in France. The Duke (Richard Roxburgh) wants Satine for himself and will do anything to get her, even if it means killing Christian. The two lovers always seem to outsmart the dimwitted Duke until they are finally found out. The story follows the two characters in their magical journey about beauty, freedom, truth, and above all things, love.I definitely recommend this movie to anyone who likes musicals or even a good love story every now and then. It's a truly inspiring film with a lot of emotional ups and downs. The performances by Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman are outstanding! They really seem to have good chemistry, which makes the story more believable. Their voices also add to the fun and excitement of the film. The rest of the cast, including Jim Broadbent, Richard Roxburgh, and John Leguizamo are extraordinary also.

Review title: 2nd Worst Movie We Ever Went To
Review_body: The only movie my wife and I ever walked out on and asked for our money back. We watched in a fairly empty theater, and that should have been our first clue. It had not been out all that long and nobody was there.Apparently there were others that liked the movie. You just can't add us to the list. The music wasn't interesting. The dialogue wasn't interesting. The plot wasn't interesting. Wish there were more tools available to us before we saw it to get a better idea of what we were about to see. Don't need to worry about renting it or pay-per-viewing, as we saw more than enough the first time...p.s. The worst movie we ever went to, if you are curious, was Leaving Las Vegas. We heard about the Oscar for Best Actor and the Golden Globe nomination for best picture. We were sure it was going to get better. It started bad and got worse from there...

This is a story of heart ache and romance but within this is deceite, jealousy and hatred. This heart stopping musical is a must watch, Baz Lurhmann creates an amazing action packed film, combining everything from bright and colourful night-life of the early 20th century to modern day music. Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman play well together as the love-struck couple battle against two deadly forces, that are death and jealousy.All the while concealing there love from the duke, who Satine must be with, if she ever wants to leave her life as a prostitute. This film is a MUST see by all accounts. One rule, Never fall in love...

Review title: Tragically and Heartbrakingly beautiful - For those artistic people out there, Watch this movie!
Review_body: The most absolutely amazing, moving, tragically and heartbreakingly beautiful film/movie I have ever seen in my life. It's incredible compositions of music, choreography of dance and the whole plot in general leaves you sitting there in wonder, long after the film was over. Ewan Mcgregor could not have done better. He has an amazing voice and a charismatic presence that makes you fall in love with him from the moment he sings his first line "the hills are alive with the sound of music". Nicole Kidman did an incredible job at shaping into the character of Satine. She ended up having a very, very good voice as well. Both of their voices complimented each other. Ewan and Nicole did such a great job that you could actually believe what they were acting. It wasn't as if you were watching a film, but two people who loved each other so much,and overcame all obstacles. Well, nearly all of them...I loved all the actors in this movie, actually (maybe not all the "characters", like the Duke) It was extremely well written and I could literally watch it over and over again and still cry at the end. This is a rare film that actually takes you on a journey, all the while you're realizing new things every time you watch it. It's like you're falling in love with them all over again, feeling their pain and longing with them all over again. Maybe it's because I am a music fanatic (not really into musicals, but the Moulin Rouge is a definite exception)And a lover of Paris, but i extremely enjoyed this film and the music.For those people who say that this movie was "trash" and "horrible", or said things like "if you liked this, never watch a movie again", or any of that, I honestly see why they don't like it, and that is: This movie is for the open minded, artistic people of the world. If you're into unique, original and beautiful scenery, music, plot, cinematography that has NEVER been seen before in any other movie or book, then i recommend you watch this movie right away.If you're not, then don't even bother, although you are missing out on something amazing. I loved it, and i'm sure you will too.

The blend of contemporary and original songs and the absolute talents of the cast make this movie one worth watching again. If you can't enjoy this movie there is truly something wrong. This is one of those movies that will live on for a long while and is a great example of mixing movie with music - a great musical. The pure enjoyment of listening to the two main characters playing off each other to the group songs for chorus purposes. The acting of course is excellent as well with a nice spin on the play within a play. The variety of music styles and songs is also a nice change of pace. The love against all obstacles is cliché but this movie puts a nice turn on that standard. The soundtrack has to be magical if it includes these talented folks. Enjoy and just a word - Magical.

I love the music in this movie... When Christian, Satie, the Doctor, Satine, Toulouse and Zidler are singing the pitch of the play,it is SO hilarious. The Elephant Love Medley is awesome as well as Come What May are awesome. Ewan and Nicole have such loving stage presence and work well together it seems. Their voices are amazing.. I sing along with all the songs and also say the dialog along with the movie. I haven't memorized the whole movie, but I'm close to doing it. That's a bit sad, but I just like the movie so much. I would just have to say that I give the songs as well as the acting a 10 out of 10. I would have to say another song that is funny is Like A Virgin sung by Richard Roxburgh and Jim Broadbent. The Duke really can't sing until the end of the song when he's belting out "Like A Virgin" LOL I recommend this movie to all those who haven't seen it. It gives a whole new spin on the idea of musicals.

I think it is an amazing film! It is not only a very romantic and lovely story, but the whole concept is so original. First of all, I really like the leading actors. Nicola Kidman and Ewan McGregor play their parts perfectly. Because it is a musical, it is standard that there are a lot of songs. When I first heard the songs, I immediately searched them on the internet and listened to them time after time. The music is powerful and has a recognizable beat, but you also have the more quiet and emotional songs. At the beginning, my opinion about the film in general was rather vague because there were strange scenes in it. But after watching it several times, I still love it. A next incredible fact about the film is the decor! It all seems fantastic. You would think the Moulin Rouge is a magic places with shows, drinks and a lot of dancers. But you still know exactly that everything is happening in Paris. The shocking side about this item is that the film wasn't made in Paris at all. Nothing you see about Paris, the buildings, the Moulin rouge itself, is real. I think it's a piece of art. This film is the reason why I like everything about the Moulin rouge. I'm fascinated about it.Therefore I strongly recommend this film, The Moulin Rouge!, to everybody I know!

I think the 'Moulin rouge'is the most romantic film I have ever seen! I sat crying on the couch watching the movie. Nicole Kidman (Satine) acts if it's real. I was shocked when she died. I just couldn't believe it. Yes, I was crying and my boyfriend too. It was so a romantic film, it's just like 'Romeo and Juliet', just as beautiful.I hope there will come another movie just as exiting as this one because it's a beautiful story and then the music!The music, it is just the thing that makes the film and the story one! I can't describe it. It's amazing!You just have to see it!!!

Without a doubt this is the most dreadful film I have ever seen. I saw it on an aircraft. Maybe this was what was being shown on 9/11 and this is why the planes flew into the Twin Towers. Anything to end the horror of seeing this mawkish teenage drivel.Dreadful music, stupid plot, tenth-rate (no, I'll amend that) twentieth-rate acting. It is utterly amazing that this film has become popular. And what a cheek to steal the title of a perfectly good 1950s biopic (the one with José Ferrer as Toulouse-Lautrec and the nice Mantovani music). Truly a dreadful film and a waste of space. If I had to replace the word "dreadful" in this review, I would choose "boring". Or maybe "banal". Or why not all three?

This movie is so spectacular spectacular!!! I highly recommend watching this film for it is humorous, romantic and has so great songs, and so charismatic actors, you can't miss it. you won't regret it.. this movie can consider itself the best of musicals. The songs that are in it are really good ones, with nice text and excellent music. Most of these are extracted from already known songs just one is original from moulin rouge's production. The cast is also excellent, with Nicole kidman and Ewan McGregor you can count on this movies like one of your classic favorites. The appearance of David Wenham is also interesting, and it proves the abilities this great actor has. So don't forget to watch this film you will be so spectacular spectacularly amused!

Review title: much love for the DVD set
Review_body: The extras on the two~disk set are so amazing. I'm only about 1/10th of the way through, but am already in awe. There have been so many DVD's I've bought, only to be disappointed in the extras. Baz did not disappoint. I felt kind of dumb buying this, at first, because I've seen it a ridiculous amount of times. :) I'm so glad I got it, though.Does anyone know what projects he's into, right now? Any more musicals?I would love to see some of these cast members again. The evil dark~haired diamond dog is such an amazing dancer. The tango scene is so moving.Does it confuse/frustrate anyone else that there are people out there who do not like this movie?

Moulin Rouge is the best Musical in Hollywood History.Nicole Kidman, played the best I've ever seen her play. The songs Fantastic.Jim Broadbent, stole the show.Ewan Mcgregor, suited the role and played it brilliantly.The Duke is a weird character, he freaks me out.Everybody acted fantastically, but some were better than others.Roxanne was may favourite song. Along with Diamonds are a girls best friend.Some of the songs were weird as hell.Baz Luhrmann directed it perfectly.Anybody who think this film is crap are mad.

Review title: What kind of drug was Lurhmann on??
Review_body: I'm not sure exactly what a "spoiler" would be considered, so I checked it just to make sure I would not be "blacklisted"! ;-) My husband and I just recently bought the DVD Moulin Rouge as the reviews were so great! As we sat there looking at it, I wondered if I was crazy, and he sat there wondering if he was crazy!!! Finally we looked at each other and said..."Does this thing make any sense to you???" It was the worst movie we have ever viewed! It appeared to be written, produced, and directed by persons who were on some type of drug...or were they schizophrenic??? The film made no sense whatsoever!! After viewing the whole film...which was an exercise in mental torture, we just had to laugh at our foolish waste of money. Well...our dog enjoyed using the DVD as a Frisbee!! ;-)

"Moulin Rouge" (2001) starts out in Paris with Christian (Ewan McGregor), a young writer who has just come from London, England. The writer begins to type his story, his story of love, jealousy, and betrayal, and how he learned the most important thing in life to learn, "just to love, and be loved in return". He begins with end; the woman he loves is dead. It all started a year before, when he first arrived in Paris, France. He rents a room in a hotel and after getting situated, has an unconscious Argentinian (Jacek Koman) fall through his ceiling. He is introduced to the Moulin Rouge through Toulouse (John Leguizamo) and thus begins the story. The love of his life is Satine (Nicole Kidman), the young and very beautiful star courtesan of the night club, Moulin Rouge. He is introduced to her through Toulouse and through a misunderstanding of him being a Count, becomes involved with the Moulin Rouge indefinitely.The film's central idea seems to be that love is the most important thing in life, and the most important lesson to be learned is to love and be loved in return. He does very well at trying to convey that message, and even begins the movie with such. He stresses how important the lesson is, but does well to include comedic areas in Moulin Rouge to not make the whole movie seem so oppressive and heavy. It is a great story about truth, beauty, freedom, and above all else, love.The whole movie is utterly amazing and appealing, and I highly applaud the director, Baz Luhrmann. Although the cinematography could use some help in spots, such as the scene on top of the elephant, the rest of the cinematography was very enjoyable to watch. The characters are realistic and believable, as if they could exist during the time period and area. The colors are dark to convey the dark plot and being about a very seedy nightclub of the film. It's a musical, and the music chosen for this film were perfect choices for this film, especially since all of the music was mostly modern. Altogether, the film was fantastic, and I would recommend anyone who enjoys a good love story or musical to watch this film and enjoy the dark playground that is Moulin Rouge.

When I saw this the first time, I was with some friends on New Years. We ended up watching it 2 times and that started an obsession of Moulin Rouge and especially Ewan McGregor. The movie is excellent. It is a mixture of comedy and drama. And I did put the warning about a spoiler on there, so I can go and spoil it now. Yes, Satine dies in the end (of course it tells you that info in the beginning, and I personally think that they shouldn't have given that out). And the Duke gets shut down and punched in the face by wonderful Harold Zidler (Good for him!). My favorite part is, of course, the beginning with its invigorating fast pace and funny lines and general... funniness! It is hilarious when Christian (a.k.a. Ewan) is trying to make up a production storyline on the spot, and I love the Duke's expressions to the different ideas! Of course, the highlight of the whole movie was the beautiful singing that came out of lovely Christian's beautiful mouth (lol). Especially their secret song (Come What May). I congratulate the composer or arranger of these songs in the movie, because they are gorgeous, and it sounds amazing! Well, I had better stop myself, though I could go on about this movie FOREVER! If you haven't seen it, do so very very quickly- you will most DEFINITELY not regret it. Unless you're not into musicals so much. But other than that it is fantastic and it is highly, highly commended! I LOVE YOU, EWAN!!!!

If you found Moulin Rouge unlikeable you are either: a) an idiot b) have no appreciation for a fantastic work of art c) an idiot or d) obviously missed the bigger picture of what the film was about.All of you who are sitting there criticizing the film because it has 'songs mixed together' or find the 'plot laughable' truly have not looked beneath the surface of the film. The meaning and messages that Luhrman presents are so significant and important in the world today that it would be stupid to dismiss them.The film is not just about Love and Lost (which I'm sure many of you found corny anyway) but it is also about how giving one's heart and soul to a single purpose will eventually mean overcoming everything. this is not just with Love but with all quests. Although there is loss along the way, eventually the truth really will set you free.The fact that Lurhman teamed the fantastic plot with such a great set up including the music, the cast, the set - hell the whole concept is just fantastic - makes it even more Spectacular.I truly think all of you so called 'critics' out there need to sit down and watch the movie again and not have such a closed mind about it. Be open to the underlying meanings and who knows - you might even learn something about what it takes to make a fantastic movie.

Having just read a large number of the other comments, by people who loved the film, and by those that thought it was awful, you can see something of a pattern emerge. Most of the people who thought it was awful don't connect with the style of the film, and given that it has such an in-your-face style, if you don't connect there, then I can well imagine that you'd find it boring, frenetic, lame, etc, etc.It is worth observing at the outset, that the style is very much that of opera - melodramatic, hyper-real, fantastic (as in "fantasy", rather than "really good"). I enjoy this style myself, but I can readily believe other people disliking it intensely.One common objection by people who disliked it is that either the film has no plot, or that the plot is not original. The plot is there, and it is essentially the same story used in several operas of the 19th century, and more than one musical of the 20th. The important insight that helps one understand this film, is that in a well honored tradition stretching back to Homer, the plot is not the "point" of the work, but rather the scaffolding on which the story-telling occurs. In opera, it is most unusual to walk in to the theater without already knowing the plot. Homer's "Odessy" and "Iliad" are both stories that would have been known by his audience. In both cases, the cleverness, the art, is in how the story is told. Moulin Rouge! is very much opera for the big screen, and it is built on this conception of story-telling. So, yes, it is style over substance, and deliberately so.That said, if a plot is to be successful scaffolding to tell an engaging story, then it has to have some bones to it. This classic story of the consumptive courtesan who falls in love has lots of song themes in it about what is important in life, life's fleeting nature, and so on. Where the film loses many people, who haven't connected to the operatic style, is that having communicated enough bits of the plot to tell us which story is being told (and the bookend structure tells us that right away), there is no obligation to join all the dots. Having given us the message that it is *this* story, it can skip over the details of the plot in order to concentrate on which ever aspects of the telling it likes.This is clear in how the snatches of song are used. The goal is evocation rather than elucidation.Anyway, enough criticism.I recommend this film, not because I can predict whether it will be to your taste or not, but because it is an excellent example of a very different style of story-telling to what we usually see in film.

This is by far one of the best movies i have ever seen in my entire life! The music is so unbelievably awesome! The actors fit their parts as if that was what they were born to do. If you believe in truth, beauty, freedom, and love this is the movie for you. I have seen Moulin Rouge more times than i can possibly count, and i still love it. This is one of those movies that never gets old. The love and romance the two characters have for each other it so unbelievable. It makes everyone want and crave the love they share! The greatest thing about the movie is not just the love they have, but the love they long to posses! In conclusion, WATCH THE MOVIE! I Guarantee a good cry and a warm feeling in your heart. You will feel as if you are right there experiencing the whole story, and if u don't feel compassion, my heart goes out to you for not being able to feel the one thing that matters in this world! LOVE!!!!

I loved this movie when I saw it on VH1 and bought it right away. After I bought it, I watched it at least 12 times(no exaggeration) and now any time someone says something that came from the movie, I finish the scene out in my mind or under my breathe! It is my all time favorite movie and I think every household(with children over the age of 13) should own a copy! Ewan McGregor became my favorite actor(and crush of all times...bigger than Brad Pitt or Johnny Depp!) and I think he played the part of Christian perfectly. Nicole Kidman nailed the part of Satine and every movie I see now with her in it, all I see is Satine. The sets were amazing and the colors were crazy, making my eyes go nuts trying to find a solid image to focus on. Again, my praise to this film and those who worked on it. Now, if you will excuse me, talking about Moulin Rouge makes me need to go and watch it again!!!!

I first watched Moulin Rouge because it was a musical, but it turns out it's not just any ordinary musical- it's a story that's heartbreaking and realistic.Set in 1899, in Paris, France, it's a vivid love story. Christian, a handsome young writer, comes to Paris from London to write about truth, beauty, freedom, and love, the ideals of the Bohemian Revolution, despite his father's scorn of the whole idea. There was only one problem with this- he'd never been in love before.As he is puzzling about how to write about something he'd never experienced, a Narcoleptic Argentinean falls through his ceiling from the flat above his own, and a carefree, laughing dwarf comes in to rescue the Argentinean. The dwarf, the Argentinean, and three other men who are peering down through the hole in Christian's ceiling are working on a play called Spectacular Spectacular, which they are to present to Harold Zidler the next day. Christian comes up to substitute for the Argentinean, who is still unconscious, and an argument ensues among the other men on what the words and tune to a song in the play should be. When Christian comes up with the perfect match, it is voted that he write the play.Zidler is the owner of the Moulin Rouge, a nightclub where "the rich and powerful come to play with the young and beautiful creatures of the underworld". Toulouse, the dwarf, passes Christian off as a famous English writer, and arranges for him to meet with Satine, the most beautiful of all the Moulin Rouge dancers, who will, in turn, convince Zidler to have Christian write the play.Zidler had arranged, however, for Satine to meet a duke that evening, which is who Satine mistakes Christian for, and soon Satine has to choose between the two men. The duke falls in love with Satine and shows her all the wonderful things he can give her, but Christian shows Satine all the things that true love can be. As it becomes harder to hide their love, Satine has another problem that is becoming harder to avoid- a more personal one that leads to a tragic climax.This is a beautiful story that definitely makes my top 10 list of movies- I recommend it.

Review title: The story of an English writer and a French cancan dancer. A story of freedom, beauty, truth, and LOVE.
Review_body: I LOVE this movie!! I watched it so many times in the cinema and I just couldn't wait 'till it came out on DVD. Once I got it on DVD, I watched it everyday for 3 weeks!!It's funny. It's romantic. It's musical. It's everything! I just love everything about it. I appreciated Nicole Kidman and Ewan Mcgregor more. They did a such great job in that film. The whole cast. They did such a good job with everything. The props, the location, the cast, the directing, everything.To those of you who haven't seen it, I suggest you do. It's really good.The soundtracks aren't bad either.

When I was to see Moulin Rouge, I didn't quite know what to expect. Some people had told me that they loved it, but some said it was boring. I couldn't disagree more. After seeing it the first time i was amazed. The music, the actors, the feeling I was left with, it was really wonderful!Ewan McGregor is excellent as the English writer Christian, who comes to Paris to be a part of the bohemian revolution. He is to write a play that are going to be shown at the moulin rouge, a nightclub, ruled over by Harold Zidler, where the rich comes to dance and have fun with the creatures of the underworld. There he meets Satine (Nicole Kidman), a courtesan and a cancan-dancer, who wants to become a real actress. They fall in love, but love between them is impossible. It's a classic love story, told in a new way.This is a movie that makes you both laugh and cry. The many singing and dancing numbers are spectacular, and Kidman and McGregor sings very well (I especially think McGregors voice is fantastic). Also the dancers impresses me much.One of the things that I like so much about this film is the way the use modern songs we all know (Smells like teen spirit,your song and like a virgin, to mention some of them), and makes them fit in to this beautiful story from the beginning of the last century. The cutting are also special, and (according to me) good. And not to mention the costumes, they are incredible.. All in all, watching this movie is a real pleasure, and you should all see it!

Review title: The story which has touched me deep deeply...till tears!=)
Review_body: It's not one of those fairy tales giving U a happy ending - not at all. Standing for truth, beauty, freedom and love rather breaks your heart...Yet only so U have one:) Spectacular spectacular indeed as for music, heroes which love, fight for it and so they bleed in more sensual, passionate ways...Carresing ones able to feel deeper causes and dreams-live them thorough over and over again. Ewan McGregor(poor writer) plays a role of an enchanted one who meets Love for the first time finding it in a beautiful cortisone played by Nicole Kidman (Satine) who seems to have lost belief in love's embrace-but only in very beginning... Nicole have said:"It's better to Love for real and lose your everything than live and never know what true love is." So this is the story of Moulin Rouge! Hope you felt it:)

Review title: Love it! Love it! Do I need to say more?
Review_body: This movie is the best movie ever! I don't think I've ever seen anything like it. The whole story is so wonderful, and somebody may see this movie only as a cliché, but I think it's brilliant! It's Supposed to be a story about love, so well...I think Baz did a very nice job ;o) He also did a great job when casting the movie. Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman were the perfect choices for this movie. They did a great job, and I guess I'm not the only one who had a huge crush on Ewan after seeing this movie. He's such a great actor and he has a lot of emotion to share with the audience who watches this movie. And not only is he a great actor, but he can sing as well! He has a beautiful voice which made me melt every time I heard him sing. Nicole Kidman did a great job as well. She has a lovely voice, and proves she can sing as well. She was perfect for the role as Satine and Ewan was perfect for the role as Christian. I also think Richard Roxburgh did a great job as the Duke. As I said, great actors! This is really a movie which is worth watching. Truly the best movie I've ever seen! You don't have to be a true musical-fan to like this movie, because it's just something about it which makes it awesome, musical-fan or not. See this movie, you won't regret! 10/10
Favorite go to movie. Great songs. Great performances.

Review title: You'd think that people would have had enough of silly love songs...
Review_body: A musically creative and awe inspiring visual dream that taps into all the emotions of life. It is nearly perfect in its artistic delivery of the bohemian, free spirit of 1900 Paris with a delightful modern flare. It isn't your typical movie musical, so I am guessing you have to like the arts and be open-minded the boundaries it crosses. You feel like you are walking into a painting and experiencing the chaos, the sin, the poverty, the non-conformity, and artistic, free- spirited beauty of bohemian life. It loses one star because the beginning came off a little too chaotic -- hang in there, it's worth it. Really awesome film.

Review title: A love story like every other which is like no other
Review_body: I think what I said above just about sums Moulin Rouge! perfectly. It is a love story like every other love story, but it is like no other love story.A paradox? Maybe, but that's exactly what this movie is.Firstly, let me just say that to fully enjoy this movie, you have to have an open mind. Forget reality and forget conventions. Moulin Rouge! isn't about reality and is as unconventional a movie as can be. Stop trying to "understand" it, and eventually, you will understand it. Secondly, you must be warned that it's a love-it-or-hate-it kinda movie. You're either a huge fan of the movie and have everything from the 2-disc special edition DVD to your own MR! t-shirt, or you hate it so much that you just want to point a gun to the character's heads. Don't listen to everything critics say. They are most likely the ones who hate this movie, as they spend a whole lifetime trying to "understand" movies, and when one like this comes along, they don't know what to do with it. They give it 0/10 before even giving it a second chance. A typical case of prejudice. You are not them, and so you at least owe it to yourself to give this movie a try.Now, let's talk about the actual movie. Moulin Rouge! is simply everything a movie should be. It has comedy. It has action. It has romance. It has drama. It has every filming style imaginable, from Disney to Bollywood. It is old vs. modern. I mean, which other movie has beautiful computer visual effects (some of which are reported to be the longest in movie history!) yet also has the old "hand-made" style of film-making, with unusual (and even wobbly) camera angles, on purpose? Which other movie has men in top hats singing Nirvana and beautiful courtesans singing Randy Crawford songs?The plot in itself is a run-of-the-mill love story, taken from the operas "La Boheme" and "La Traviata", taken from Dumas' "La Dame aux Caméllias". Christian (Ewan McGregor) is a young, middle-class writer who wants something new in life. He wants to write a brilliant novel with a beautiful love story at the heart of it. The only problem is... he has never been in love. Stuck in a rut in London with his overly-religious father, he decides to move away to Paris, the city of love, to become part of the Bohemian revolution. After an accident involving a Narcolpetic Argentinian, a very sweet and apologetic Toulouse Lautrec (John Leguizamo) and a falling roof, he meets a group of kind-hearted Bohemians who believe he is the one to help them write a show they are currently in the process of. The show is extremely important to them because it is a show all about their ideals of Truth, Beauty, Freedom and Love. However, they have other plans for it: they want to show it to the new financier of the Moulin Rouge, a Duke (Richard Roxburgh), whom they hope will agree to fund the conversion of the famous nightclub into a theatre. Now with a new writer for the show, the Bohos need a star for it. They immediately think of the Moulin Rouge's beautiful, top courtesan Satine. Before he can say "The hills are alive with the sound of music", Christian is off to the Moulin Rouge to convince Satine to be in the show. He sees her performing her rendition of "Diamonds are a girl's best friend" and is immediately head over heels in love with her. The only problem is, Satine is needed elsewhere. At the same time, on a table nearby, the Duke is waiting for Satine to finish her show. However, the Bohos had told Christian that Satine would meet with HIM after the show... and you can guess what happens next... yep, you've got it... Satine mistakes Christian for the Duke! Alone in her boudoir with Christian, inside an Elephant, Satine tries flat out to seduce this Duke who is actually Christian. Christian's Orphean soul makes Satine fall in love with him as he sings his own rendition of "Your Song". However, after finding out that he is in fact NOT the Duke, Satine tries to take back all the feelings she had. However, true love is not like that, and before you know it, they're kissing passionately on top of the Elephant. Another thing about true love is that it's unmistakable to miss, and before long, everyone else at the Moulin Rouge finds out about Christian and Satine's affair... apart from the Duke. To keep the Duke out of the know, Satine still has to seduce him and the night comes when she has to sleep with him... but she can't do it as she cares too much about Christian, and then it builds into a heart-wrenching climax... you'll have to watch the movie to see what I mean!!

When I first saw the movie, I gave up after 10 minutes, walked out of the theatre and kicked myself that I just have wasted 8$ on it. I just could not connect the use of modern songs with a historic setting. Convincing myself that I might just have had a bad day, and telling myself to have an open mind, I watched the DVD all the way through. Good grief, what a drag, and was I happy that I have just borrowed it from friends! A poor excuse for a plot, no character development at all, recycled (or, dare I say, massacred) pop songs, recycled ideas (La Boheme, La Traviata, Orpheus in the underworld), and, on top of that, dialogues which are mostly made up of strings of song titles, or repetitions of the key lines of the songs that have just been performed, the rest being commonplace statements. The only amazing thing is the art direction ,scoring a well deserved Oscar, but that's about it! Seemingly, Baz Luhrmann could not decide whether to make a movie (not enough plot) or an MTV video clip (too long, but still using the modern editing style of a video of light-speed camera moves and nano- second scene changes, which makes everyone older than 21 just nauseous!), and , most probably to keep the risk factor low, did not use even the tiniest bit of original ideas! Zip! Zero! Zilch! It has its funny moments, but they are too rare to make up for its shortfalls, such as lack of depth. The term love is used about 1000 times, however I could not connect to the characters (there is just not enough plot), and Satine's death left me stone cold. In short: a total waste of time.

Review title: Extremely left down, expected much much more.
Review_body: It must have been the fact that before this movie I watched the beautiful masterpiece that Chicago (2002) is! After having a great time watching one of the best musical movies I've seen, I was left wanting more so I went to my Netflix recommendations and saw Moulin Rouge. What a great mistake, Netflix! I'm pretty sure I didn't see more that 30 minutes of the movie as I ended up having a terrible headache and even wanted to vomit. I have never, ever stopped watching a movie after so little time. If something, I think this movie has the record of sickening me in the shortest amount of time.It's definitely not a good musical as the singing could not be appreciated because of all the horrible noise around it. Everything had me feeling dizzy and feeling embarrassed for the movie. A specially cringe-worthy scene was the one with the Tinkerbell like fairy doing this strange dancing and looking extremely fake. I've seen some people that also hated the movie say that at least the Art Direction was decent but I really couldn't see pass the bizarre camera effects. Well, I got to see the horrible make- up worn by the "Diamond girls" which were supposed to be the most beautiful women in all France. Well, I was extremely disappointed in that department.Still, I must admit that Lady Marmalade is one of the best pop songs I've ever heard and is a great collaboration between 2000's most successful pop ladies. I was left wanting to hear the whole song and watching a similar performance as the music video but they could even take good advantage of it.I don't recommend it at all. Disappointing.

This movie is one of the best I have ever seen. If you are reading this, and have not seen the movie. Go to your library or Blockbuster and RENT IT NOW!!! You will be hooked. The Best part of the movie was that all musical-haters love it. My friend (who will remain name-less) Watched the whole thing without complaining. And she turns off the TV if any Disney Movie is on. Shes pretty sad. ANYWAY! The best part(s) were the songs "You Make Her Feel Like A Virgin", and the composition of the play. Oh, the red room scene was pretty good too. PLEASE rent this movie, you will LOVE it. If not, you can write a review and yell at me in it, I wont mind.

This movie is tragic, but that is an integral part of the story. I think it is still a wonderful movie, and I'm not the type that likes sad movies. If you like love stories or musicals, and even if you don't, you should find time to sit down and watch the movie. Even though you can understand the movie without giving it your full attention, it would really be a shame to miss the visuals presented in the movie. From the first moment you see Christian sitting at his typewriter, there are subtleties that are present throughout the movie serving to raise the enjoyment of the viewer. One of the most visually stimulating scenes in the movie is the initial dance scene in which Christian first lays eyes on Satine, and most of the other scenes are just as gripping as that one. No matter what type of movie you like, this one is a must-see. The music, the dancing, the love interest, and the comedic undertones all combine to make this film a fantastic experience.

Yes. Yes it is 2015 and I am reviewing Moulin Rouge, which I am aware came out in 2001. I have seen this movie well over 100 times and can sing, not well, every song from the movie. Now that is out of the way I will give an actual review of this movie. The theme of this review is "theme." Spoiler alert, it's not love. Or is it?It's the very early 1900's and Christian (Ewan McGregor), a young writer, moves to Paris. He meets Toulouse-Lautrec (John Leguizamo) and agrees to help him and other actors in this Bohemian movement to finish and present their show "Spectacular Spectacular" to Harold Zigler (Jim Broadbent), the owner of the infamous Moulin Rouge. Well to make ones dreams come true, a few white lies are invented and next thing you know Christian is not some poor writer but instead posing as the Duke of Monroth (which is later played by Richard Roxburgh) to convince the star courtesan, Satine (Nicole Kidman) to listen to their work who they hope will later take it to Harold.Long story short Satine discovers Christian isn't who he says he is, they fall in love despite this fact. Unfortunately she is a prized "whore" and needs to actually be with the Duke to save the failing Moulin Rouge but is starting to feel guilty because she is in love. The Duke finds out about Christian and Satine and tries to rape her. Satine decides to give up her life at the Moulin Rouge for a life with a penniless writer but soon finds out she is dying and ends it with Christian to "save him" but instead it backfires. She dies. But before passing, they reconcile. Christian is heartbroken.Let's talk about theme. The fact that I have been watching this film for almost fifteen years I have discussed this film with many people during that time. A common topic is theme. Most of the time the answer is love. Is love actually a theme? No. Love plays a role in many themes especially in this film; moral implications, the truth of human nature, the struggle for human dignity, complexity of human relationships and coming of age. Lets pick one. I will put it out there the theme of Moulin Rouge is the coming of age/loss of innocence/growing awareness.Let's examine each one.  Coming of Age. Christian left home for Paris to be a famous writer. He is new to a big city and we have to watch him develop into a man.  Loss of Innocence. This applies both to Christian and Satine. Christian for obvious reasons (falling in love with a courtesan) and Satine because being a "whore" was the only life she has ever known.  Growing Awareness. Christian and Satine realize life is not always what it presents itself to be. These two realized if in opposite ways. Christian ended up realizing it is sometimes worse than you want it to be and Satine realizing it can be better than you think it is. Of course that's before she dies. This film is shot well. The editing creates the needed chaos for emotion. The visual effects are appropriate to each scene. Costume and makeup design are on point. And don't even get me started on how amazing they did as singers There is emotion created from this film. You may not like it, you may think it's cheesy but I respect that this film was shot different than anything else I have ever seen. I liked the organized chaos and I enjoyed watching Christian and Satine come of age, lose their innocence and grow more aware of who they are as individuals and as lovers.

Review title: The musical for non musical lovers.
Review_body: "Spectacular, Spectacular! No words in the vernacular, can describe this great event you'll be dumb with wonderment" Although these are lyrics from one of the many great songs in this movie they're the perfect words to describe this movie! I don't know what makes me so crazy about this movie but I just love it. The songs, the actors, the story... Everything! Not only do Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman make a great performance, but let me tell you, they can sing! They also have great chemistry which every good movie needs. I can't forget all the other actors too! They all did great performances.Beauty, Freedom, Truth and Love may be the main words to describe this but it's also somewhat a comedy hehe it has it's funny moments.

I decided to watch the movie The Moulin Rouge. I was first introduced to this movie by my wife and I have loved it ever since. It is a compelling comedic love story based in a historical setting with real historic references to war, art, diseases and artistic revolution upon a fictional story line along with fictional character. Through this critique we will be looking at some essentials of the plot, theme and characters as well as analysis, interpretations, evaluations and engagements.So starting with the plot, characters. The plot surrounds a penniless bohemian revolutionary writer and his love interest, a courtesan in a night club known as the Moulin Rouge who is aspiring to be an actress. The villain in this story is portrayed as a misogynist duke who falls in love with the courtesan and wants her for himself. The duke plays an essential role in the plot because he is not only the villain, but the main cause of the plot. The duke shows his essential characteristics in two ways. The first, he is the wedge between the protagonist and his love interest. The second goes into this because the wedge is because the duke is the only one who has offered to fund turning the Moulin Rouge from a night club to a theatre to that the courtesan can have her dream. The penniless writer is accidentally thrown into it under the impression that he would become the Moulin Rouges head writer for the bohemian revolution. However, because he falls in love with her, and very unfortunate miscommunications, the courtesan falls for the writer to the point where she cannot bring herself to betray the writer by satisfying the duke for his money.The theme is very easy to perceive. The theme is set in France in the year 1900. At this time, France was going through a revolution of arts and expression which was known as the Bohemian Revolution. The theme is mixed with some modern principles and songs but for the most part, keeps true to the history of the time period with dance, dress, art and even historical facts and political views at the time. The protagonist shows the purpose of this theme early in the movie as he remembers the conflict he had with his father concerning the difference in socially accepted principles. The main theme of this is of an early 1900s night club but does transform, adding to the theme of the Bohemian Revolution itself, into a more artistic and higher culture form of entertainment. Analyzing this film, there are many themes and characterizations that carry throughout the film. Starting with the theme that has been developed. The protagonist going from a household deemed by society as well developed and mannered, to a community that sees art and behavior more liberally, it shows the increasing liberal nature of humanity and self-expression. Characterizations are more along the lines of usual night clubs where most of the men and women involved in this story are more sex driven than those who are not, or in other words, the protagonist and his group are pretty much the only characters who are not driven by sexual desires in this movie. The interpretation the Moulin Rouge as a movie and a concept is trying to provide is that love is greater than anything anyone can offer. With the duke and the courtesan, as stated in the plot, the courtesan cannot sacrifice love just to win over money from a possessive duke.This movie, looking at it, is probably not within the confines of higher art, and would most likely be put in the wonderful, ever expanding box of popular culture. The movie in itself has enough comedy and sexual innuendos that it could possibly be considered boring or offensive to those of higher art or of previous generations. I consider this entertaining because of the comedy and music, such things are relatable to our current pop culture and other pieces of culture that us as an audience find entertaining, livable, or just plain hilarious. This is due to the overbearing underwhelming even childish special effects (e.g. mustached moon singing in background) and overdone makeup to help illustrate the colors and theme of the movie. Looking at reviews of this movie from IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes, it is a general 7-7.5 out of 10. However, most of the users of IMDb found it to be the best movie they have seen in a long time. As well according to IMDb, this film was the first musical nominated for best picture in 10 years, the last being Beauty and the Beast. Most of the reviews I have seen have matched my review and personal opinions of the movie based on the plot, characters, themes, and overall likeableness of the film. I would definitely give it a higher rating than the average given, probably at least an 8-8.5 but that is just me. Overall this is an exceptional film if you are not looking for a higher culture performance or form of entertainment that can come from this picture. The plot and characters are very easy to believe and the theme is very appropriate along with the music. Everything was put together very nicely and very professionally and I have to say, it was a great movie, would love to watch it again or recommend it to others.

I thought that this was the worst movie that I have ever watch. I have never walked out of a movie theater until the day I tried to sit through this movie. I tried to watch it again because everyone said that it got really good at the end and I thought that maybe I did not watch long enough. But watching it all the way thought I realized that I hated it worse the second time. But I guess everyone is entitled to their own opinion if you liked it good for you. I thought the the acting was almost as bad as the storyline. I especially dislike movies that give away the ending in the first 2 min. of the movie. But actually her death at the end was the most interesting part of the movie.
